decided end sept - weather - everything resolved travel . ptc peak summer crazy busy know.
we stayed years beach hotel th floor nice, hotel felt dated much inside , looks revamp thought us.pct nice find atrek forth hotel side dining , close much residence wing buggys.
southall money held dont lake view prepared shot ,
im mindful ahead happy southall good year. trust cant whatever reason trip.
the price 2200 inc 10 nights two adults flights emirates manchester - thought bargain - able upgrade 380 save. wouldnt lock much nearer time.

column5:
we have decided to go end of sept - better weather - and hopefully everything will be resolved for travel . also ptc in peak summer is crazy busy as you know.
we stayed a few years back at the beach hotel on the 5 th floor and it was nice, but the hotel i felt was dated and not much really inside , looks now its had a bit of revamp so thought it would be better for us.pct is nice but i find it a bit of atrek back and forth to the hotel side for dining etc , ok if your close by but it would be to much for me if we were out by the residence wing even with the buggys.
southall who we are doing it with as they have some money of mine held dont do the lake view as i was prepared to give that a shot ,
im mindful it may not go ahead so happy to go with southall as they have been good with me this year. and i trust them if we cant for whatever reason take the trip.
the price is around 2200 all inc for 10 nights for two adults with flights with emirates from manchester - i thought that was a bargain - might be able to do the upgrade on the 380 with what we save. but i wouldnt lock into that until much nearer the time.
im liking the fact a few new restaurants and bars so it wont feel perhaps as samey as it got.

column5:
booking hotels on the day is not a problem but the price will vary. i cannot say i have been anywhere where every single hotel in town is fully booked and many people book a room for the first night then either stay where they are or if there is somewhere better or cheaper down the road move.
if my flight landed in nyc as it did many years ago we spent 2 days seeing the sights then headed off to killington for a weeks ski ing -
if you do plan to come please spread your horizons beyond a hot humid city. there are some stunning spectaculr temples in bangkok but once you have seen one you have seen them all and i am sure you have bars and malls in the us !
i doubt if the just over a week quarantine will be lifted by then so maybe delay your plans , just kep looking out for updates
either hit the beach or head for the hills !

column4:
want phuket right ?
current restrictions phuket:
- massage parlours traditional massage businesses, massages spa businesses, massage businesses health, massage businesses beauty, including thai massage establishments, foot massages similar businesses suspended.
- prohibited operate snorkelling scuba diving business.
- walking street markets prohibited
- forbidden join social activities, drink alcohol alcoholic beverages public areas parks, playgrounds, canal roads, roads reservoirs, public caves, etc.
- restaurants food businesses prohibited customers premises 9pm
- department stores, shopping centers must hold promotional activities must limit number visitors open hours.
- cinemas, theaters, water parks, swimming pools ‒both government private (i.e. condos, communal pools) ‒ open public, including swimming pools competitive athletes, allowed open.
- indoor fitness courts gyms, fitness centres badminton courts, prohibited opening.
"forbidden join social activities, drink alcohol alcoholic beverages public areas" means can't meet friends beach drink beer together ?
column5:
why would you want to go to phuket right now ?
current restrictions for phuket:
- massage parlours and traditional massage businesses, massages at spa businesses, massage businesses for health, massage businesses for beauty, including thai massage establishments, foot massages and other similar businesses are suspended.
- it is prohibited to operate a snorkelling or scuba diving business.
- walking street markets are prohibited
- it is forbidden to join social activities, drink alcohol or alcoholic beverages in public areas such as parks, playgrounds, canal roads, roads around reservoirs, public caves, etc.
- all restaurants and other food businesses are prohibited from having customers on premises after 9pm
- department stores, shopping centers must not hold any promotional activities and must limit the number of visitors during open hours.
- cinemas, theaters, water parks, swimming pools ‒both government and private (i.e. condos, communal pools) ‒ that are open to the public, including swimming pools for competitive athletes, are not allowed to open.
- indoor fitness courts such as gyms, fitness centres and badminton courts, are prohibited from opening.
"forbidden to join social activities, drink alcohol or alcoholic beverages in public areas" probably means you can't meet friends at the beach and drink a beer together ?

column4:
forget scuba diving snorkelling , arabian sea rough that. goa catering domestic tourists traditional season foreign tourist ends early april trend carry later month. visit easter period stay open easter. recommend basic beach cottages , right beach benaulim -  near main beach restaurants shacks entertainment.
edited: 4:01 am, march 19,
column5:
forget about scuba diving and snorkelling , the arabian sea is too rough for that. goa is catering more for domestic tourists and although the traditional season for foreign tourist ends early april the trend is to carry on until later in the month. your visit is over the easter period too and most stay open until after easter. can recommend these basic beach cottages , right on the beach at benaulim -  also near to all the main beach restaurants and shacks with entertainment.
edited: 4:01 am, march 19, 2021

column4: cancun several times, drug cartels operate anywhere near it. american lots american/mexican style restaurants bars to. resorts lovely problem mexico weather. torrential rain day. happened sister flew home four days, happened hurricane season. humidity summer worse dubai. lucky good time 5* resort reasonable price - definitely cartels!
column5: i have been to cancun several times, the drug cartels don't operate anywhere near it. its very american with lots of american/mexican style restaurants bars etc to go to. the resorts can be lovely but the problem with mexico can be the weather. it can have torrential rain all day. it happened to my sister who flew home after four days, it has happened to me and that wasn't in hurricane season. the humidity is summer is worse than dubai. you can be lucky and have a really good time in a 5* resort for a reasonable price - and definitely absolutely no cartels!

column4:
singapore less hot april/may bangkok casual: walk shorts sg everyone wears long trousers.
and subway trains sg don’t tinted windows obviously tinted bts trains. makes difference sit sunny side.
worth mentioning: night clubs entertainment venues sg closed year city closes currently 10.30 alcohol sold time.
column5:
singapore may be less hot in april/may but bangkok is more casual: you can walk around in shorts if you like while in sg everyone wears long trousers.
and subway trains in sg don’t have tinted windows while they are obviously tinted in bts trains. makes a bit difference if you sit on the sunny side.
worth mentioning: night clubs and entertainment venues in sg have been closed for a year and the city closes down currently at 10.30 pm since alcohol may not be sold after that time.
column8: Bangkok vs Singapore and Hong Kong in March-May

column5:
have to agree, kamala was the most 'open'.
also surprised how 'crowded' (relative to me) kata was. off season, july maybe, and it was also, but take away the surfers, and it would have been empty. katamama, and the bar a couple doors down, both with customers, now & then, along with surf shop, now renting sup, since the surf is flat.
stopped at most of the beaches on west side, and they really are lovely, even patong. least favorable looking, though taking nothing away from it, was karon. revamping the one access area, which i never liked, but still, the seas are crystal clear, and every beach except kata, was basically empty.
vids of a few here:

column4: stayed both, comments bophut true, fully refurbished years ago. bophut beach pretty course sand water clear. time, spoilt jet skis noise music cocotams plenty good restaurants area. lawana photos don’t show rocky beach . anantara’s service good breakfasts.and food general. alternative rent private pool villa. want good beach popular area trade usually highly populated resorts choeng mon beach nowhere noisy busy chaweng.
column5: i have stayed at both, comments re bophut are not true, it was fully refurbished a few years ago. bophut beach is pretty course sand and water not clear. at time, spoilt by jet skis and noise from music from cocotams but plenty of good restaurants in area. lawana photos don’t really show how rocky the beach is . both anantara’s have great service and very good breakfasts.and food in general. the other alternative is to rent a private pool villa. if you want a good beach in a popular area the trade off will be usually highly populated with resorts choeng mon has great beach and nowhere as noisy or as busy as chaweng.

column4:
asif, starting thread short time skye.but comments road isles journey:
unless train buff, car. driving route follows train route pretty much terms views advantage allowing stop enjoy much lovely scenery route.
neptune's staircase worth time views ben clear fine views canal.


the glenfinnan viaduct - walking route nearer interest. spot alone peak season.

my favourite views glenfinnan hotel (good lunch mentioned) beautiful st finnan's church nearby.


loch nan uamh bonnie prince charlie connections (similar glenfinnan) - beautiful sea loch several places pull photos drink views.
arisaig nice cafe harbour boat small isles leaves.gets busy.
camusdarach i've mentioned silver sands - me, decent weather day, highlights road isles.
i mallaig many rate much - whole lot final destination; cafes restaurants shops fishing boats, ferries come harbour islands, seagulls keen overhead skye sits tantalisingly across sea.


that route along road isles could easily day, include lunch somewhere short strolls.easy enough too, simply enjoy unfolding scene, photos skye.book ferry well advance.
column5:
asif, you might be better starting your own thread about some short time on skye.but some comments on the road to the isles journey:
unless you're a train buff, i would take the car. the driving route follows the train route pretty much in terms of views but has the advantage of allowing you to stop and enjoy so much lovely scenery on route.
neptune's staircase is worth time if the views to the ben are clear as you get some really fine views of it from the canal.


the glenfinnan viaduct - there is a walking route to take you nearer it if of interest. great spot though you won't be alone in peak season.

my favourite views around glenfinnan are from the hotel itself (good for lunch as mentioned) and also from the beautiful st finnan's church nearby.


loch nan uamh has bonnie prince charlie connections too (similar to glenfinnan) - it's a beautiful sea loch with several places you can pull over for photos and just to drink in the views.
arisaig has a nice cafe down at the harbour where the boat to the small isles leaves.gets busy.
camusdarach i've already mentioned and the silver sands - to me, on a decent weather day, probably the highlights of the road to the isles.
i like mallaig though many don't rate it much - there isn't a whole lot to do in it as a final destination; a few cafes and restaurants and shops but it still has the fishing boats, the ferries come in to the harbour from the islands, seagulls keen overhead and skye sits tantalisingly across the sea.


that route along the road to the isles could easily take up a day, if you include lunch somewhere and some short strolls.easy enough too, to simply enjoy the unfolding scene, take some photos and make for skye.book the ferry well in advance.

all,
i you’re safe well! :) i’m currently planning trip outer hebrides normally consider short notice end june/beginning july (i experience orkney, shetland, mull etc. appreciate islands usually start book far advance) – covid situation is, i'm starting confident book something, i’d questions locals regulars forum!
1. usually avoid july remote inner-scottish trips order avoid midges families kids school/general high season lots campervans – wondering expect notable impact choose go.
i’d guess islands windy enough former problem, accommodation limited (and campervans currently restricted official campsites, read), much capacity visitors. wanted check time bad idea go. i’m worried weather, accept unpredictable (even aware usually ideal scottish travel month – looking weather brought us, left rely ;) ).
2. many forum, i’m wondering split time. terms i'm looking for, i'm usually interested everything. hiking, beaches (the best ones told!), sights (everything castles distilleries), good restaurant two (if open). i’ll something 7-10 nights – limiting factor cost.
i’ve seen suggestion forum something nights lewis&harris, uists/benbecula barra 10 night split, wondering best cut i’d need shorter, want rush it. end 8, thinking leave barra future trip (possibly connection coll tiree) - worth going day trip south uist case? drive straight skip uists/benbecula case visit barra instead? aware cut enough weeks every islands - i'd rather sure cut "right" needed.

column5:
hey all,
i hope you’re all safe and well! :) i’m currently planning my first trip to the outer hebrides at what i would normally consider too short notice this end of june/beginning of july (i have experience with orkney, shetland, mull etc. and appreciate the islands usually start to book up far in advance) – but with the covid situation being what it is, i'm just now starting to get confident to actually book something, and i’d have a few questions for the locals and regulars on the forum!
1. i usually avoid july for more remote inner-scottish trips in order to avoid both the midges and the families with kids out of school/general high season and lots of campervans – and was wondering if i should expect either to have a notable impact should i choose to go.
i’d guess the islands are windy enough for the former to not be a problem, and with accommodation limited (and campervans currently restricted to the official campsites, or so i have read), there is only so much capacity for visitors. but just wanted to check if that time is a bad idea to go. i’m not so worried about the weather, i accept that that is unpredictable as it is (even though i am aware usually may is the ideal scottish travel month – but looking at the weather just now and what this may has brought us, what is there left to rely on ;) ).
2. like so many on the forum, i’m wondering about how to split my time. in terms of what i'm looking for, i'm usually interested in a bit of everything. hiking, beaches (the best ones up there i have been told!), sights (everything from castles to distilleries), and a good restaurant or two (if those are open). i’ll have something like 7-10 nights – the limiting factor is cost.
i’ve seen suggestion on the forum to do something like 4 nights for lewis&harris, 3 uists/benbecula and 3 for barra for a 10 night split, and was just wondering where would be best to cut if i’d need to go shorter, since i don't want to rush it. if i end up with 7 or 8, i was thinking to leave out barra for a future trip (possibly in connection with coll and tiree) - or would it be worth going over for a day trip from south uist in any case? or should i drive straight through and skip the uists/benbecula in that case and visit barra instead? i am aware i will always have to cut things out and there is probably enough to do for weeks on each and every one of the islands - but i'd rather make sure to cut the "right" things if needed.
apologies for the long message – i’d usually try to do a lot more research myself before coming with more refined questions, but the short notice is making me eager and a little nervous to book accommodation/car/flights asap.
thank you all so much and stay safe!
sebastian

column4:
club lounge nice normally 6-8 evening , restrict . april fantastic time travel , weather perfect . found years travelling dubai club popular used many deals fantastic bars city happy hours ladies nights ( ladies pay comp many drinks free reduced ) bars something going , places sean r mentioned top ones visit near dubai mall.
i personally metro much , tend taxis , cheaper uk oil cheap middle east , add forth across city visiting marina area et busy traffic , id plan metro cabs up.
column5:
club lounge is nice normally around 6-8 pm each evening , but it does restrict you . april is a fantastic time to travel , weather should be just about perfect . i have found over the years of travelling to dubai club is not as popular as it used to be as there are so many deals in fantastic bars in the city from happy hours to ladies nights ( that is when ladies don't pay or are comp so many drinks either free or reduced ) or the bars have something going on , and the places sean r mentioned are the very top ones to visit and all near dubai mall.
i personally don't use the metro that much , but tend to use taxis , its cheaper than the uk as oil is cheap in the middle east , but it can add up if your back and forth across the city visiting and the marina area can et busy with traffic , id plan on the metro and then have cabs as a back up.

column4:

when core clientele “drink much can’ instruction challenge rather advice, there’s little point trying something else.

column5:
for some of these resorts, i’m surprised they don’t just move the beds around the bar, close the restaurants and set up a doner/shawarma trolley. everything else in between is just redundant.
when the core clientele take “drink as much as you can’ as an instruction or challenge rather than advice, there’s little point in trying to be something else.
speaking from a position of experience of course; i went to sharm for a diving holiday and never touched a boat or the sea. 🥃
edited: 3:59 pm, january 06, 2021

but we found most staff helpful and polite, and the hotel was clean, it certainly need an update, the location was also good.
the a la carte, restaurants were good, we could use these if booked in advance instead of the evening buffet.
enjoyed our holiday as the weather was great, and met some nice people, but would not return.
made the most of it as we were very luck to go with the current virus situation
not surprised they put dubai back on the travel corridor as we found itvti be very busy after the new year.
stay safe everyone

column5: i love raffles , service is excellent i booked a club room both times , nice balcony . just one thing though the pool wasn't heated so in december i would imagine a bit cold for swimming . marriot marquis ? if so its a good hotel with good service levels , heated pool and good restaurant's .

column4: mallorca amazing! definitely drive valdemossa, amazing hikes tramuntana mountains. area visit deiá, cala deiá sóller port de sóller (you old tram port, lovely part island) sa collabra must see, walk torrent amazing too. weather good, renting rib exploring calas along north east amazing day out. mallorca amazing wine too, book tour ribas, oldest winery island, lovely options. rose lovely. wine front  definitely try an2 anima negra (and feeling flush), 12 volt, sio. many amazing restaurants palma, definitely time sunset drink es boulard (the museum bar) wall old town. st elm st jordi lovely little towns visit. (i'll stop here, questions shoot message! ) forget ensaimada, crema option fave!
column5: mallorca is amazing! definitely take a drive out to valdemossa, there are some amazing hikes in the tramuntana mountains. and while you're in the area visit deiá, cala deiá sóller and port de sóller (you can get the old tram down to the port, it's such a lovely part of the island) sa collabra is also a must see, and you can walk up the torrent which is amazing too. if the weather is good, renting a rib and exploring the calas along the north east is an amazing day out. mallorca has some amazing wine too, if you can book a tour at ribas, it's the oldest winery on the island, they have a few lovely options. their rose is lovely. on the wine front  definitely try the an2 by anima negra (and the an if you're feeling flush), 12 volt, and sio. there are so many amazing restaurants in palma, but definitely make time for a sunset drink at es boulard (the museum bar) it's up on the wall of the old town. st elm and st jordi are also lovely little towns to visit. (i'll stop here, but if you have any questions shoot me a message! ) and don't forget to have an ensaimada, the crema option is my fave!

column5:
ive travelled all over and also was in phoneix one year in early august , phoneix and vegas were scorching hot but did not have the humidity that dubai has , so im just saying maybe take it a tad easily a bit in the day .
we walked with ease the vegas strip at midday and whilst phoenix was hotter it was manageable and we could eat outside with some degree of comfort , although most places did have misters .
no chance of that in dubai, its just to hot.
hotter than than and more uncomfortable would be singapore. ive never found the states that hot at that time ever.
a lot can be achieved in doors and early pm . dubai mall is really lovely in the pm so you could do burj khallifa before it gets dark then move on to the mall /fountains etc. its a huge mall with some highly expensive shops .
mall of the emirates is pretty standard now , but worth a trip if you want to ski at ski dubai.
atlantis and jumeriah beach are nice .
marina more for the late pm with the bars and restaurants - maybe do yellow boats tour but prob best when it is a bit cooler ie late pm.
i would say the theme parks are not as good as the states . ferrari world i thought was a bit to educational but it draws in people for that big ride. never done img i think a lot is indoors as well.
edited: 11:45 am, june 05, 2021

column4: went japan christmas new years eve 2019. planned skiing decided much traveling nagano. went tokyo, hakone, kyoto side trips nara, himeji, & hiroshima, hamamatsu tokyo. plan spending new years eve? huge family holiday japan lot restaurants close early. luckily, live entertainment hotel spent new years eve there. wanted tokyo everyone started travel see families nye.
column5: we went to japan for christmas and new years eve in 2019. we had planned on skiing but decided it was too much traveling to get to nagano. we went to tokyo, hakone, kyoto with side trips to nara, himeji, & hiroshima, hamamatsu and back to tokyo. where do you plan on spending new years eve? it is a huge family holiday in japan and a lot of restaurants close very early. luckily, there was live entertainment at our hotel so we spent new years eve there. we wanted to get back in tokyo before everyone started to travel to see their families over nye.

column4: almost impossible booking restaurant. weeks away, let alone weekend. best bet talk campsite staff see local pubs walk ins service. advertised hit miss. major seaside towns plenty options terms fish chip vans, away pizza upmarket food vans evening stroll impromptu quayside picnic good option. otherwise, look bring cook simple barbecue whatever available. time matter pack macs weekend look brilliant, weather-wise.
column5: it is almost impossible to get a booking for a restaurant. even for weeks away, let alone this weekend. your best bet would be to talk to the campsite staff and see if any local pubs are doing a walk ins only service. this may not be advertised and will be hit and miss. the major seaside towns seem to have plenty of options in terms of fish and chip vans, take away pizza and some more upmarket food vans so an evening stroll with an impromptu quayside picnic can be a good option. otherwise, maybe look at what you can bring or cook for yourselves on a simple barbecue or whatever you have available. you will have a great time no matter what although pack the macs as this weekend does not look to be brilliant, weather-wise.

column4: self catering look lakelovers "heart lakes" (now jointly owned) cumbrian cottages, select ones swimming pool access, many though. hotels allow book leisure day passes swimming, avoid public swimming baths troutbeck gets busy. nowhere flat lakes cycle except old keswick railway line, hire, i'm sure advice. brockhole windermere lots activities kids, used summer classes adventure book quickly. number honister via ferrata, never forget experience. wet days (you them) kendal indoor climbing center great, drink watch child learn climb safely, ambleside well tried that, lot smaller. prefer ambleside central places, craxy golf, putting, tennis well easier walks, grasmere. someone said ambleside yha good, best place lakes sit outside drink right lake, pubs near by. platty kayaking derwent good, sure windy day though.
column5: self catering look at lakelovers and "heart of the lakes" (now jointly owned) and cumbrian cottages, you can select ones with swimming pool access, not many now though. some hotels allow you to book leisure day passes to go swimming, avoid the public swimming baths at troutbeck it gets very busy. nowhere is flat in the lakes to cycle except maybe the old keswick railway line, but ask before you hire, i'm sure they can give advice. brockhole on windermere has lots of activities for kids, they also used to do summer classes for adventure things but they book up very quickly. number one thing to do is the honister via ferrata, you will never forget the experience. for wet days (you will get them) kendal indoor climbing center is great, you can just have a drink and watch your child learn to climb safely, there is one at ambleside as well but not tried that, it is a lot smaller. we prefer ambleside as it is central for most places, it has craxy golf, putting, tennis as well and some easier walks, such as to grasmere. as someone said ambleside yha is good, best place in the lakes to sit outside and have a drink right on the lake, better than the pubs near by. platty kayaking on derwent is really good, make sure it is not a windy day though.

column4: we’re long fantastic six days wales. lucky pick week weather glorious (11th july onwards) loved every minute. two days monmouth, two aberystwyth two rhayader. found everyone extremely friendly wherever went, travelled over. pre booked restaurants excursions vale rheidol railway, red kite feeding rhayader. can’t wait more. we’ve tenby north wales, haven’t ventured snowdon barmouth area, that’s next list.
column5: we’re not long back from a fantastic six days in wales. we were lucky to pick the week where the weather was glorious (11th july onwards) and loved every minute. we had two days in monmouth, two in aberystwyth and two in rhayader. we found everyone extremely friendly wherever we went, and we travelled all over. we pre booked all restaurants and excursions such as the vale of rheidol railway, and red kite feeding at rhayader. we can’t wait to go back and do some more. we’ve already been to tenby and north wales, but we haven’t ventured to snowdon or the barmouth area, so that’s next on our list.
column8: My thoughts on Wales at this time

column5:
you don't say in your op when you have booked (what month) to stay in kuta and why kuta was your choice?
at present due to covid-19 kuta is not the hustle/bustle is usually is and post covid-19 it may not quite be the same as it was or who knows it may be even better!
i can only comment on kuta in low season (not aussie school holiday season/s or christmas/new year) e.g may/june (when we usually stay) also have stayed in august & oct/november.(oct/november 2019 kuta was very quiet).
australian school holidays you would expect that kuta is busier with lots more aussies about.
while most think of kuta as the 'party area' (late night/early morning) the 'party area' is one small section along jl legian (the main street from kuta to legian).
you can walk past this area during the day & at night, if it is of no interest to you just keep walking.
some bars/restaurants do have music, e.g a guitarist, vocalist/guitarist or band.
kuta is also most known for it's accommodation for backpackers, surfers, budget travellers but these days
singles, couples, groups, families stay in kuta. guests ages from the young to their 80's.
the surf is rolling waves so not really suitable for swimming (it also has rips) more for boogie boarding/surfers.
you can still eat cheap in kuta where you will find restaurants/warung that don't add tax to the total of the food bill.
beach bars (esky with ice cold drinks) under the trees south of kuta gate (the main entrance onto kuta beach.
beach bars on kuta beach and you will find beach bars along the beach to legian/seminyak.
beach lounges can be hired on the beach as you walk away (north) from the main kuta beach area.
kuta is also shopping whether it's market shops where you can bargain prices for e.g beachwear, bags, hats, sunglasses, shoes/sandals, souvenirs etc or fixed price shops e.g beachwalk bali shopping complex, matahari department store (may not be there when we get to return), kuta galleria, lippo plaza sunset road, discovery mall & lippo mall both in south kuta (tuban).
waterbom waterslide park also in south kuta on jl kartika plaza.
yes there is traffic, during peak times of the day/evening/night it's busier on the roads & traffic moves slower, jl pantai kuta is one way traffic, jl bakungsari (jl singosari)one way, jl legian (from jl melasti) to kuta one way,jl kartika plaza two way traffic.
walk from kuta to south kuta (tuban) along the beachfront path, a very pleasant walk, along the beach to legian (north) & seminyak or the streets (footpaths).

column5:
all the good info above aside ubud - gili t - “down south” is a popular itinerary.
fastboats
easily done with fastboat companies who will include free pickup in ubud and free dropoff “down south” on return.
if you want the best fastboat company then www.bluewater-express.com is widely acknowledged as the best company (we use them for gili t to serangan/“down south”). they are one of the few companies who has services out of padangbai (ideal for ubud) and a “direct” service from gilis to serangan (ideal for “down south”).
ubud
there are lots of villas and highend accommodation available but be very wary of location if you want to be close to town/amenities. always check exact location of any property carefully. never believe any property bumf on location or even go by the name as an indication of location. there is ubud town, ubud district (up to 8km from town in some directions) and “nowhere near ubud but we’ll call ourselves ubud anyway even though it is over 20km/1hr drive to town”. one of the best examples of the worst is “padma ubud”.
gili t
the gili islands are vehicle free. people walk around, cycle or take a donkey/trap.
the islands aren’t that big. you can cycle around gili t in 40minutes.
best if you decide first what part of the island you want to stay and go from there. e.g. east/southeast side is where the fastboats arrive and main party area. we stay in this area at a dive resort ( www.manta-dive.com ) as more interested in diving and snorkeling.
west side has a goodchoice of accommodation and local bars/eateries without the louder nightlife.
also ideal for sunsets with views of bali and mt agung.
north and south quieter.
although popular it isn’t overdeveloped from a highend luxury resort/villa point of view so limited choice.
if looking for a private villa just be aware that some properties using the description “villas” may be just large “bungalow” rooms around a pool.
purely as an example  has these type of rooms but also have a couple of villas.
another example 
be aware that these are more “inland” with majo being basically in the middle of the island ~ 1km from beach/life.
seminyak
has lots of villas but need again like ubud to check exact location. although not as bad as ubud.
seminyak is part of the large urban tourist sprawl of kuta/legian/seminyak. basically one area merges into the next just by crossing the road from 1 bar/shop to another. legian in the middle only covers 1.5km of beach. you can actually be in seminyak and be closer to the nightclub area or beachwalk mall of kuta than seminyak square.
there are plenty of villas close to seminyak square.
at the south end of seminyak/border with legian (jalan double six/jalan arjuna) you will also find villas in the area behind the double six luxury hotel.
have to check location of any property carefully as you can find some properties calling themselves seminyak who are over 5km inland from the beach on the other side of the jalan sunset bypass and also in the middle of nowhere between seminyak and canggu.

column4: choose nusa lembongan lombok. nl quick 30 minute boat ride sanur island paradise. plenty beach bars, cafes restaurants fabulous array water activities. stay main town area jungut batu mushroom bay highly recommend staying hai tide huts right beach. they’re cheap fantastic. lombok quick 30 minute flight garuda bali. unspoilt paradise stepping stone spectacular gili islands famous diving snorkelling. can’t wrong place.
column5: i would choose either nusa lembongan or lombok. nl is a quick 30 minute boat ride from sanur and is an island paradise. plenty of beach bars, cafes and restaurants and a fabulous array of water activities. i would either stay around the main town area of jungut batu or go to mushroom bay where i can highly recommend staying at the hai tide huts which are right on the beach. they’re not cheap but they are fantastic. lombok is a quick 30 minute flight with garuda from bali. this is an unspoilt paradise and is a stepping stone to the spectacular gili islands which are famous for diving and snorkelling. you can’t go wrong with either place.
column8: Which beach area should we stay in?

column4: hello grace, lot rubbish washed beach particularly plastic rainy season. talk seminyak locals comes islands true lot villagers rivers dispose waste. seminyak area surf beach many people prefer swim hotels pool particularly swim pool bar. rubbish gathered piled high side everyday. beach fun attack beach sellers encounter offering jewellery sarongs, bags, hats clothing, real designer watches sunglassessouvenirs massage, show interest swarmed . sitting beach sunset drinks experience.
column5: hello again grace, a lot of rubbish is washed up on the beach particularly plastic from the rainy season. if you talk to seminyak locals they say it comes from the other islands maybe true but a lot of the villagers use rivers to dispose of their waste. seminyak area is more of a surf beach and many people prefer to swim in their hotels pool particularly if there is swim up pool bar. the rubbish is gathered piled up high off to the side everyday. the beach is still fun and the attack of the beach sellers is an encounter offering you jewellery sarongs, bags, hats and other clothing, real designer watches and sunglassessouvenirs and massage, if you show any interest you will be swarmed . sitting on the beach for sunset drinks is another great experience.

column5:
hi,
first to note to avoid any confusion that the kembali villas you listed in post #3 (perhaps it was an auto link) is not kembali beach bungalows in amed.
kembali villas linked in post #3 are in seminyak.
do you dive or just snorkeling.
pemuteran
check exact location of any property carefully. pemuteran spreads out a long way also inland.
pemuteran is mrs pigs favourite after amed.
we stay at 
you have to walk down the beach a little to enter the sea for snorkeling. main reasons is that their are a lot of sea urchins in the sea along with low lying reefs close to shore. there is a signpost.
entry is more or less in front of the pondok sari.
you will also find the biorock reef restoration project.
the only thing is that pemuteran bay is very sandy (just offshore). at full moon/spring tides/windy/choppy seas the sand can get churned up in the bay. even snorkeling close to shore it can be like snorkeling in a milkshake. literally can’t see your hand in front of your face. biorock not visible.
i’ve been diving well offshore and when in shallower water 10-15m on a sunny day it was like diving in a snowglobe with all the glistening sand.
i use the dive centre on the beach behind the swimming pool/wellness massage centre.

they have 2 dive boats. one rib and one larger fibreglass hull boat.
if only snorkeling you can enquire at the dive centre or others along the beach, about snorkeling trips menjangan.
dive trips often willing to take snorkelers if space. advantage is the boat goes from the beach.
you can arrange snorkeling trips locally but this may involve a road trip in a minibus before picking up a local boat.
out on the main singaraja road you will find a few restaurants geared up for tourists. we particularly like warung tirta sari at tirta sari bungalows opposite suka sari bungalows and warung.
also nearby selini bakery does some nice cakes.

column5:
i would avoid all the southern beaches at that time of year and head for pemuteran. particularly if you are going to head up to ubud, its only around 4 hours drive from there (traffic dependant) and the drive itself has some great scenery and places to stop. unlike sanur, where the swimming is very tide dependant, its great for swimming at all times of the day, and there is also great basic snorkelling right off the beach. i don't drink (so no expert on the bar scene) but there seem to be lots of lovely beachside places to drink and eat. its definitely laid back and in four visits i've never had to deal with any sarong /massage/hair braiding/nail painting/sunglass selling vendors. no-one goes there to shop, its a more local feel. the hills are lovely and green at that time of the year, and i've never struck a rainy day there in january. it also doesn't get all the rubbish that you find in the south. worth considering as an option.
edited: 10:32 pm, january 02, 2021

the main diving area amed tulamben. lots “fall water” diving snorkeling.
this area over-commercialised tourismwise. big “western” style highstreet shop/restaurants /hotel/resort enclave.
very quiet. large hotels rare. villas.
we amed every year (diving/snorkeling/chillaxing). (myself mrs pig adult daughter) usually stay www.kembalibeachbungalows.nl planned 2019 (cancelled twice) larger family holiday (us plus son wife daughter&bf) planned book  next door.
column5:
hi,
it is very important that your prioritise what is important. being in “town” close to “westernised” tourist shops/restaurants etc or is the property the most important and location isn’t.
beachside villas
you will find it hard pushed to find any beachside villas in the “western” resort towns/urbanised holiday towns “down south”.
you can find beachside villas around bali but expect location to be isolated.
if you want a “western” style resort town you will have to compromise on villa location.
ubud
there are lots of villas around ubud. you will be spoilt for choice however be aware that ubud isn’t ubud isn’t ubud. do not believe any accommodation description of location or time/distance to town.
there is ubud town, ubud district (up o 8km from town) and “nowhere near ubud but we’ll call ourselves ubud anyway even though it is 20km and 1hr drive to town”.
diving/snorkeling - amed/tulamben
if anybody wishes to dive (or snorkel) there is no diving/snorkeling “down south” unless you go on a very very very expensive day trip.
closest places to “down south” are at padangbai or going to nusa lembongan/penida.
the main diving area is up around amed and tulamben. lots of “fall in the water” diving and snorkeling.
this area is not over-commercialised tourismwise. no big “western” style highstreet with shop/restaurants /hotel/resort enclave.
very quiet. large hotels rare. some villas.
we are in amed every year (diving/snorkeling/chillaxing). although we (myself and mrs pig or me and adult daughter) usually stay at www.kembalibeachbungalows.nl we have had planned since 2019 (cancelled twice) a larger family holiday (us plus son and wife and daughter&bf) so had planned to book  next door.
column8: Best area to stay in Bali for non-surfers?

column4:
could visit gili middle weeks bali, wise leave last part trip case weather/sailing conditions prevent boats leaving time. factor time takes travel insurance .
i allocating remainder time ubud seminyak suit well, consider staying villa. personally, limits opportunity meet others enjoy restaurants/cafes resort offers.

edited: 8:05 pm, january 05,
column5:
you could visit gili t in the middle of your 2 weeks in bali, as it's wise to not leave it to the last part of the trip in case weather/sailing conditions prevent boats leaving on time. do also factor in the time it takes to get there and back and also travel insurance .
i think allocating the remainder of time in ubud and seminyak should suit you well, but i would also consider not staying in a villa. personally, i think it limits the opportunity to meet others and also enjoy the restaurants/cafes that a resort offers.

edited: 8:05 pm, january 05, 2021

column4: novotel airport nice place beautiful garden pool swim bar. walk going lower level airport taking tunnel— 10 minutes walk.
column5: the novotel at the airport is a very nice place with a beautiful garden pool and swim up bar. and you can walk there just by going to the lower level of the airport and taking the tunnel— 10 minutes walk.

column4: going pattaya many years obviously love (i’m 51 years old). trip thailand thought pattaya noisy busy picked hua hin big mistake quiet boring (although dad loves 80). 2nd time picked pattaya stayed avanti (ex marriott) amazing trip. i’m beach person sit swimming pool swimming sea important pattaya/jomtien miss. look beach sea swim pattaya you. love walking lots places walk good sightseeing pattaya. love live music many bars live music. love eating pattaya lots restaurants cheap expensive, lots street food. pattaya markets, shopping malls, day trips etc. used stay large resort hotels marriott, avani, dusit thani tend pick cheaper hotels base travel places. stayed jomtien week found rather soulless beach good swimming nightly entertainment rather dull limited. baht bus bonus pattaya 10 baht (20p) convenient getting cheaply. long planning for? budget? dusit fantastic hotel budget allows hotels direct beach access located beach road easy access shops, bars etc. days stay soi bukhaoe that’s play pool hotels, bars restaurants cheaper area (probably ideal timer). jan feb favourite months made good choice (providing thailand open tourists - ruled jan trip i’m sure running soon) . feel free message queries questions. lisa
column5: i have been going to pattaya for many years and obviously i love it (i’m 51 years old). my first trip to thailand i thought pattaya would be too noisy and busy so i picked hua hin which was a big mistake as it was too quiet and boring for me (although my dad loves it but he is 80). the 2nd time i picked pattaya and stayed at the avanti (ex marriott) and had an amazing trip. i have to say that i’m not really a beach person as i like to sit by a swimming pool so if swimming in the sea is important then give pattaya/jomtien a miss. if like me you like to look at the beach and sea but not swim then pattaya may be for you. i love walking and there are lots of places to walk to and some good sightseeing in pattaya. i love live music and many of the bars have live music. i love eating out and pattaya has lots of great restaurants from cheap to expensive, also lots of street food. pattaya also has great markets, shopping malls, day trips etc. i always used to stay in large resort hotels like marriott, avani, dusit thani but now i tend to pick cheaper hotels and use them as a base as i like to travel to other places. i have stayed in jomtien for a week and found it rather soulless and again the beach was not good for swimming and nightly entertainment was rather dull and very limited. the baht bus is another bonus for pattaya as it is 10 baht (20p) so convenient for getting about cheaply. how long are you planning to go for? what is your budget? the dusit is a fantastic hotel if your budget allows and is one of the few hotels with direct beach access and is located on beach road so easy access to shops, bars etc. these days i always stay in soi bukhaoe but that’s because i like to play pool and hotels, bars and restaurants are cheaper in this area (probably not ideal for a first timer). jan and feb are my favourite months so you made a good choice there (providing thailand is open for tourists by then - i have ruled out my jan trip as i’m not sure things will be up and running that soon) . please feel free to message me with any queries or questions. lisa

column5:
hello everyone.
sorry this is so long.
i am planning a trip to thailand for the month of november 2022, (surely we will be good to go by then right?). i am so excited just thinking about travelling i want to ask your opinion on my plan.
i am 67 and my husband 72. i have been in various countries in south east asia, and in thailand 3 times. my husband has never been.
so this is the plan so far (open to critique, comments and suggestions)
i will have been in bali for the month of october with a friend and then flying to bangkok to meet up with hubby. overnight at the airport hotel
fly to siem reap for four nights. i have been , husband and friend have not. see the temples, ton le sap lake at sunset and a dance show. anyone recommend a good show?
looking for a mid range hotel with a pool walking distance to the market etc if you have a favourite.
from there fly to chaing mai for six nights . again i have been, others have not. we want to go to an elephant sanctuary (any recommendations?) a cooking class and sightsee lots of temples.
perhaps a trip up to chaing rai, (is it worth it? haven’t been) perhaps add another day to overnight there?
the yee peng lantern festival will be happening so thinking of going to the university for the first night to see it, and looking for recommendations for a roof top restaurant /bar for the second night.
any hints on chaing mai would be appreciated. i will want to stay in the old city.
i will also get another thai silk jacket made if i can. i had one made there 15 years ago and it was amazing. i lost too much weight to wear it any more. which is good and bad. anyone recommend a good reasonable tailor who has actual thai silk . i had one made in vietnam a couple years ago but it was a silk polyester blend i think and not the same.
my friend will go home at this point and husband and i will maybe head to khao sok for four nights, thinking of jungle house.
is that too much time, not enough? i read of another place where the cabins are on the water and you can kayak right off them but cant find that. any one know what it is called?
would i want to stay a couple of nights at each place?
will it be really hot, muggy and buggy there in november? my husband does not do well with extreme mugginess and heat.
then the beach!! phi phi for 8 nights to relax, read, swim and snorkel. i stayed at phi phi relax last time, this time though i think i will stay in one of their beachfront cabins so as to avoid all of those stairs.
or open to any other recommendations of similar places. we like to walk out the door and swim in the ocean.
then railay beach for 5 nights . i cant believe how much the prices have gone up since i was there 4 years ago! thinking of railay village resort but open to suggestions. last time we stayed at sand sea but the price has gone up so much.
i am not planning to spend any time in bangkok on purpose.i have been twice before and don’t need to go back other than overnights for flights.
i can add a few more days if you think there is something else that is a must do, close to where we will be so not adding too much travel time
i loved koh samui but from what i have read november is not the best time to travel there.
i look forward to any suggestions from you. this is my favourite part , the planning of it all. i am so excited.
thank you in advance for your expertise and experiences.

column4:
recommend wareham walks swanage beach road could steam train corfe. favourite circular walks scot arms kingston, walking trees begin opens sunshine, coast round along different path, pub lunch best garden views.
there plenty good restaurants wareham could look boat trips swanage or, hire canoe venture river.
if opt weymouth, look stay near harbour way, book soon many places fully booked throughout september! enjoy
column5:
i would recommend wareham for walks and swanage beach is just down the road or you could take the steam train from corfe. one of my favourite circular walks is from the scot arms in kingston, walking under trees to begin with and then it opens up into the sunshine, down to the coast and back round along a different path, maybe for a pub lunch with the best garden views.
there are plenty of good restaurants in wareham and you could look at boat trips from swanage or, hire a canoe and venture up the river.
if you do opt for weymouth, look to stay near the harbour and either way, book as soon as you can because many places are already fully booked throughout september! hope you enjoy

column4:
born bred londoner, nice hear people keen city call home, matter world end living!
i longer live london, lucky live lovely town 20 miles south...although honest, times town "lovely" liking find craving trips town. i'm lucky reasonable train links london, opening i've made point setting saturdays aside jump train explore familiar familiar sights. noughties spent little year working canary wharf, fan, soulless concrete jungle (possibly helped enjoying job there!). last saturday decided see anything changed, pleasantly surprised! saturday, place buzzing. people enjoying bars, restaurants malls, generally strolling start week-long heatwave. particularly enjoyed watching hot tub bbq boats, fairly new attraction group friends hire boat cook food onboard grill, float docks private hot tub (note way affiliated company provides service, enjoyed seeing them!).
sometimes takes told allowed something appreciate finally allowed again...hang there!
column5:
as a born and bred londoner, it's nice to hear that people are keen to get back to the city i will always call home, no matter where in the world i might end up living!
i no longer live in london, but am lucky to live in a lovely town only 20 miles to the south...although being honest, at times my town is a bit too "lovely" for my liking and i find myself craving trips up to town. i'm lucky that we have reasonable train links into london, so since things have been opening up again i've made a point of setting saturdays aside so that i can jump on a train and go and explore familiar and some not so familiar sights. back in the noughties i spent a little over a year working in canary wharf, and i have to say that i wasn't a fan, to me is was a soulless concrete jungle (possibly not helped by not enjoying the job i was doing there!). but last saturday i decided to go and see if anything had changed, and was pleasantly surprised! for a saturday, the place was buzzing. people were out enjoying the bars, restaurants and malls, and generally strolling around in what was the start of a week-long heatwave. i particularly enjoyed watching the hot tub and bbq boats, a fairly new attraction where you and a group of friends hire a boat and either cook your own food on an onboard grill, or float around the docks in your own private hot tub (note that i am in no way affiliated with the company that provides this service, i just enjoyed seeing them!).
sometimes it takes being told your not allowed to do something to make you appreciate it all the more when you're finally allowed to again...hang in there!

column4:
hi, personally i’d ubud first, gili t, kuta. kuta closer airport departure flight.
why interest seminyak? i’m personally fan kuta prefer seminyak. metered taxis plentiful economical visit seminyak kuta want wander around. favourite sanur. sanur half hour boat trip across island nusa lembongan/nusa penida you’re interested water activities (not necessarily diving snorkelling) stay days.
think nights gili long. me, ubud deserves longer stay nights (2 full days) plenty see ubud town good base sightseeing cultural sites/experiences afield. could walk campuhan ridge ubud. you’ve stated “replanning” you’ve done research chosen areas. perhaps read pinned posts top forum “the different areas bali.....”.
the weather less wet according crystal ball tell hot humid. june lovely time visit. july/august/september popular time room rates higher busy.
eating bali excellent. many, many cafes/restaurants/local warungs cuisines prices suit budgets.
these comments pre covid.
column5:
hi, personally i’d go to ubud first, then gili t, then kuta. kuta being closer to the airport for your departure flight.
why your interest in seminyak? i’m personally not a fan of kuta and prefer seminyak. metered taxis are plentiful and economical for you to visit seminyak from kuta if you want to have a wander around. and my other favourite is sanur. from sanur you can go for a half hour boat trip across to the island of nusa lembongan/nusa penida if you’re interested in water activities (not necessarily diving but maybe snorkelling) and stay for a few days.
think 6 nights on gili t too long. for me, ubud deserves a longer stay than 3 nights (2 full days) as there is plenty to see and do in ubud town and a good base for sightseeing cultural sites/experiences further afield. you could walk the campuhan ridge in ubud. as you’ve stated your “replanning” it would suggest you’ve already done the research of your chosen areas. perhaps have another read of the pinned posts at the top of the forum “the different areas of bali.....”.
the weather will be less wet according to my crystal ball but i can tell you it will be very hot and humid. june is a lovely time to visit. july/august/september is the most popular time but room rates are higher and very busy.
eating out in bali is excellent. many, many cafes/restaurants/local warungs with all cuisines and prices to suit all budgets.
these comments are pre covid.
column8: Bali & Gilli T - Itinerary Help please

column4: visited bali times son- aged 11-13 time. loved gili t. stayed nights time nights second. cycled island, hired boat snorkelled, son surfing lessons. good restaurants chilled vibe bars too. took speed boat across lombok. bank nights again. i’d avoid kuta, it’s blackpool abroad. legion much nicer. tonne ubud, days plenty. white water rafting, electric bike tour, quad bikes, monkey forest, coffee tasting.
column5: we have visited bali 4 times with our son- aged 11-13 at the time. we all loved gili t. we stayed 4 nights first time and 6 nights the second. we cycled around the island, hired a boat and snorkelled, our son had surfing lessons. some good restaurants and a very chilled vibe but bars if you like that too. we also took a speed boat across to lombok. we would go bank for 6 nights again. i’d avoid kuta, it’s like blackpool abroad. legion is much nicer. we did a tonne of things in ubud, but 4 days is plenty. we did white water rafting, electric bike tour, quad bikes, monkey forest, coffee tasting.
column8: Bali & Gilli T - Itinerary Help please

column5:
"i had covid in january and am doubly vaccinated so my body is stuffed with antibodies. the nonsense coming out of the fcdo and sage is for the birds and the gullible."
from the uk gp publication pulse dated 3 dec 2018
"there were over 50,000 excess winter deaths in england and wales last winter, the highest recorded since 1975/76, according to data released by the office of national statistics (ons).
the increase is thought to be a result of the prevalence of flu last year, alongside ineffectiveness of the flu vaccine and colder than usual temperatures in the 2017/18 winter period, according to the ons."
the current 7 day average (9 per day) of deaths from covid in the uk extrapolated for the year gives 3285 deaths. now i am not understating the importance of treating covid seriously but when it is all over can we expect lock downs each winter, pubs closing, travel banned, social distancing, working from home, due to 50,000 annual flu deaths. equivalent to 137 deaths a day.

column4:
sort "tours" "things do" interest you? active days sea kayaking cycling? nature oriented driving tours landscapes wildlife? food oriented? handicrafts? knowing helps people steer towards choice.
using two suggestions example, hua hin modern, tourist oriented town whereas prachuap khiri khan everyday working thai town. hh tourist oriented restaurants (ie westernized food) day trip choices. pkk local's oriented dining options less tour options far hh pop hh worthwhile daytrip.
people's ideas "authentic" "culture experience" widely varied, need wants best suggest.
column5:
what sort of "tours" and "things to do" interest you? active days sea kayaking or cycling? nature oriented driving tours for landscapes or wildlife? food oriented? handicrafts? knowing this helps people steer you towards a better choice.
using the above two suggestions as an example, hua hin is a very modern, tourist oriented town whereas prachuap khiri khan is more of an everyday working thai town. hh will have more tourist oriented restaurants (ie westernized food) and probably more day trip choices. pkk will have more local's oriented dining options and less tour options though not that far from hh that you couldn't pop up to hh for a worthwhile daytrip.
people's ideas of what is "authentic" or what is a "culture experience" are so widely varied, that we need to know more about your wants to best suggest.

probably unless member community decent length time.
here's problem - illegal let residential space (in part who) rent consideration (in cash kind) periods less three months singapore.
now permitted host family friends connections free legally within limits.
couchsurfing started popular 90s network backpacking friends knew friends friends used internet connect. backpacking variation 80s boom international vacation home-swaps were. sites become big connection community side whole couch surfing pretty much minority people cheap/free crashing option.

the government ramped cutting illegal letting associated nuisance, covers sites vrbo, airbnb on's bread butter type lets. couchsurfing potential legal surf host swept nuisance sweep help staying many little difference tourist surfing operating tourist timings non-residential nature - thats points raised public consultation short term renting residential areas.

column5:
>>israel and iceland (no quarantine when entering but u have to be at least vaccinated once to enter<<
with iceland and i would therefore suspect israel, the reference to single vaccination shots relates to the vaccine make that only needs one shot. it requires full vaccination to be in place...and given the inserts all say x time post vaccination for efficacy you may well run into places enforcing that wait as part of the 'fully vaccinated' description. so unless you can do that you need to look at those that will accept negative testing.
>>well back to the topic in hand....i did do research on couch surfing in singapore, is that worth it?<<
probably not unless you have been a member of that community for a decent length of time.
here's the problem - its illegal to let residential space (in part or in who) out to rent for any consideration (in cash or in kind) for periods of less three months in singapore.
now you are permitted to host family and friends you have connections to for free legally within limits.
couchsurfing as it started being popular in the 90s was a network of backpacking friends who knew each other or were friends of friends and used the internet to connect. a backpacking variation of the 80s boom in international vacation home-swaps as it were. now such sites have become so big that connection and community side of the whole couch surfing thing is pretty much the minority and people use it as a cheap/free crashing option.
if you were staying with someone you have some connection with for free then its legal - as soon as their is no connection or there is any consideration (even be it host rating/site rating on a couch surf network that the person can use to improve their ability to couch surf then you are effectively on a cheap rental.
even if you fall into the community couchsurfer definition (ie where it could be legal) there are still potential issues especially in hdb buildings. if someone has couchsurfers over enough that they cause a perceived nuisance to the other residents then it can be shut down just on that basis(leaving you with no place to stay, potentially at the point you turn up).
the government has ramped up cutting down on illegal letting and associated nuisance, which covers such sites a vrbo, airbnb and so on's bread and butter type of lets. couchsurfing has more potential to be legal but if a surf host is swept up in a nuisance sweep its not help to those staying and for many there is little difference as a tourist surfing is still operating on tourist timings so being non-residential in nature - thats one of the points raised in the public consultation on short term renting in residential areas.
so you have to be very very careful on exactly what you are doing with couch surfing to stay legal and also not be a nuisance.
also on a practical side, most couch surfing is done in suburban areas a long way from tourist sites. you would in many cases do better to look at a good cheap hostel or pod type hotel where costs are much lower than big city centre hotels but you have a) a guaranteed legal stay, b) access to the community from which couch surfing sprang, c) more personal and legal safety and d) potentially better access to singapore's sights.

column4:
planning visit singapore return nz uk early january 2022. advise it’s possible combine city sentosa island best area stay?
also, weather good nights right? thankyou!
column5:
we are planning to visit singapore on our return from nz to the uk early january 2022. can anyone advise if it’s possible to combine the city with sentosa island and if so where is the best area to stay?
also, will the weather be good then and is 4 nights about right? thankyou!

column4:
stay mainland wider variety hotels, shops, eateries etc, sentosa roughly 15 min taxi ride city. best place stay city hall bencoolen area choice everything hand others prefer marina bay scenery, suppose depends requirements budget.
the time spend depends itinerary, normally less days recommended many stay longer , stay less weeks.
weather wise expect hot humid 30c year round many rainy days odd thunderstorm. saying normally rain day long obviously whole island time. remember year went treetop walk macritchie got caught thunderstorm shelter returned hotel city hall attracted quite attention bone dry walking hotel lobby looking drowned rats.
column5:
i would suggest stay on the mainland as you have a wider variety of hotels, shops, eateries etc, sentosa is roughly a 15 min taxi ride from the city. as for the best place to stay then city hall and bencoolen area would be my choice as you have everything to hand but others prefer marina bay for the scenery, i suppose it all depends on your requirements and budget.
the time you spend depends on your itinerary, normally no less than 7 days is recommended but many of us stay for longer , i myself stay no less than 2 weeks.
weather wise expect it to be hot and humid around 30c as it is all year round with many rainy days and the odd thunderstorm. saying that it does not normally rain all day long and obviously not over the whole island at the same time. lol i remember one year we went on the treetop walk at macritchie and got caught in a thunderstorm and had to take shelter and when we returned to our hotel in city hall we attracted quite a bit of attention as it was bone dry there and we were walking through the hotel lobby looking like 2 drowned rats.

column4:
entirely possible combine city sentosa. sentosa district singapore right southern part city quicker northern parts. isnt somewhere hugely separated...15mins taxi marina area, mrt chinatown.
four nights whistlestop trip. taste singapore, see major items. isnt enough singapore destination stopover nz let try bits three full days have. enough planning you’ll plan enjoy place...just try major sites time releases pick want letting enjoy trying hard cram.
weather pretty much year round. tropical heat humidity cloudburst type rain. rains variable. january tail end wet season....which means rain hits average every day rather every three days driest months chance full day rain require activate backup.
however typical cloudbursts last hour cause much trouble typically..and assumes rain hits open. many time returned city see sodden glorious sun west. short visit, snapshotting weather dry wet months (which frankly relative average european visitor) consider singapore weather form time year, seasonal differences acutely noticeable resident, less visitor.
column5:
its entirely possible to combine the city with sentosa. really sentosa is just another district of singapore and from the right southern part of the city can be quicker to get to than some northern parts. it really isnt somewhere hugely separated...15mins in a taxi from the marina area, the same by mrt from chinatown.
four nights is a bit of a whistlestop trip. you will get a taste of singapore, so see a few major items. it isnt enough for singapore as a destination but as a stopover from nz will let you try bits out in the three full days you would have. do enough planning and you’ll get a plan to enjoy the place...just do not try or think that you can do all the major sites in that time and that releases you to just pick and do what you most want to do letting you enjoy it without trying to hard to cram.
weather is pretty much the same year round. tropical heat and humidity with cloudburst type rain. however when and where it rains is variable. january is the tail end of the wet season....which means rain hits on average every other day rather than every three days in the driest months and the chance of there being a full day of rain which might require you to activate a backup.
however the typical cloudbursts last an hour and go so do not cause too much trouble typically..and that assumes the rain hits where you are and when you are in the open. many the time i have returned to the city to see it sodden while having had glorious sun out west. the thing is that with a short visit, you are snapshotting the weather and in dry or wet months (which frankly are a relative thing to the average european visitor) and so have to consider any singapore weather form at any time of the year, the seasonal differences are acutely noticeable to a resident, less so to a visitor.

“posh hotels”, of which singapore has a bountiful supply, have never been my thing, but each to his/her own choice.
next time i visit singapore i’ll be on my own and plan to do a hostel recce and review, taking into account, price, value, cleanliness, service and welcome. it’s just hurry up and wait as things stand, but seriously doubt 2021 is going to be the year, but one lives in hope.
stay safe everyone.
p.s. minxbaby, i’d put up with 22 c all day long, just now it’s hovering around -1c with snow flurries.

column4:
>>we spending days singapore, days bangkok days koh samui. <<
ok - slightly misread - days uk travel agent speak usually means day arrive restrictions it, day full unrestricted days, day include travel (either home bangkok) restrictions.
this short planning sort 'what cut list options'
it worth deciding ahead time plan - ensuring enough knowledge hand easily pull filler (for much less time expected somewhere, simply enjoy it), swap bad weather affecting choice attraction. long days full rain common, short snapshot point unlucky sizeable block time affected.
your flight times routing singapore heavily affect days travel possible - want planning help vital - uk legs direct, bouncing way time arrive, local flight (bangkok koh samui) outbound when. sort double time singapore issues terms suitable see day early morning landing direct uk example.
column5:
>>we are spending 4 days in singapore, 3 days in bangkok and then 8 days in koh samui. <<
ok - i slightly misread that - 4 days in uk travel agent speak usually means day 1 arrive which will have restrictions on it, day 2 and 3 are full unrestricted days, and day 4 will include travel (either home or to bangkok) and so have restrictions.
this is really short and so most planning will be of the sort of 'what do we cut out from the list of options'
it is worth deciding ahead of time what you plan to do - ensuring you have enough knowledge to hand that you can easily pull out a filler (for if you take much less time than expected somewhere, or get there and simply not enjoy it), or to do a swap for bad weather affecting a choice of attraction. while long days full of rain are not common, with such a short snapshot at the point you get unlucky and get one its a sizeable block of time affected.
your flight times and routing in and out of singapore will heavily affect the days of travel and what is possible - so if you want planning help those are really vital to know - for the uk legs is it direct, or bouncing on the way and what time does it arrive, and for a more local flight (bangkok or koh samui) is that in or outbound and when. while you can sort of double your time in singapore there are issues in terms of what is suitable to see for say a first day with an early morning landing direct from the uk for example.

column4:
noticed booking site (expedia) favourite little budget hotels renovation rooms foyer.
hotel snow, cavan road, lavender (about minutes walk lavender mrt station) updated small rooms fresh, modern functional.
some find tiny rooms basic claustrophobic (some don’t windows) bathroom tiny wet room shower head toilet area suit people, stayed times found location excellent quiet narrow road lavender street.
prices looked higher remembered, reno/update it’s good small option night two definitely stay again...when eventually singapore.
column5:
just noticed on a booking site (expedia) that one of my favourite little budget hotels has had a renovation of their rooms and foyer.
hotel snow, cavan road, lavender (about 7 minutes walk from lavender mrt station) has updated their very small rooms to make them fresh, modern and functional.
some may find the tiny rooms basic and claustrophobic (some don’t have windows) and the bathroom is a tiny wet room with shower head over the toilet area so that may not suit some people, but i stayed 4 times and found the location excellent on a quiet narrow road off lavender street.
prices looked higher than i remembered, but with the reno/update it’s still a good small option for a night or two and i will definitely stay again...when i eventually get back to singapore.

column5: like one of the other posters indicated, that dubai can be windy and cold in january. they said they were there in jan 2019. i was there nov-feb 2020. and january it definitely was cold and windy. not freezing just windy and noticeably cooler. it wasn't just dubai, it was in qatar too. i was on several cruises in that area from december to the first week of february, and in when the middle of january hit, the wind and cool weather hit too. it was better when i left mid february. but, new years up until about 10 days later was excellent, no problem.

dether, i have to disagree with your last comment -
"rental prices have fallen and this has allowed locals to repossess their island and reopen businesses at reasonable prices"
i've been many times to koh tao (numerous times a year in fact) and have noticed the exact opposite - the majority of places still open were foreign owned, and lots of my cheap little thai places have closed down. thank f. the duck place in sairee is still open!
however there are now many options on fb food groups for very cheap food from people working out of their home kitchens, it seems.
lots of dive schools appear to have closed, with the larger ones still running - asia divers, sairee cottage, mojo, dpm and puravida all closed when i went past. the diving has been great though,the corals in excellent condition due to less people trampling on them too. the empty dive sites a great bonus for those lucky enough to be on the island!
hope the locals can survive this pandemic...

column5:
bangkok info is easy. using your laptop or other big screen computer pull up this link from the bangkok forum.

* any city you have an interest in will have information available at the top of the particular forum.
"myself and my wife are travelling with another couple.. 11.3.22 _to 26.3.22"
if you mean march, and you actually intend to go in the water, then choose a beach location with good weather for march. (google and forum search.)
"finish off with some high end resort break for 2 or 3 days..."
do you intend to actually swim at a beach or just watch the water and use the hotel pool? how far will you go from bangkok? there are beach areas you can drive to (or have someone drive you) not that far from bangkok.
if march next year you have a lot of time for research.
look up nakhon ratchasima forum. nearby is the town of phimai, just a short bus ride away.

if your departure flight is from bangkok my advice is to finish there with a night or two. this way you can buy your tourist junk and be a simple train or taxi ride to the airport.
good luck.

column4:
presumably southborough kent, uk ? uk find thailand getting quite hot towards end february, particularly round golf, flexibility early possible month rather later.
several courses near hua hin apart black mountain. group 50 something couples find hh much nicer place pattaya.
agree withmrc, chiang mai pleasant small city almost entirely low rise. end february daytime maxima could 35c smoke haze could problem. air quality hh time year....though weather pollution wise nothing set stone thailand.
column5:
presumably southborough kent, uk ? if from the uk you will find thailand getting quite hot towards the end of february, particularly for a round of golf, and if you have flexibility i would go as early as possible that month rather than later.
several courses near to hua hin apart from black mountain. for me a group of 8 50 something couples would find hh a much nicer place than pattaya.
agree withmrc, chiang mai is a pleasant small city and almost entirely low rise. but by the end of february daytime maxima could be up around 35c and smoke haze could be a problem. the air quality at hh would probably be better at that time of year....though weather and pollution wise nothing is set in stone in thailand.

column4:
loki it’s cold chilly bangkok december?
once twice year bangkok temperatures drop 15 or16c dawn december january there’s spell cool weather normally evening temperatures pleasantly mid 20s right folk tucked bed. cm yes, degrees cooler. occasional spells cooler weather bangkok rarely last longer days.
column5:
loki you really think that it’s cold to chilly in bangkok in december?
once or twice a year bangkok temperatures sometimes might drop to 15 or16c by dawn in december or january if there’s a spell of cool weather but normally evening temperatures are pleasantly mid 20s right through until when most folk are tucked up in bed. cm yes, a few degrees cooler. the occasional spells of cooler weather in bangkok rarely last for longer than 2 or 3 days.

column5:
knowing your interests would help...maybe. history (thai / khmer) then you're in the right place for that, the ne. two of the better restored sites, phimai & phanom rung. korat city itself is nothing special, especially since you'll be spending a bit of time in ubon. thai culture is everywhere, and no need to travel for it, simply open your mind where you are.
close by, sort of and along the mekong can be nice, that phanom & nakhon phanom, though more a self drive kind of thing. ne can be a bit boring on the korat plateau, but the edges of have some lovely landscape.
monsoon / raining season, so most of the country is going to be wet at times, sunny at times, actually my favorite time of year, since very lush & green, except when wanting to play in the surf, as that can be very rough / dangerous. also may affect any ferry traffic to islands, for comfort, all the to being cancelled.
if you've only been to cm & phuket during smog season, then you'll really enjoy the views in rainy season, when sunny out. so may want to think about a revisit there. instead of almost seeing that 1 ridge through the smog, you'll see the 5 or 10 behind it. goes for all of the upper north side, and along myanmar border mountain range.
check weather and sea conditions, before heading to anywhere in the gulf, maybe a better bet for actually swimming in the seas. you state flying, but train runs down the gulf coast, if not wanting to self drive, and can be very convenient for visiting all that is along there. get near chumphon & surat thani, and you can think about hopping over to ko tao or samui.
i would definitely hit the khao sok np area, and cheow lan lake, more just the lake, as spectacular landscape, and hopefully sunny day for boat tour & hotel stay on the lake for swimming. no worries about rough seas there. can't think of a better place to get your nature freak on.
side trips out of krung thep (bangkok) to all the normal touristy stuff, since none here, and they're great now, as been out & about ourselves, on & off since june 2020.
kanchanburi
pattaya / ko larn
khao yai
hua hin
all places we'd avoid during normal times, as way too crowded, and lovely now. use kt as base, for 1 or 2 night stays. or add hua hin in with the train ride down the gulf coast, or better, self drive. buses and limo vans plow the routes also, but train is safer and kind of convenient. damn cheap if trying to stretch your budget. towns are only 1 to 3 hours away, if hop scotching down.
options abound.
