column4:
asq offer "pool access" simply let lounge pool, swim it. shared swimming pool defeat purpose isolation quarantine.
there alq phuket offer villas private pools, order stay alq phuket, need arrive internationally phuket many direct semi-commercial flights. places geared towards private plane arrivals groups charter flights.
if kids used hanging indoors day home, quarantine, long playthings along. used playing outdoors, asq rough them, comprehend can't play outside.
column5:
the asq that offer "pool access" simply let you lounge by the pool, not swim in it. a shared swimming pool would defeat the purpose of isolation during quarantine.
there are some alq in phuket that offer villas with private pools, but in order to stay at an alq in phuket, you need to arrive internationally in phuket and there aren't many direct semi-commercial flights. those places are more geared towards private plane arrivals and groups on charter flights.
if your kids are used to hanging out indoors all day at home, then they will probably do ok with quarantine, as long as you have their playthings along. but if they are used to playing outdoors, then asq will be rough on them, as they won't really comprehend why they can't play outside.
column8: Quarantine with beach and pool use

column4:
popular spot surfing nai harn beach athough crowded.
kata beach surfing spread out.
there surfing schools kata beach.
getting around? expats drive cars motorbikes.
public transportation: well, tend drive slow mostly phuket town back, town town otherwise. could figure something out.
chalong pier mostly used diving trips start pier there.
and yachties park boats chalong bay.
lots restaurants around. kim eng good thai food.
more international foods towards raway/naiharn area.
welcome good luck!
column5:
a popular spot for surfing is nai harn beach athough it can get crowded.
kata beach also has surfing and more spread out.
there are a few surfing schools at kata beach.
getting around? most expats here drive cars or motorbikes.
public transportation: well, there is some but they tend to drive very slow and mostly go to phuket town and back, not really from town to town otherwise. although you could probably figure something out.
chalong pier is mostly used for diving trips which start out from the pier there.
and yachties park their boats there in chalong bay.
lots of restaurants around. kim eng is good for thai food.
more international foods towards raway/naiharn area.
welcome and good luck!

column4:
emily, phuket place live. i'll moving pretty soon well. chalong area south phuket town (quite charming), beaches facing east. beaches general west side island, i'm sure exactly what's preferred surfing. far ride mountains kata karon beaches (or patong/kamala beaches north chalong).
they buses, big encaged trucks routes island. i've taken them, imagine fairly regular schedule. otherwise grab good way book quick ride, motorcycle taxi going far want avoid traffic.
sorry can't help regarding what's open business moment, i've away while. check phuket community discussion page  - users living i'm sure could help assist well. best luck journey time there!
column5:
hope you like it emily, phuket is a great place to live. i'll be moving back pretty soon as well. chalong is the area just south of phuket town (quite charming), with beaches facing east. the better beaches in general are on the west side of the island, though i'm not sure exactly what's preferred for surfing. it's not too far a ride to get over the mountains to kata or karon beaches (or patong/kamala beaches if you're further north in chalong).
they have buses, or sometimes big encaged trucks that have a few routes around the island. i've not taken them, but i imagine they go on a fairly regular schedule. otherwise grab is a good way to book a quick ride, even a motorcycle taxi if you're not going far or want to avoid traffic.
sorry can't be of more help regarding what's open for business at the moment, i've been away for a while. but you can also check on the phuket community discussion page here  - there are users living there who i'm sure could help assist as well. best of luck in your journey and time there!

column4:
prior major international disruption due covid, bangkok opinion food capital world. cuisine desired available, fabulous street food high end dining. didn’t walk far find huge variety food types styles suit every taste.
eating bangkok adventure.
column5:
prior to the major international disruption due to covid, bangkok in my opinion was the food capital of the world. any cuisine that you desired was available, from fabulous street food to very high end dining. you didn’t have to walk very far to find a huge variety of food types and styles to suit every taste.
eating in bangkok can be a great adventure.

column4:
@jeevan patnaiak
my reply normal conditions,not considering covid19 lockdown/restrictions ,you check trip covid regulations.
1st looks priority sight seeing budget, believe going worst time year per priority.
1> yes too,you check railway retiring room booking available,there basic lodge/hotel infront njp also,not good option save hassle traveling siliguri night.
2>bus much time share cab budget priority go.
3>very less chance north sikkim nathula accessible,hope best.
4>no bus,you share cab ghezing or/and jorangthan,
5>ok
6>don't find reason stay near batasia loop infact splitting stay, staying single place better.
7>certainly walking distance,it's 15 km plus rains last phase bad roads difficult walk raining,take share cab,also july visiting morning sunrise wasting time money,you find clouds.even days mostly cloudy.
8> easily,get share cab morning reach njp well time.but case visit tiger hill sunrise total wastage money time suggested earlier.
//and apply required permits 1st day//
you apply, travel agent apply.//
//along nathula pass permit (gangtok - zuluk - nathula pass - changu - gangtok). hoping could shared cab round trip.//
dzuluk single day trip,you gangtok tsongo nathula back,share trip available 700-800 rs,but monsoon arrives full fledged nathula possible,even tsongo doubtful.
//then start lachung 4th day (sunday) public/shared transport, homestay lachung days. (pre-booking done guess read homestays booked via tourism packages)//
again weather dependent,less chance exactly predict.share package available 3.5-4 k includes fooding, lodging, transport permit days night to/from gangtok.
//so, manage 14k sikkim days? pre-booking not? worry hike price pre-booking//
if prebooking certainly going pay ,in july tourist sikkim, hotels vacant,taxi drivers travel agent searching tourist,can certainly deals spot.
column5:
@jeevan patnaiak
my reply is for normal conditions,not considering covid19 lockdown/restrictions ,you have to check before your trip for covid regulations.
1st of all it looks your priority is sight seeing and that too in budget, believe me you are going worst time of the year as per your priority.
1> yes you have too,you may check railway retiring room too if booking available,there are some basic lodge/hotel infront of njp also,not a good option but may save some hassle traveling siliguri in night.
2>bus will take much more time than share cab but if budget is priority then go.
3>very less chance that north sikkim and nathula would be accessible,hope for the best.
4>no bus,you may get share cab from ghezing or/and jorangthan,
5>ok
6>don't find any reason to stay near batasia loop infact splitting stay, staying at a single place is better.
7>certainly not a walking distance,it's more than 15 km plus rains and last phase are bad roads which will be difficult to walk when raining,take a share cab,also in july visiting in morning for sunrise is wasting of time and money,you would find only clouds.even during days mostly cloudy.
8> easily,get a share cab in morning around 9 and will reach njp well before time.but in that case you have to visit tiger hill for sunrise which would be total wastage of money and time as suggested earlier.
//and apply for the required permits on the 1st day//
you don't have to apply, travel agent will apply.//
//along with nathula pass once i get the permit (gangtok - zuluk - nathula pass - changu - gangtok). i am hoping i could get a shared cab for this round trip.//
dzuluk not a single day trip,you can do gangtok tsongo nathula and back,share trip available around 700-800 rs,but if monsoon arrives with full fledged nathula would not be possible,even sometimes tsongo is doubtful.
//then start to lachung on 4th day (sunday) by public/shared transport, and homestay in lachung for 3 days. (pre-booking to be done i guess as i read all homestays can be booked via tourism packages)//
again weather dependent,less chance but not one can exactly predict.share package available around 3.5-4 k which includes fooding, lodging, transport and permit for 2 days 3 night to/from gangtok.
//so, can i manage with 14k in sikkim for 8 days? should i do pre-booking or should i not? my worry is that they may hike price if i don't do pre-booking//
if you do prebooking you are certainly going to pay more ,in july very few tourist in sikkim, all hotels vacant,taxi drivers and travel agent searching for tourist,can certainly get better deals on the spot.

column5:
i am planning a detailed trip to jammu and kashmir in may 2021 (finger crossed).
i have time in hand so please suggest if i am missing anything.
if i go alone - i will be riding a motorcycle but if i am coming with my wife - then a car.
please let me know :
1. if i am missing interesting place or anything
2. where can i stay
3. any suggestion of change in my itinerary.
my main aim of the jammu and kashmir trip is to trek to vaisno devi and amarnath cave but i will visit other tourist spots.
this is how i am planning my trip :
day 1 : reach jammu and proceed to katra.
note : get yatra parchi online ahead of time.
night stay at katra
day 2: take shared auto to ban ganga check post. after security atrt the 13 km trek.
distance - charan paduka (3 km), adh kuwari (6 km), and sanji chatt (9.5 km)
after darshan trek to kal bhairav temple (2.5 km) steep climb
night halt at the top - bhawan.
day 3 - trek down to katra. from katra - drive/ride to patnitop (around 140 km 3 to 4 hrs)
its beautiful village / hamlet to explore in the evening.
night halt at patnitop.
note : if time permits - can spend a day at each of this beautiful place - bhaderwah, kishtwar
day 4 - drive / ride to anantnag. around 85 kms. will take 4-5 hours.
visit markand sun temple
gurudwara mattan
night stay at anantnag
day 5 : drive to pahalgam 26 km around 1 hour
pahalgam - "valley of shepards"
visit aru valley and betaab valley
banks of river lidder. has some great trekking routes.
night stay at aru road, pahalgam
note : get your yatri permit and doctor certificate ahead of time for sree amarnath yatra
day 6 : pahalgam to chandanwadi by shared taxi (16 km)
start trek to amarnath cave. (distance from chandanwadi to amarnath gufa is around 36 km)
chandanwadi to pissu top - 5 km
pissu top to sheshnag - 9 kms
night halt at sheshnag (total trek of 14 kms)
day 7 : trek to sree amarnath cave 22 kms.
darshan and night halt at sree amarnath cave.
day 8 : trek to sheshnag 22 kms
day 9 : trek to chandanwadi (14 kms)
shared taxi to pahalgam.
night halt at aru road, pahalgam.
day 10 : drive / ride to srinagar 60 kms 2-3 hours
check in a houseboat and go around dal lake.
char chinar and kabootar ghar in dal lake
take a shikara ride for 1 hour.
day 11 : local sight seeing
mughal gardens - nishat,
zabarwan hills,
shalimar bagh,
wular lake,
chashme shahi,
hari parbat,
hazratbal,
pari mahal,
sankaracharya temple,
chatti padshahi gurudwara, located in hari parbat
check in to hotel at rajbagh, srinagar
day 12 : trip to sonamarg.
sonamarg - around 86 kms, also called 'meadow of gold'.
sonamarg is located at 9000 ft. against snow-clad mountains - be prepared with warm jacket.
sindh river flows nearby. hire ponies that can take upto the thajiwas glacier.
back to srinagar hotel.
day 13 : drive / ride to gulmarg - "meadow of flowers" around 30 kms. 1- 2 hours.
visit the world's highest 18-hole golf course
enjoy a cable car ride or a gondola ride to glaciers of khilanmerg and afarwat
strawberry valley, nageen valley and maharaja palace
pir panjal peaks,
stay at gulmarg (somewhere at circular road)
day 14 : drive / ride to kargil (around 157 kms) 4-5 hours
column8: Planning a detailed trip to Kashmir in May 2021

column5:
before go to kashmir keep few points in mind
know about weather
kashmir is heaven for nature lovers. kashmir offers amazing panoramic views and numerous sightseeing places such as lakes, mughal gardens, mountains, hills, and much more. you can experience kashmir in all seasons but the summer season is a mirror for you to see this beautiful place. the weather of kashmir during summer is very pleasant and you will find people of all ages enjoying there but the high temperature may be problematic so you need to be prepared about your trip only then you will have a great experience of your vacations in kashmir.
choose packages wisely
your kashmir tour is the best time you will have in your life in case if it happens to be your first. after all, this is your first kashmir tour; it has to be memorable. therefore, book the important things for your kashmir tour in advance and avoid any last-minute predicament. thousands of tourists visit kashmir every year to explore the natural beauty of the state. they have to choose from the various tour packages, offered by travel agencies in kashmir while planning their trip.
carry necessary documents
you need to carry all your necessary documents while traveling to a foreign country. the documentation of kashmir tour packages requires certain important things which are actually mandatory, and if you forget them, you will be at loss. you are supposed to carry all your necessary documents as per the requirements of the government of india such as passport, passport size photograph, identity proof.
compare tour packages
the golden valley of kashmir has been the homeland for people from different cultures for centuries. the beautiful place attracts thousands of foreign tourists every year across the globe. if you are among those who plan to visit kashmir then, it is important that you must compare tour packages on the internet. these packages have been developed and designed in a way that makes all of the tourist requirements known. people who are planning a holiday in kashmir can now choose from some great options when it comes to traveling.

we are planning to visit srinagar in last week of august, hoping that rain will subside by now and weather will be good. our itinerary is:

column5:
timings : early august menas highest chances of rain , from mid-september chances of early snow at 4000+ meters. two examples : end-september trek i made aiming for sarchu on the manali-leh road

, abandoned after two days up from chandra tal when it started to snow heavily.
and ....euhm , extending my nubra permit walking out over the 5400-ish digar la in mid-october. steep , difficult descent forcing me to a high , cold camp : i guesstimated it to around -15.

double wall tent , two sleeping bags , boots inside the the bag under the knees .. even this early one needs a separate set of skills and gear to manage night camps seriously higher than leh.

column4:
andaman definitely destination. beaches offers lot different things.
lovely, relatively unspoiled, less crowded beaches - north / middle andaman find less people!
some best scuba diving sites india
the gateway middle north andaman - baratang - reaching experience - drive dense tropical forest - tribal reserve (you allowed step vehicle) - chance see jarawa tribal people (hunter,gatherer tribes dont want ‘civilized’ lead blissful life oldest tribes historically)
30 minute boat ride breathtaking mangroves - something see nat geo! trek forest see limestone caves
boat ride creeks watch 100s parrots reach parrot island - night time home
ross & smith islands connected sandbar disappears high tide
turtle nesting sites (during nesting season)
the famous radhanagar beach havelock
watersports havelock, neil, northbay
coral watching jollybuoy / redskin
history: cellular jail british imprisoned tortured indian freedom fighters, japanese bunkers, remnants british rule ross island (this different ross & smith), sound light shows both
i on, highlights. beware - facilities developing top notch - reason relatively unspoiled!
hopefully time travel, london - chennai direct flights resumed connecting flight there. (port blair international airport open soon direct flights!)
depending interests plan. idea
1 full day visiting cellular jail,samudrika marine museum, anthropological museum, chatham saw mill (if interests you) sunset watch trip chidiya tapu
1 full day northbay (sea walking) ross island
1 full day jolly buoy - coral viewing see combine mount harriet trek afternoon
3-4 full nights havelock enjoying beaches, scuba, sea walking, snorkelling etc
2-3 nights neil island
1 day baratang
3-4 nights north andaman - ross & smith, full day saddle peak trek, aam kunj beach etc
there option - much travel - spend week havelock resort radhanagar vijaynagar beaches nights neil islands night arrival night departure port blair town!
ps: reach havelock neil - ferries. baratang, north andaman - travel road. self drive cars available andaman, hire cab driver
column5:
andaman is definitely a great destination. it is not just about beaches and offers a lot of different things.
lovely, relatively unspoiled, less crowded beaches - if you go to north / middle andaman you may find even less people!
some of the best scuba diving sites in india
the gateway to middle and north andaman - baratang - reaching here is an experience - drive through dense tropical forest - it is also a tribal reserve (you are not allowed to step out of your vehicle) - chance to see jarawa tribal people (hunter,gatherer tribes who dont want to be ‘civilized’ and probably lead a very blissful life and one of the oldest tribes historically)
30 minute boat ride through breathtaking mangroves - something like what you see in nat geo! then trek through forest to see the limestone caves
boat ride through creeks to watch 100s of parrots reach parrot island - their night time home
ross & smith islands that are connected by a sandbar that disappears during high tide
turtle nesting sites (during the nesting season)
the famous radhanagar beach in havelock
watersports in havelock, neil, northbay
coral watching at jollybuoy / redskin
history: cellular jail where british imprisoned and tortured indian freedom fighters, japanese bunkers, remnants of british rule in ross island (this is different from ross & smith), sound and light shows at both
i can go on, but these are some highlights. but beware - facilities are still developing and may not be top notch - may be the reason why it is relatively unspoiled!
hopefully by the time you travel, london - chennai direct flights would have resumed and take a connecting flight from there. (port blair international airport will open soon and you may even have direct flights!)
depending on your interests you can plan. just to give you an idea
1 full day visiting cellular jail,samudrika marine museum, anthropological museum, chatham saw mill (if that interests you) and a sunset watch trip chidiya tapu
1 full day for northbay (sea walking) and ross island
1 full day for jolly buoy - coral viewing and see if you can combine a mount harriet trek in the afternoon
3-4 full nights in havelock enjoying the beaches, scuba, sea walking, snorkelling etc
2-3 nights in neil island
1 day for baratang
3-4 nights for north andaman - ross & smith, 1 full day for saddle peak trek, aam kunj beach etc
there is another great option - if so much of travel is not for you - spend a week in havelock in a resort either on the radhanagar or vijaynagar beaches and about 5 nights in the neil islands and just the night of arrival and night before departure in port blair town!
ps: to reach havelock and neil - you have to take ferries. for baratang, north andaman - you travel by road. self drive cars are not available in andaman, you have to hire a cab with driver

column4:
day 2
we woke morning. breakfast ready 8. decent omlette coffee served. breakfast places included package. clicked photographs orchard cottages river bridge pretty sight (rather scary previous night). staff helped luggage car. set mountainous road. jio network disappeared soon left dirang came days later reached dirang back. stopped pick oranges - rs. 150 big bunch them. going source vitamin c extreme cold ahead. vegetation changed coniferous/alpine. noticed significant presence indian army paramilitary agencies itbp, ssb along route.
after hours (around noon) reached sela pass. temperature felt anywhere degrees. good amount snow, lake frozen. slipping sliding start descent snow turned smooth ice everyone walking it. saw people walk comfortably beside actual path. legs going snow, atleast risk falling slipping. gained courage walked lake rewarded. hardly came lake 30 min stay there. clicked good pictures walked car proceeded towards tawang. shoes got wet remove mine. wore sandals 500 meters later, saw side sela lake beautiful views too. got click pics walked 100 meters away. ran car started realise toes numbing. immediately took steps warm toes scared losing frostbite.
we reached nuranang/jung falls pm. arindham gave hour falls sun way down. falls quite empty. something noticed arunachal crowds quite less. picturesque falls river. dipped hands river frigid. left made journey towards tawang headlights. reached hotel - yul pemakhar 6:30 pm. hotel away main market closer monastary. two boys hotel took bags immediately climbed two floors them. showed room took order dinner said available 8:30 pm. room spacious wooden look, heater gyser took 20 mins heat water. dinner decent overpriced, could offer anything local boys assam hotel opened march 8th lockdown hadnt got cook specializes tibetan food yet.
there group boy tourists drunk noisy night.
column5:
day 2
we woke up at around 7 in the morning. breakfast was ready by 8. a decent omlette and coffee was served. breakfast at all places were included in our package. we clicked some photographs at the orchard of the cottages and at the river bridge which was now a pretty sight (rather than scary the previous night). the staff helped us with our luggage to the car. we set off again on our mountainous road. my jio network disappeared as soon as we left dirang and only came back 5 days later when we reached dirang back. we stopped by to pick up some oranges - rs. 150 for a big bunch of them. this was going to be our source of vitamin c for the extreme cold ahead. the vegetation changed to coniferous/alpine. we also noticed significant presence of indian army and paramilitary agencies like itbp, ssb along the route.
after around 2 hours (around noon) we reached sela pass. the temperature felt anywhere between 0 and 5 degrees. there was a good amount of snow, but the lake was not frozen. we were slipping and sliding at the start of our descent as the snow had turned into smooth ice with everyone walking over it. but then we saw some people walk comfortably just beside the actual path. although our legs were going into the snow, atleast we did not risk falling down by slipping. we gained courage and walked down to the lake and were rewarded. hardly anyone came to the lake during our 30 min stay there. we clicked some good pictures and then walked back up to the car and proceeded towards tawang. our shoes got wet there and i had to remove mine. i wore sandals and 500 meters later, we saw the other side of sela lake had beautiful views too. i got down to click from pics and walked around 100 meters away. i ran back to the car when i started to realise my toes were numbing. i immediately took steps to warm my toes up as i was scared of losing them to frostbite.
we reached nuranang/jung falls around 4 pm. arindham gave us an hour at the falls as the sun was on its way down. the falls was quite empty. something we noticed in arunachal that the crowds were quite less. more picturesque than the falls though was the river. we dipped our hands in the river and it was frigid. we left at around 5 pm and made the journey towards tawang with headlights. we reached our hotel - yul pemakhar at around 6:30 pm. the hotel was a bit away from the main market and was closer to the monastary. two boys from the hotel took our bags and immediately climbed up two floors with them. they showed us our room and took our order for dinner which they said will be available only by 8:30 pm. our room was spacious and had a wooden look, had a heater and the gyser took around 20 mins to heat the water. dinner was decent and not overpriced, they could not offer anything local as the boys were from assam and the hotel had just opened up on march 8th after the lockdown and they hadnt got a cook who specializes in tibetan food yet.
there was a group of boy tourists who were drunk and noisy in the night.
column8: Trip Report - Arunachal Pradesh and Kaziranga - 9D8N - Mar21

column4:
day 3
we noticed bathroom shared window adjacent bathroom group boys staying brought notice pappu hotel staff. someone room could place mobile strategically see whats happening bathroom. also, boys smoked lot bathroom filled smoke.
next morning served french toast coffee 7:30 am. am, scorpio driven tawang local tashi arrived. innova crysta assam allowed north tawang local vehicle four wheel drive.
he explained tawang part tibet half ended india china due mcmohan line drawn across it. steadily gained altitude soon snow common sight. stopped ptso lake. looked majestic draped snow around. spent half hour sliding making snow angels snow tashi came call us. said place called junction 10 army wont allow proceed towards bumla. reached junction 9:55 proceeded towards bumla. temperature dropped sun reflected snow everywhere blinding. difficult see anything wearing glares. reached 11 am. kept mobiles tashi car. asked note car registration asked registration desk. went room run military register names vehicle number. ladies washroom nearby girls used. army maggi soup sale given boiling hot conditions provided heat. everyone asked deposit mobiles counter, warning officers border view point found mobile reset it. cellphone complied deposited mobiles. finally, army took 10 meters short border explained war, border, etc.there overzealous tourists kept requesting army allow right chinese border, army guy kept refusing follow orders. came room desk, returned mobiles. rested little thin mountain air put pressure lungs. carry sun glasses place, glare sun snow pretty harsh. also, exert much, oxygen less end getting altitude sickness. resting army officer asked wants again, next batch people. bumla called bumula locals – la meaning height bumula stands beautiful woman.
we proceeded car mins came across highest cafeteria world. run army talks daily lives. soon started snowing lightly sight outside pretty. set way. driver tashi patient stopped several pretty sights way. saw number frozen lakes took lot pictures. snow got heavier tashi obliged asked stop pictures. reached room pretty tired. rested while. vodafone airtel networks disappeared 3:30 day, tower stopped functioning. note: mobile network whole trip patchy. vodafone/airtel work upto tawang jio works upto dirang. parts mountains receive network all. bsnl works well arunachal.
arindham came call light sound show tawang war memorial. memorial took giant buddha statue overlooks tawang. saw several people evening walk there, others praying making rounds statue. seemed hang spot youth. reached war memorial 5:30 pm. arindham told look show pm. saw war memorial heroes defended chinese aggression 1962 war. 5:50 pm, went light sound show, crowd gathered. army guys trying figure accommodate many people amidst calls put second show (7 pm?), brought chairs accomodated us, couldnt see show clearly. show added lot context trip.
since wanted taste local food, asked arindham local hotel. took mon valley tawang market. food good, took chicken momos thukpa. momo plate accompanied soup. quantity quite lot. hotel closed immediately left. way back, 7:30 pm, roads deserted quiet. town shut night.
when came room, noticed window planked up. thanks pappu prompt action. arindham tried search chicken tawang away trip, could find any.
column5:
day 3
we noticed that our bathroom shared a window with the adjacent bathroom where the group of boys were staying and brought it to the notice of pappu from the hotel staff. someone from the other room could actually place their mobile strategically and see whats happening in our bathroom. also, the boys smoked a lot and our bathroom filled with smoke.
next morning we were served french toast and coffee by 7:30 am. by 8 am, our scorpio driven by tawang local tashi arrived. the innova crysta from assam is not allowed north of tawang and has to be a local vehicle which is a four wheel drive.
he explained how tawang was actually a part of tibet and how half of ended up in india and china due to the mcmohan line being drawn across it. we steadily gained altitude and soon snow was a common sight. we first stopped at ptso lake. it looked majestic draped in snow all around. we spent around half an hour sliding and making snow angels in the snow when tashi came to call us. he said that we have to be at a place called y junction before 10 am or else the army wont allow us to proceed towards bumla. we reached y junction around 9:55 and then proceeded towards bumla. the temperature had dropped and the sun reflected on the snow everywhere was blinding. it was difficult to see anything without wearing glares. we reached around 11 am. we kept our mobiles with tashi in the car. he asked us to note down our car registration as we would be asked at the registration desk. we went into a room run by the military where we had to register and give our names and vehicle number. there was a ladies washroom nearby which the girls used. the army also had maggi and soup for sale which was not all that great but given that both were boiling hot in such conditions provided us some heat. everyone was asked to deposit their mobiles at the counter, with a warning that if the officers at the border view point found the mobile they would reset it. one of us still had our cellphone and complied and deposited our mobiles. finally, the army took us 10 meters short of the border where they explained to us about the war, the border, etc.there were a few overzealous tourists who kept requesting the army to allow them to go right up to the chinese border, however the army guy kept refusing that he has to follow orders. when we came back to the room with the desk, we were returned our mobiles. we rested for a little while as the thin mountain air did put a bit of pressure on our lungs. please carry sun glasses to this place, the glare of the sun on the snow can be pretty harsh. also, do not exert yourself too much, the oxygen is less and you may end up getting altitude sickness. while resting the army officer asked if anyone wants to go again, since the next batch had a very few people. bumla is called bumula by the locals – la meaning height and bumula stands for a very beautiful woman.
we proceeded back to the car and after a few mins came across the highest cafeteria of the world. this was run by the army and we had a few talks with them about their daily lives. it soon started snowing lightly and the sight outside was pretty. we set off on our way. our driver tashi was very patient and stopped at several pretty sights on the way. we saw a number of frozen lakes and took a lot of pictures. the snow got heavier and tashi obliged when we asked him to stop for some pictures. we reached back to our room at around 2 pm and were pretty tired. we rested for a while. our vodafone and airtel networks disappeared at around 3:30 pm for a day, may be their tower stopped functioning. note: that mobile network for the whole trip is patchy. vodafone/airtel work upto tawang and jio works only upto dirang. there are parts in the mountains which receive no network at all. bsnl works well in arunachal.
arindham came to call us to go for a light and sound show at tawang war memorial. before the memorial he took us to a giant buddha statue that overlooks tawang. we saw several people on their evening walk there, while others were praying by making rounds of the statue. it also seemed like hang out spot for youth. we reached the war memorial at around 5:30 pm. arindham told us to look around and then go for the show at 6 pm. we saw the war memorial to our heroes who defended against chinese aggression in the 1962 war. at 5:50 pm, when we went for the light and sound show, there was already a crowd gathered. the army guys were trying to figure out how to accommodate so many people amidst calls to put us in the second show (7 pm?), they some how brought some chairs and accomodated us, although we couldnt see the show clearly. the show added a lot of context to the trip.
since we wanted to taste some local food, we asked arindham to take us to a local hotel. he took us to mon valley in the tawang market. the food there was really good, we took chicken momos and thukpa. each momo plate was accompanied by soup. the quantity was also quite a lot. the hotel also closed immediately after we left. on our way back, it was just 7:30 pm, but the roads were deserted and quiet. the town had shut for the night.
when we came back to our room, we noticed that the window was planked up. thanks to pappu for the prompt action. arindham had tried to search for chicken at tawang while we were away on our trip, he could not find any.
column8: Trip Report - Arunachal Pradesh and Kaziranga - 9D8N - Mar21

column4:
“ small window 3-4 months (june-sept), ride leh. roads blocked rest year.”
this wildly inaccurate, starting idea two inroads open/close time. last decade srinagar-leh opened march , final closure open often long december - twice early january. pics run early december - road closed , unsurprisingly, three weeks later :

manali-leh runs lot higher , closes earlier . snowfallls often mid-september , closure normally mid/late november . pics run made end-october :

roads within ladakh remain normally open thru winter . month long stay count days problems snowfall , quickly burns away sunny conditions.
rain occur nowadays early august , problem road trips.
“ indian citizens require permit visit ladakh..”
neither angrezis , 90+ percent ladakh & zanskar permit free areas . permits required :
* north leh ( nubra , tso moriri )
* northwest leh ( dha & hanu )
* east manali-leh road , close chinese border ( pangong tso )
column5:
“ there is a small window of 3-4 months (june-sept), when you can ride to leh. the roads are blocked during the rest of the year.”
this is wildly inaccurate, starting with the idea that the two inroads open/close at the same time. over the last decade srinagar-leh has opened between march and may , and final closure open often long in to december - twice in to early january. here some pics from a run in early december - road closed , unsurprisingly, three weeks later :

manali-leh runs a lot higher , and closes earlier . first snowfallls often in mid-september , closure normally around mid/late november . here some pics from a run i made end-october :

roads within ladakh remain normally open thru the winter . in a month long stay i count on a few days with problems from snowfall , that quickly burns away in sunny conditions.
rain does occur nowadays in sometimes around early august , and can be a problem on road trips.
“ indian citizens require no permit to visit ladakh..”
neither does angrezis , and 90+ percent of ladakh & zanskar is permit free areas . permits are required :
* north of leh ( nubra , tso moriri )
* northwest of leh ( dha & hanu )
* east of manali-leh road , close to chinese border ( pangong tso )

i love goa but not for snorkelling or diving.
there are a lot of jetski rentals near calangute leaving trails of oil and fuel in the water as they roar about.
its too rough for windsurfing or sailing.
if you do a search on this forum you will find similar comments.

column4:
#7 suggested possible practically. zanskar closed april winter local administration worked hard keep open far major snowfall roads blocked again, clearance happen immediately route, best avoid april.
in option ii itinerary suggested, day 4, impossible cover, turtuk siachen base camp single day, different valleys direction. traveler choose turtuk siachen base camp (tourists allowed till base camp glacier).
column5:
#7 again what you suggested are not possible practically. zanskar may be closed in april although this winter the local administration has worked hard to keep it open so far but a major snowfall and the roads will be blocked again, clearance does not happen immediately on this route, so best to avoid in april.
in the option ii itinerary you have suggested, on day 4, it is impossible to cover, both turtuk and siachen base camp on a single day, both are in different valleys and direction. so the traveler will have to choose either turtuk or siachen base camp (tourists are allowed only till base camp and not to the glacier).

column4:
donna - jul/aug off-season, namely due heat lots locals residents decamp europe summer. recent years brought tourists off-season (due price drops) - heat ott outside activities - brunches lot tourist-centric attractions close reduce significantly
a hotels shall say, mini-malls (e.g. jumeirah emirates towers, hyatt regency, atlantis) much time/attention far getting 'main' malls eg. dubai mall, mall emirates etc. marina mall address dubai marina perhaps best combination.
column5:
donna - jul/aug is off-season, namely due to heat but also as lots of locals and residents decamp to europe for summer. recent years have brought a few more tourists in during the off-season (due to price drops) but - other than the heat which can be ott for outside activities - things like brunches and a lot of the tourist-centric stuff like attractions either close or reduce significantly
a few hotels have shall we say, mini-malls (e.g. jumeirah emirates towers, hyatt regency, atlantis) but not much to take your time/attention and you'd be far better off getting to the 'main' malls eg. dubai mall, mall of emirates etc. marina mall and the address dubai marina are perhaps the best combination.

enjoy visiting hh, real reason overnight there. check surf, lunch lake, little shopping, needing, little compared past 'availability things. krung thep better.

column5:
i've done retirement visas before, 800k in, no witness, approved locally. usually takes 15 - 30 mins for them.
don't care for tying up money, and local imm (hh), wants 400 k in + 400 direct deposit as an alternative, so basically need the same bank paperwork if not doing the 800k in. my witness enjoys the day out, and only real addition for me, is returning to p/u 30 days later, which, i enjoy the day out also ... 🤣
enjoy visiting hh, just no real reason to overnight there. check out the surf, lunch by the lake, a little shopping, if needing, though very little compared to past 'availability of all things. krung thep still better.
this time we'll pop in on the way to krung thep anyway. all the visa applying is simple, just a bit time consuming, and that's relative, as way better than a thai trying to go to my or most countries, so nobody can really complain. a 5 yr visa and no 90 day pulse check would be nice, but don't mind the pulse checks either, as again, another day out of the house, but much closer to home for them.

column5:

column4:
everywhere central, eastern northern thailand qualify "least humidity", dry season areas away coastal breezes showers. none "dry heat" desert sw us. simply slightly lower level rainy season.
temperatures north pleasant january early february, start climbing approach "summer" (march may). temps central eastern parts tend stay warm. deal haze time time dry season, weather patterns trap smoke, pollution dust.
column5:
everywhere in central, eastern and northern thailand would qualify as "least humidity", as it is dry season and those areas are away from the coastal breezes and showers. but none are really a "dry heat" such as what you would get in the desert sw of the us. it is simply a slightly lower level than rainy season.
temperatures in the north are pleasant in january and early february, then start climbing as we approach our "summer" (march to may). temps in central and eastern parts tend to stay warm. all of these have to deal with haze from time to time during the dry season, as weather patterns can trap the smoke, pollution and dust.

column4: #29 - lot others. everyone assumes work tourism answer thailand questions, must thailand tour company. partner based tour company offering tours 15 different countries, which, mentioned, thailand represents 10% tour inventory. bulk "work" days traveling potential new destinations research adventure travel options, develop itineraries, check lodging, meet guide prospects, etc. vested interest comments people hurl way, fall short mark.
column5: #29 - you and a lot of others. everyone assumes that because i work in tourism and answer thailand questions, i must have a thailand tour company. but i am a partner in a us based tour company offering tours in 15 different countries, of which, as mentioned, thailand represents only 10% of our tour inventory. the bulk of my "work" these days is traveling to potential new destinations to research adventure travel options, develop itineraries, check out lodging, meet guide prospects, etc. so all these vested interest comments that people like to hurl my way, fall short of the mark.

column4:
visited thailand 1989, went grandmother lived phuket bhuket known lived 1960’s. lived phuket town 1989 lucky see house lived communal swimming pool grandfather helped build. met grandparent’s thai friends amazing experience aged 17 grandmother return 20 years. soon stepped plane different europe, smells noise traffic bangkok. clearly remember journey airport bangkok.
i silver cigarette box presented grandma left thailand teaching thais scottish country dancing. 1989 could believe island called last place god’s earth destination people called paradise number hotels! trip beach 1960s journey along bumpy roads, hotels. spent amazing weeks starting bangkok, visiting pattaya, phuket, penang kl, ending singapore.
it enjoyable trip returned 1998 grandma husband. house phuket inhabited communal pool empty. love find exact location. husband loved trip, sadly lost grandma 1999. delightful surprise brother announced moving bangkok 2001 teach months, intended move onto japan countries, 20 years later bangkok married two children. managed visit twice kids visit every year. last february winter trip amazing away cold weather. can’t wait able return annual winter trip us.
edited: 4:22 pm, january 04,
column5:
i visited thailand in 1989, i went with my grandmother who had lived in phuket or in bhuket as it was known when she lived there in the 1960’s. they lived in phuket town and in 1989 i was lucky to see the house they had lived in and the communal swimming pool my grandfather had helped build. we met my grandparent’s thai friends and it it was an amazing experience for me at aged 17 and for my grandmother to return after over 20 years. as soon as i stepped off the plane it was different to europe, the smells and the noise and the traffic in bangkok. i still clearly remember the journey from the airport into bangkok.
i have a silver cigarette box that was presented to my grandma when she left a thailand as a thank you for teaching the thais scottish country dancing. in 1989 she could not believe that the island she had called the last place on god’s earth was now a destination people called paradise and the number of hotels! a trip to the beach in the 1960s was a journey along bumpy roads, there were no hotels. i spent an amazing 5 weeks starting in bangkok, visiting pattaya, phuket, penang and kl, ending in singapore.
it was such an enjoyable trip that we returned in 1998 with my grandma and husband. her house in phuket was now inhabited and the communal pool empty. i would love to find out the exact location. my husband and i loved our trip, sadly we lost my grandma in 1999. it was a delightful surprise when my brother announced he was moving to bangkok in 2001 to teach for a few months, he intended to move onto japan and other countries, 20 years later he is still in bangkok and is now married with two children. we have managed to visit twice with our kids and once on our own and now hope to visit every year. last february was our first winter trip which was absolutely amazing to get away from the cold weather. can’t wait to be able to return and think it will be an annual winter trip for us.
edited: 4:22 pm, january 04, 2021

column5:
hoping it works out to go to thailand next year (booked refundable flights already for a great price!)
my original plan was to head to chiang mai area for the first 4-5 days, then finish the trip off with a week or so around koh tao/koh samui for some beach and diving time, then a night or two in bangkok before flying home.
then i discovered burning season might make chiang mai a bad idea (had not heard of that before)...
we have been to thailand once before a few years ago (dec/jan) and flew in/out of phuket, spent 2 weeks island hopping between there and koh lipe so would like to have a different experience this time.
what could we add in place of chiang mai for some mountainous, temple, jungle... experience? not too crazy about big cities, prefer laid back places (hence just a night or 2 in bangkok on the way home). i know we’d be happy at the beach but since that was all we did the first trip there just wanted to check out something other than just that this time around.

column5:
#1 ... +1 khao lak &especially khao sok / cheow lan lake are excellent choices for quieter, non diving nature.
as pointed out, nothing will be a version of pp 1994, well, except for now, at int'l tourist beach areas, and probably a little too quiet for most folks. just came back from phuket, and with few exceptions, all beach areas were dead, and most vendors shuttered.

how soon that will change, if & when things open up is a guess, so should still be fairly quiet, relative to mass crowds of pre-c19.
i'd choose pp for the water / diving part, as closer to. out of phuket, and they are all day affairs, as most go to the same sites. hours vs minutes to same sites.
you probably know already, but the boys are men, and hotels will consider them as such .... lol, pricing wise, so budget wise, villa & suites may be a bit thrifty, if wanting to be near each other. or since young men enjoy nightlife of the island, their privacy may be a bit more of a priority.
wouldn't book any hotels that need to be paid for, or non refundable rates, if wanting to lock in some 'covid discounts'. also encourage the 'boys' to do a bit of research, and they, and yourself may enjoy a night or 2 on phuket, possibly bangla rd, and should be festive, maybe by year's end.
good luck .... enjoy

column4:
#14 - whats wrong rainy season ? someone living tropics want sun beating 12 hours day spending till huddling shade.
people cold countries uk often fail appreciate unlike home countries cloudy weather means cold outdoors gloomy tropics days bright walk sand burning feet. add returning uk october june fun - landing cold days six layers shirts keep warm.
the whole country grind halt onwards wet dry pretty quickly. bad news coming july instead january need shower cool swimming sea hot !
column5:
#14 - whats wrong with the rainy season ? as someone living in the tropics i don't want the sun beating down on me 12 hours a day and spending from 9 am till 4 pm huddling in the shade.
people from cold countries such as the uk often fail to appreciate that unlike in their home countries where cloudy weather means being cold and the outdoors gloomy in the tropics the days are just as bright and also you can walk on the sand without burning your feet. add to that returning to the uk between october to june is no fun at all - landing on cold days with only six layers of t shirts to keep you warm.
the whole of the country doesn't grind to a halt from may onwards and if you do get wet you dry off pretty quickly. the only bad news about coming in july instead of january is you need a shower to cool down after swimming as the sea is too hot !

column4: honest problems thailand wet season, never found spoilt enjoyment thailands many varied attractions. guess different main purpose lay bech day (i appreciate that) often cloudy hot often rain heavy comes lasts couple hours so. biggest danger rainy season tourists thinking overcast burnt sun........rest assured can!
column5: to be honest have no problems either with thailand in the wet season, never found that it has spoilt my enjoyment of thailands many and varied attractions. i guess it may be different if your main purpose is to lay on a bech all day (i appreciate there are some that do like to do that) however even then though often more cloudy it is still hot and often the rain though very heavy when it comes only lasts for a couple of hours or so. the biggest danger in the rainy season is tourists thinking because it is overcast they won't get burnt by the sun........rest assured you still can!

note--i posted message thailand forum mistake remove post.
as wrote bkk cm forums, planning senior parents asia food good affordable 2022 1-2 months. time frame late march mid/late may. friendly members ta, learn chiang mai's air quality extremely bad time--and ruled cm. bangkok away mountains, hot.
can anybody comparison heat bangkok vs hong kong singapore? personally hong kong destination (too $$$ little do), summer temperature often lower feels hot island effects. singapore sits equator season. heat stifling hong kong, long outdoor daytime much. singapore's air feels cleaner hk's, except bush burning season indonesia.
in bkk, pretty much decided stay away central areas lots skyscrapers trapping heat.
i understand look historical temp/humidity charts, often tell feels ground. appreciate advice. thanks.
column5:
dear all:
note--i posted this message in the thailand forum by mistake but don't know how to remove that post.
as i wrote in the bkk and cm forums, i am planning to take my senior parents to asia where food is good and affordable in 2022 for 1-2 months. the time frame will be from late march to mid/late may. from the friendly members in ta, i learn that chiang mai's air quality is extremely bad during this time--and so i have ruled out cm. bangkok is further away from the mountains, but can get hot.
can anybody give me a comparison of how the heat is like in bangkok vs hong kong and singapore? i personally don't like hong kong as a destination (too $$$ with too little to do), and its summer temperature often is lower than it actually feels because of hot island effects. singapore sits on the equator and only has one season. the heat is not as stifling as that in hong kong, as long as one isn't outdoor during daytime much. singapore's air also feels cleaner than hk's, except during the bush burning season in indonesia.
in bkk, i have pretty much decided to stay away from the central areas with lots of skyscrapers trapping heat.
i understand that i can look at historical temp/humidity charts, but they often don't tell one what it actually feels like on the ground. would appreciate your advice. thanks.
column8: Bangkok vs Singapore and Hong Kong in March-May

column5:
from my experience, hk is definitely very hot and the humidity is almost unbearable especially starting in may and onwards into the summer. i would still go as i love it in hk, can get food easily for cheap. as for things to do, i was never bored but to each their own.
i actually did not find singapore to be too hot or humid and i went in may. the weather was bearable for me, but for me there wasn't a lot to do and the food wasn't as good as i expected.
for bangkok, i usually go at either end of the year or beginning and the weather is fine for me. but it goes get back if you are out and about a lot especially in the day time.
so in conclusion hk is the worst for me, followed by bkk and sg was fine.
good luck!

replies.
i answer easy. personally love beach folks senior that. issue hk singapore worked expat year thus traveling places reminds work. job.

as far mediterranean concerned, believe weather stable enough till least mid may. also, parents see asia time. covid situation eu seems far worst thailand, singapore, hk. love greece parents excited it. 2019, spent five "eat, pray, love" type weeks spain portugal alone. love (i call "romance myself") romantic parents.

column5:
thank you for the replies.
i know that the answer won't be easy. i personally love the beach but my folks are too senior for that. another issue with hk and singapore is that i worked there as an expat for one year and thus traveling in these places reminds me of work. i didn't like my then job.
i will do some research about phuket, which has more of a real community though it doesn't have the best beaches. i still want to consider bkk as we can always just lounge by the pool in hot afternoons. riding taxis all the time isn't expensive either. public transit is available and acts as a good alternative transit mode when traffic is bad.
as far as the mediterranean is concerned, i believe the weather is still not stable enough till at least mid may. also, my parents would like to see asia this time. the covid situation in eu also seems to be far worst than thailand, singapore, and hk. i love greece but my parents aren't too excited about it. in 2019, i spent five "eat, pray, love" type weeks in spain and portugal alone. love it (i call this "romance with myself") but i don't think it is romantic with my parents.
so, my next question is: other than phuket, where can i find places with both nice beaches and real local communities? i believe that in phuket, i would stay around phuket town since there is a more local feel and that i don't have to drive around. i also thought about pattaya, but my parents hated the red light districts when they visited a decade ago. i also considered mexico, but soon dismissed it due to high crime.
edited: 7:53 pm, april 03, 2021

column4: choice diving koh bon richelieu rock 100% richelieu rock trip. good chance spotting manta rays sites - richelieu rock stunning pinnacle covered soft corals huge amount tropical life - koh bon cleaning station prone strong currents underwater topology mostly massive boulders. slim chance see whale sharks richelieu rock well.
column5: if you have a choice of diving at koh bon or richelieu rock then 100% do the richelieu rock trip. there is a good chance of spotting manta rays at both sites - but if you do not then richelieu rock is a stunning pinnacle covered in soft corals and a huge amount of tropical life - koh bon is a cleaning station that is prone to strong currents and the underwater topology is mostly massive boulders. also a slim but better chance to see whale sharks at richelieu rock as well.
column8: Which dive sites? Similan vs Koh Bon, Tachai, Richelieu

column4:
question be, children gets car sick, night train wise choice? mention heat factor, march, april & "summer" thailand northern reaches quite hot (upper 30s low 40s).
if kids nature, perhaps lieu chiang mai (save future winter trip) check kanchanaburi khao sok. kids kick couple nights hotel floating cheiw larn lake khao sok, able jump water swim right rooms porch. couple nights safari tents elephant hills khao sok.
column5:
my first question would be, since one of your children gets car sick, is an all night train a wise choice? you also mention heat being a factor, march, april & may are "summer" here in thailand and the northern reaches get quite hot (upper 30s to low 40s).
if your kids like nature, perhaps in lieu of chiang mai (save it for a future winter trip) check out kanchanaburi or khao sok. kids might get a kick out of a couple nights in a hotel floating on cheiw larn lake in khao sok, being able to jump into the water for swim right off the rooms porch. or a couple nights in safari tents at elephant hills in khao sok.

does your 3 nights at khao sok include the night on the lake or in addition to? your first day will be short, with the notoriously late train from bangkok and the drive to khao sok and of course the check out day being morning only. i personally would go for three nights in the village plus a night or two on the lake. there is canoeing, float trips, nature walks out from the village, feeding the fish at wat tham wararam, plus you are there during the blooming season for rafflesia, the world's largest and rather bizarre flower. my 8 year old loves it down there.

column4:
due latent heat.
in short, bodies water heat cool (absorb release energy) depending surroundings (which sun beating them, cool night air etc).
as general rule smaller body water easily lose gain heat. larger body water longer takes occur. why:
- pools cooler morning- cooled night air. effect stronger area cold nights, ie mountains, deserts etc. overcome heat pools put cover night expensive, resource heavy options.
- ocean cold spring hot days summer - big warm quickly
- ocean surprisingly warm autumn/fall,- takes time cool heat summer
this thai thing, occurs everywhere world.
hope helps, enjoy swimming, ever are!
column5:
it's due to latent heat.
in short, bodies of water heat up or cool down (absorb or release energy) depending on their surroundings (which can be the sun beating down on them, cool night air etc).
as a general rule the smaller the body of water the more easily they will lose or gain heat. the larger the body of water the longer it takes for this to occur. this is why:
- pools are cooler in the morning- they have been cooled by the night air. this effect will be stronger if you are in an area with cold nights, ie mountains, deserts etc. to overcome this you can heat pools or put a cover over them at night but both are expensive, resource heavy options.
- the ocean is still cold during spring and the first hot days of summer - it's too big to warm up quickly
- the ocean is surprisingly warm in autumn/fall,- it takes some time to cool after the heat of summer
this isn't a thai thing, it occurs everywhere in the world.
hope this helps, enjoy swimming, where ever you are!

column4:
there
we spent month thailand feb 2020 children aged 11. amazing experience worthwhile them.
our itinerary was:
3 nights bangkok stayed ibis riverside (great family rooms)
2 nights khao yai stayed greenleaf afternoon tour 1st day full day tour 2nd day. amazing place greenleaf highly recommended. tours incredible saw wild elephants well much else.
next got train ayutthaya spent afternoon temple tour getting night train chiang mai.
7 nights chiang mai fabulous kids. highlights day karen tribe native elephants (cant recommended highly enough), sticky waterfalls, big game fishing, grand canyon water park.
then got direct flight krabi taxi koh lanta nights. koh lanta amazing family friendly. best day ever private long-tail trip koh rok, magical day life lanta paradise called. loved car hire going national park, mangrove kayaking trip.
after got speedboat koh mook nights. quiet pretty totally different vibe developed, real roads, 7/11, atm etc. loved here, put going hotel behind main beach knocked quite building site.
next got speedboat koh lipe nights. stayed castaway family house. stunning here, nowhere i've been. busier. snorkeling incredible water beautiful crystal clear turquoise colour. loved it.
then flew hat yai bangkok night heading home.
i love hesitate encourage others travel thailand young families. enjoy planning i'm envious!!!
column5:
hi there
we spent a month in thailand feb 2020 with our children aged 8 and 11. absolutely amazing experience and so worthwhile doing with them.
our itinerary was:
3 nights bangkok stayed at ibis riverside (great family rooms)
2 nights khao yai stayed at greenleaf and did the afternoon tour on 1st day then full day tour on 2nd day. absolutely amazing place and greenleaf is highly recommended. tours were incredible and we saw wild elephants as well as so much else.
next we got train to ayutthaya and spent afternoon on temple tour before getting night train to chiang mai.
7 nights at chiang mai which again absolutely fabulous with kids. highlights were day with karen tribe native elephants (cant recommended highly enough), sticky waterfalls, big game fishing, grand canyon water park.
then we got direct flight to krabi and taxi to koh lanta for 5 nights. koh lanta amazing and very family friendly. best day ever was a private long-tail trip to koh rok, most magical day of my life with lanta paradise i think was called. also loved car hire and going to national park, and mangrove kayaking trip.
after this we got speedboat to koh mook for 3 nights. very quiet but very pretty and a totally different vibe as not at all developed, no real roads, no 7/11, no atm etc. loved it here, only thing put me off going back was a hotel behind main beach been knocked down and was quite a building site.
next got speedboat to koh lipe for 4 nights. stayed at castaway in family house. absolutely stunning here, like nowhere else i've been. but busier. snorkeling incredible and the water the most beautiful crystal clear turquoise colour. loved it.
then flew from hat yai to bangkok for 1 more night before heading home.
i would love to do it again and would not hesitate to encourage others to travel to thailand with young families. enjoy the planning i'm very envious!!!

column5:
there's a little funfair with rides for young children on the pier, and in the last couple of days a new ferris wheel has also appeared on the pier - 
bonkerz is an indoor play centre which might be a useful place to visit if it's raining - 
if the weather is nice there are two beaches to visits - the north shore and the west shore (of which west shore is by far the better beach).
there's a toboggan run at the ski centre on the great orme. it's up quite a steep hill but you can drive up and there's a car park - 
bodafon farm park would be a good place to visit with young children. it's a bit of a way from the town centre so you'd need to drive there but again there's a car park on the site.
there is parking throughout llandudno but it's a mixture of street parking with time limits, street parking with no time limits and car parks that you have to park on. it's not a big town and other than the great orme it's mostly flat so your best bet might be to find somewhere reasonably central so you don't have to keep moving your car. the town hall car park might be an option if you're happy to pay and display or there are car parks at maelgwyn road and york road which are a bit cheaper but a bit further from the town centre - 
the postcode for the copper mines is ll30 2xg - there's a car park on site.
edited: 12:53 pm, august 28, 2021

the bus driver nice friendly. asset durham i'm sorry note name.

there young, young woman gift shop; precious sweet. shop good book architecture cathedral reading.

column5:
i went to durham to see the cathedral on tuesday, july 6, and i wanted to share my experience with other would-be travelers.
-book the guided tour in advance. it was sold out for the day i went, and i had been waiting many years to visit the cathedral (romanesque architecture is my absolute favorite). it did not even occur to me that i needed to book many days in advance. i honestly thought i would cry when they kindly said it was sold out*. i texted my children and husband; my husband offered to try to find me a private tour guide immediately, but there was not way that could have worked out. very sweet of him, though.
-tour groups are currently limited to 5 or 6 ppl total. i was confused bc there was at least 1 large school group there on that day; many more than 5-6 ppl. i realize the rules come from the uk govt, not the cathedral. i realize that the cathedral is doing its best to follow what seem to be confusing rules (a big school group = ok, +6 adults in a tour group = not ok). it is what it is--just know them before you go.
-reserve a table in the cafe if you think you might eat there, or eat after 2pm.
*i did not cry, although i may never get to go to durham again (i live in tx), because of the volunteers at the cathedral. i would especially like to highlight hazel, a docent who was so helpful. she was like an angel. she answered my many questions in great detail and was the best of the british--kind, knowledgeable, and with a reserve that comes from a deep well of very good manners. she made me feel i could ask as many questions as i wanted to.
another female docent, tall, thin, with a sporty short haircut, encouraged me to buy a guidebook (which i did) and it was so helpful. many thanks to her.
it was a miserable day--chilly and pouring rain. a chipper younger woman at the entrance pointed out the river path to the bridge, and i'm so glad she did; it was a wonderful (although chilly) walk.
i arrived on a train from london; there is a bus that runs you to the cathedral every 15 minutes or so. many thanks to the women working in the station that day who pointed me in the right direction to catch the bus.
the bus driver was so nice and friendly. such an asset to durham and i'm sorry i did not make note of his name.
i had not eaten all day and, after seeing most of the cathedral, i went down to the cafe on a chance; there was 1 unreserved table at 2:15 (the guided tour started at 2). the women working in the cafe were very helpful. i had the lasagna special (lasagna, bread, and a salad) and a giant (hot and cozy) latte. my lunch was delicious and perfect for the weather.
there was a young, young woman in the gift shop; she was precious and sweet. the shop has a very good book on the architecture of the cathedral which i have been reading.
i wandered around the immediate area before catching the bus back to the train station and back to london. 6 hours on a train; 3 hours in durham.
all of the people i have referenced were at their posts after 12:20 on july 6. they deserve recognition. if there is any way to forward my thanks to them, please let me know.
the cathedral is exceptional and durham, even in the pouring rain, was charming. it was well worth the 3 hours there and 3 hours back on the train.
thank you, durham, for preserving this amazing unesco world heritage site and welcoming people so graciously and kindly. it's the graciousness and kindness i will most remember. and the lasagna. :)

we are planning on driving from cheshire and getting the ferry from southampton (as my partner doesn't fancy flying or going through an airport) but understand we won't really need the car when we get there.
any thoughts much appreciated!

'#1 mac. no, dissappointed. weather perfect, worked fine me, ie walking generally got sunshine etc. real affect weather camping i'm foot standard length season sleeping bag ! good trip enjoyed lot. many thanks help. blimey, 1,400 miles 12 days going !!!!!
#2 #4 - guess moved trip reports, deliberately put there, impression noone ever looks there. thought allowed stay general scotland section basis others contributed towards planning trip (sounds lame argument tbf haha)

column5:
'#1 mac. no, wasn't dissappointed. the weather wasn't perfect, but it actually worked out fine for me, ie when i was out walking i generally got sunshine etc. only real affect the weather had on me was camping as i'm 6 foot 4 and have a standard length 2 season sleeping bag ! it was a good trip that i enjoyed a lot. very many thanks for all your help. blimey, 1,400 miles in 12 days is going some !!!!!
#2 and #4 - i guess it might get moved into trip reports, but i deliberately didn't put it in there, because i get the impression noone ever looks in there. i thought it might be allowed to stay in the general scotland section on the basis that others contributed towards planning the trip (sounds like a lame argument tbf haha)
#3 that was the storm that hit when i was at the top of the quirang. on the way out it was glorious weather, then as we got to the top it closed right in and visibility dropped to almost nothing. quite a bit of hail, but it cleared up enough for us (i was tagging along with some others, one of whom had a map app on his mobile), to get back to the car park literally moments before the temp dropped to zero and the skies opened for an hour and a half of heavy snow.
i'll get those photos sorted out asap.

column5:
back from my 4 night break last week - had an absolutely fantastic time. we did blencathra via blease fell/scales fell and we found this to be perfect for us as first timers. we also did catbells, half the ullswater way, glenridding dodd, aira force & gowbarrow fell and castle crag. did not get around to angletarn pikes as my dodgy knee had given up the ghost by that point. we got very lucky with the weather too.
cannot wait to go back and do some more walks, so will be looking for more suggestions of walks of a similar difficulty nearer that time. thanks for all the advice :)

column5:
i’m glad ripon had it’s problem sorted out.
i was looking at the week starting at 30.7.21.
wood burner in july. there’re english summers, and there’re english summers. 3 years ago, when we visited yorkshire it was so hot! water in aysgarth falls dried out. all of the gardens looked miserable, and sun burnt.
2 years ago, in dartmoor there were many rainy days, with temperatures dropping to +16c during the day ( our winter temperature). reaching your cottage after being caught in the rain - wood burner is useful and cozy. our resilience to cold is different to yours. we had a one day heat wave (+29c), just two days ago.
also, i’m only looking at the cottages with larger fridge, since we’re eating breakfasts and dinners at “home”. we’ve hired cottages with them smallish installed fridges before. it’s been annoying, to go to the supermarket every second day.
we need two bathrooms! teenage girls need their time in shower, and i’m an ale drinking diabetic...
we need a garden, with outdoor seating. that’s where i spend my evenings drinking tea, smoking, etc.
we don’t like them compound like a few cottages sharing a yard. we’ve stayed in such place in peak district by monyash once. there were a few noisy families there. girls felt they had to behave at all times, instead of allowing themselves to act freely. it’s not like they’re doing something criminal. they like to dance, sing, jump, play badminton, chess, chase bunnies, etc. i like to make them feel comfortable. both are extremely hard working students, and they deserve their time off the rules&regulations.
all in all, choosing a holiday cottage is always uneasy task for me. corona only made things more complicated.
since most ( if not all ) of the self catering bookings are totally refundable nowadays. i’d expect late vacancies to pop up. that, if uk will allow british folks to travel abroad. then, it’ll go back to normality: when you stand better chance to meet a brit in crete, than in the oxford street, london!
yuri.

column5:
if you must head that way though, i would suggest you have a look at the “snow roads” scenic route, which puts you near enough to loch ness and will let you leave/join the motorway network at perth and travel through superb country in the eastern cairngorms and it will avoid the major roadworks/10mph convoys on the busy a9 - personally i think it is best taken heading south so you could link at heading west of glasgow, crossing the erskine bridge, then the a82 up loch lomond, across rannoch moor and through glencoe and the lower part of the great glen to fort augustus - which is by far the best village on loch ness and some of the finer landscapes f the wes.

column4:
>> planning rent car driver. <<
that good choice itinerary.
>> chennai, mahabalipuram, pondicherry, kumbakonam, thanjavur, tiruchirapalli, chettinad, madurai.<<
okay. state tamil nadu gets rain northwest monsoon october december; rather southwest monsoon july september.
even so, chennai / pondy / coastal places rain august; average temperatures mid 30s. along coast sub-tropics expect quite humid conditions - depending used to. madurai inland places likely drier, similar temperatures. note little relief temperatures night - mid 20s perhaps.
generally speaking, best time - weather wise - january - march; monsoon avoid rain cooler weather. late january - early februay pick.
column5:
>> i am planning to rent a car with a driver. <<
that is a good choice for your itinerary.
>> chennai, mahabalipuram, pondicherry, kumbakonam, thanjavur, tiruchirapalli, chettinad, madurai.<<
okay. the state of tamil nadu actually gets most of its rain in the northwest monsoon from october to december; rather than the southwest monsoon between july and september.
even so, chennai / pondy / and other coastal places will still get rain in august; average temperatures will be in the mid 30s. along the coast in the sub-tropics you should expect quite humid conditions - depending on what you are used to. madurai and other inland places are likely to be drier, with similar temperatures. note that there is very little relief from the temperatures at night - mid 20s perhaps.
generally speaking, the best time to go - weather wise - would be january - march; after the monsoon so you avoid the rain and get cooler weather. late january - early februay would be my pick.

column4:
mentioned dates indicate 7nights/8days
i'm sure baratang open now, open travel dates. baratang definitely worth covering limestone caves, scenic route. start early (as early 3am) takes full day. crossing jarawa tribal forest reserve, allowed car.
typical itinerary - modify need!
day 1: arrive port blair, visit cellular jail, samudrika museum, corbyn cove beach sound light show
day 2: baratang northbay & ross jollybuoy+
day 3: ferry havelock, radhanagar beach sunset
day 4: elephant beach water sports - snorkeling, sea walking, scuba diving, evening kalapathar beach
day 5: vijainagar govind nagar beaches free time
day 6: ferry neil, natural beach (guided tour shows lot marine life), lakshmanpur beach sunset,
day 7: sitapur beach sunrise, bharatpur beach glass bottom boat ride, snorkeling water sports, ferry port blair
day 8: depart
edited: 10:57 pm, february 15,
column5:
your mentioned dates indicate it is 7nights/8days
i'm not sure baratang is open now, but it may open around your travel dates. baratang is definitely worth covering not just for the limestone caves, but also the scenic route. you may have to start very early (as early as 3am) and it takes a full day. when you are crossing the jarawa tribal forest reserve, you are not allowed to even get out of the car.
typical itinerary - modify as you need!
day 1: arrive port blair, visit cellular jail, samudrika museum, corbyn cove beach and sound and light show
day 2: baratang or northbay & ross or jollybuoy+
day 3: ferry to havelock, radhanagar beach for sunset
day 4: elephant beach for water sports - snorkeling, sea walking, etc or scuba diving, evening to kalapathar beach
day 5: vijainagar and govind nagar beaches during free time
day 6: ferry to neil, natural beach (guided tour shows lot of marine life), lakshmanpur beach for sunset,
day 7: sitapur beach for sunrise, bharatpur beach for glass bottom boat ride, snorkeling and other water sports, ferry to port blair
day 8: depart
edited: 10:57 pm, february 15, 2021

also,any recommendations on a local tour guide (not looking for package tours)?
thanks in advance

column4:
>> planning visit leh late june/early july <<
this year? unless indian national, hold oci, put planning efforts destination. india suspended tourist visas commercial passenger flights; suspension extended month-by-month basis.
>> idea weather usually time year.should worried monsoons/landslides? <<
that essentially summer ladakh, averages expect cool warm pleasant days. ladakh experience monsoon way rest country does. rain - climate change real, high altitude plateaus.
column5:
>> planning to visit leh late june/early july <<
this year? unless you are an indian national, or hold oci, you should put your planning efforts into another destination. india has suspended all tourist visas and commercial passenger flights; and the suspension is extended on a month-by-month basis.
>> would like to get an idea of what the weather usually is that time of the year.should we be worried about the monsoons/landslides? <<
that is essentially summer in ladakh, and on the averages you should expect cool to warm pleasant days. ladakh does not experience monsoon in the way the rest of the country does. this does not mean it won't rain at all - climate change is real, even for high altitude plateaus.

column4:
notes north east india trip. helpful community members. total 12 days trip. itinerary lists activities useful tips:
dates : 20 dec 2020 - jan 2021
dec 20 - land guwahati
dec 20 - dec 27 -> meghalaya
dec 27 - jan -> arunachal
jan -> assam fly bangalore
bomdilla : cafes here, rooms etc. atms easily available too. well connected everywhere best focal point stay. explore dirang places nearby. lower altitude tawang temperatures warmer. whole town shuts towns arunachal pradesh.
tawang : night temperatures fell -5. town big much tourist attractions except monastry. main attraction going higher border areas.
i wanted cover mechuka time. pretty sure miss post feel free contact mail shivam.agarwal345@gmail.com ping me. instagram hanle - agrwl_shivam
pre-trip preparations:
1. obtain inner line permit enter arunachal pradesh: covid times lot confusion regarding this. seemed reviews online application enough submitted application dec 15 never processed. cannot enter arunachal one.
we lucky travel agency called holiday homes. overcharged got done days.
2. plan crossing states did, times covid certificate valid days need tested again.
- soon entered meghalaya border guwahati show certificate border checkpoint (whole process took hour)
- covid tested meghalaya local hospital (was 300 rs results came spot painful) wanted enter arunachal
3. winter clothing - cannot stress enough.
4. bother much availability arunachal pradesh hostels/b&b's states advance bookings.
5. advance booking cab arunachal (from meghalaya/guwahati upto you) spot prices bad (4 days arunachal 20k us). book big car sumo, jeep etc. trip i20 couple times stuck snow, bad.
we friends meghalaya meghalaya assam part visiting friends family exploring nearby places. recommend miss dawki matter what. cherrapunji disappointment wrong time year see cloud cover etc.
this report mainly focus arunachal pradesh trip we(2 friends + driver) covered days!!
dec 28: shillong bomdilla - 300 kms avg speed 31 km/hr
pumpkin guest house oyo review - stayed shillong days, rooms cheap 1k per night rooms bathrooms reasonably comfy, good location too. however, staff value money seriously here. except warm water, every other
