column5:
here are my notes from north east india trip. hope these are helpful to other community members. we had total 12 days for the trip. itinerary below lists activities and useful tips:
dates : 20 dec 2020 - 2 jan 2021
dec 20 - land at guwahati
dec 20 - dec 27 -> meghalaya
dec 27 - jan 1 -> arunachal
jan 2 -> assam and fly back to bangalore
bomdilla : you get great cafes here, rooms etc. there are atms easily available too. well connected to everywhere and is the best focal point to stay. you can explore dirang and other places nearby. at a lower altitude than tawang so temperatures are warmer. the whole town shuts down at about 6 pm though like in other towns in arunachal pradesh.
tawang : at night temperatures fell to -5. the town itself isn't so big and not much tourist attractions except a monastry. the main attraction is going even higher to the border areas.
i really wanted to cover mechuka too but didn't have time. i am pretty sure i will miss some things in this post so feel free to contact me over mail at shivam.agarwal345@gmail.com or just ping me. instagram hanle - agrwl_shivam
pre-trip preparations:
1. obtain inner line permit to enter arunachal pradesh: this was covid times and there was a lot of confusion regarding this. seemed from reviews that online application is enough but we submitted our application on dec 15 and it was never processed. you cannot enter arunachal without one.
we were lucky to get it from a travel agency called holiday homes. they overcharged but got it done in 2 days.
2. if you plan on crossing states like i did, during these times the covid certificate is only valid for 4 days so you may need to get tested again.
- as soon as we entered meghalaya border from guwahati we had to show a certificate at the border checkpoint (whole process took about an hour)
- we had to again get covid tested in meghalaya local hospital (was like 300 rs and results came on the spot but was very very painful) because we wanted to enter arunachal
3. get winter clothing - cannot stress this enough.
4. don't bother so much about availability in arunachal pradesh in hostels/b&b's but in other states make advance bookings.
5. make advance booking for a cab to arunachal (from meghalaya/guwahati upto you) but on the spot prices are bad (4 days for arunachal was 20k for us). book a big car like a sumo, jeep etc. we did the trip in i20 and a couple of times it was stuck in snow, bad.
we have friends in meghalaya so meghalaya and assam part were just visiting friends and family and exploring nearby places. i will recommend not to miss dawki no matter what. cherrapunji was a disappointment as it was the wrong time of the year to see cloud cover etc.
this report will mainly focus on the arunachal pradesh trip that we(2 friends + driver) covered in 4 days!!
dec 28: shillong to bomdilla - 300 kms at an avg speed of 31 km/hr
pumpkin guest house oyo review - we stayed here in shillong for 3 days, the rooms where cheap some 1k per night for the 2 of us and the rooms and bathrooms are reasonably comfy, good location too. however, the staff take value for money really seriously here. except i think warm water, every other
request was denied by one guy at the reception who manages everything. i think for breakfast he gave me 2 boiled eggs + red tea and said no to bread, omlette and even salt. so don't expect any service.
10 am : leave shillong
2 pm : reached guwahati (where our 4 wheeler car was booked)
3 pm : leave for bomdilla
we covered 300 kms at an average speed of 31 km/hr on this day. we wanted to reach our hostel we booked in bomdilla before midnight but actually we were running way late. plus soon after you leave bhalukpong you gain altitude really fast and the roads start spiralling like crazy and it was sort of 9 pm by the time
we reached bhalukpong, so we were riding very bad terrain in pitch black darkness. but my crazy excitement after entering arunachal was too much (and we had to cover the whole trip in 4 days losing a day wasn't an option) and i kept pushing the driver and we made it to bomdilla by midnight. wouldn't recommend anyone at all to drive that route at night though.
12 pm : 1 km from our hostel we saw that there was a police block. except us like 2 other cars were also stuck. there is apparently some rock cutting going on ahead and roads won't be open till 8 am. there was no warning about this by anyone at all. we did a 180 and started looking for lodging before its too late and only option left
is to sleep in car. we found an amazing place soon although nothing is open by then. the guy gave us proper dinner, a room with heater and comfy bed and blankets and it was all for some 1.5k for the night. this is the most striking feature about arunachal the people are just crazy hospitable. they want
to welcome travellers from their entire heart. we basically stood in front of one of many hotels and it was pitch black no lights and all but we rang the number and someone picked up and did all this for us. i think its a common thing for them, travellers asking for rooms late so they sleep by the phone..by 1 am we had eaten and were asleep.
note: as you enter arunachal there is a very small check that happens where they check if u have ilp.
dec 29: bomdilla to tawang - 170 kms at avg speed of 9.5 km/hr
9 am : breakfast at elegant restaurant. so so cheap and tasty that while returning also we didn't try another restaurant, this one was just perfect.
9 am - 4 pm : this drive from bomdilla to tawang is what the trip is all about. you are driving through beautfil hills with snow capped mountains in the background thinking this is so bful when out of nowhere, a half frozen lake appears. we actually shouted and got out of our car and danced on reaching this lake (at 1 degree celcius) called sela pass .
the beauty of sela pass and the drive both before and after is so bful i will never ever forget it. as you enter tawang there is an army checkpoint where a very detailed check happens. you have to show ilp, verification, covid certificate etc. took 2 hrs at this checkpoint. the army people give you free tea and snacks (like biscuits/samosa etc) and its really something listening to their stories. safe to say my best day of the year 2020 came at the end of the year.
we stayed at dolma khangsar guest house tawang.
dolma khangsar guest house tawang review - very good service, the poeple are very friendly and the rooms shower etc are extremely cozy and well maintained. will recommend it 11/10. the only negative i can think can be the taste of food.
we did a lot of stops in between so we reached this place by about 10 pm.
dec 30: explored tawang, explored the market, visited monastry, pankang teng tso lake - the highest field firing range in the country(4225 m altitude). with the himalayan range in the background, tawang is a must visit. bumla pass was closed for travellers due to border tensions and we missed madhuri lake as we got stuck in the snow once and had to get down and push while coming to p.t.tso and didn't want to risk it going further up. return back to bomdila, stayed at anu's guesthouse
review of anu homestay bomdilla - run by anu, this place is the perfect stop for travellers. cozy rooms and good kitchen services are available, parking is available too. met a lot of fellow backpackers and had an amazing time. it was very cheap as are other places in bomdilla. food was very tasty and cheap too. no complaints.
dec 31: bomdilla to guwahati - 217 kms at 38 km/hr
left bomdilla early morning, reached guwahati by 4 pm. we made sure not to do a road travel at night.
note on the locals : never met more hospitable and welcoming people than arunachal pradesh locals in india. i loved the food there too. they all shut shop at 6 pm, live a simple enough life. they have an appreciation for the beauty that sorrounds them and they want others to experience it too - thats why i will wanna revisit sometime in life.
note on the roads : you can either take tezpur -> bhalukpong -> bomdilla route which we took while coming or the tenga valley -> samteng -> bhairabkunda -> orang route which we took while going back. the roads in the second route is 10 times better than first and i will never repeat the mistake of following the first route. it was a nightmare, there was rocky road and construction every 2 kms and there was km's of strectches of very bad road. plus it was very late at night and dark and you gain altitude very fast in that route too many hairpin bends.
because of the construction on that route, it may be built by the time the reader travels but i highly recommend to take the second route. there was a bit of snowfall on 30th dec night so there was some snow (not a lot) while coming from tawang but still very risky in such narrow roads. driving there without an experienced driver is a strict no.
note on the drinks : if you try local ara, do not take more than 2 shots together :p
overall, my best trip in india so far and would go again in a heartbeat xoxo
column8: North East Itinerary 2 weeks (Tawang, Mechuka, Bumdula)

column4:
leh-pangong tso-leh single day gives little time vehicle. going directly tso´s leh staying overnight outside safety guidelines , worse spent least three nights 3000+ meters ( # ) , medicating advance . option overnighting tangtse ( higher leh , lower pangong tso ) , tso return leh next day.
warm winter far . chaddar trek stopped feb 7th. got message school phey yesterday : last hockey match season. weather forecast shows zero leh tangtse @ 3950 meters coming days - shade , warmer sun.
column5:
leh-pangong tso-leh in a single day gives little time out of the vehicle. going directly to the tso´s from leh and staying overnight is outside safety guidelines , this is even worse if you haven't spent at least like three nights at 3000+ meters ( like in # 1 ) , and are not medicating in advance . one option is to overnighting at tangtse ( higher than leh , lower than pangong tso ) , do the tso and return to leh next day.
warm winter this far . chaddar trek stopped feb 7th. i got a message from the school in phey yesterday : last hockey match of the season. weather forecast shows just above zero in leh and tangtse @ 3950 meters the coming days - in the shade , so even warmer in the sun.

column4:
radhanagar beach famous pristine sands sunset - afternoon - 3pm 5.30 till sunsets enough - felt worth least 4-5 hours (for kid play folks enjoy!) rush!
we skipped scuba seawalking havelock glass boat ride / snorkeling neil (off bharatpur beach) enjoyed both. depends time hand place. scuba - many prefer havelock.
the key deciding factor undersea activity: weather given day high water visibility - suggestion earlier day sunny bright weather devoid clouds, go. wait location - short tight schedule cant again!
if makruzz actual travel time 90 minutes pb - hl. hl-nl nl pb 60+ mins. government ferries much longer. check process complex need report 90-120 minutes earlier depending current regulations - security checks, checking in, verification covid negative report, handing baggage.
collecting baggage arrival 30 mins.- chaotic process.
you book sound light show online - museums guess - checkout available pre-book

water sports booked spot - scuba day earlier preferably
column5:
radhanagar beach is famous for its pristine sands and sunset - an afternoon - say from 3pm to 5.30 pm till the sunsets is enough - though i felt it is worth at least 4-5 hours (for your kid to play and you folks to enjoy!) do not rush!
we skipped scuba and did seawalking in havelock and glass boat ride / snorkeling in neil (off bharatpur beach) and enjoyed both. it depends on the time you have in hand in either place. scuba - many prefer havelock.
the key deciding factor on when to go for undersea activity: the weather on a given day for high under water visibility - my suggestion if an earlier day has sunny bright weather devoid of clouds, go. do not wait for the location - you are on a short tight schedule and you cant do it over again!
if you go by makruzz the actual travel time is about 90 minutes pb - hl. hl-nl and nl to pb should be about 60+ mins. government ferries take much longer. the check in process is more complex now and may need you to report 90-120 minutes earlier depending on the current regulations - security checks, checking in, verification of covid negative report, handing over baggage.
collecting baggage on arrival would take another 30 mins.- it was a chaotic process.
you can book sound and light show online - some museums also i guess - checkout what is available to pre-book

water sports can be booked on the spot - scuba one day earlier preferably
column8: Itinerary for 6D in Andaman and Nicobar

column4:
,
each hotel different way, pick hotel aware hotels different region nubra, sumur hunder. recommendation pick place rather hotel. sumur green general, hunder little "destery" view something cottage feel it. nubra large valley, center market place- none! rather consider nubra...
in case intend visit siachen panamik hot springs stay sumur .. intend explore dunes tur tuk village hunder ideal choice. helps
column5:
hi ,
each hotel is different in its own way, before you pick the hotel hope you are aware that both these hotels are in different region of nubra, one is in sumur and one in hunder. my recommendation would be to pick a place rather than a hotel. sumur is more green in general, hunder is a little more "destery" in my view you should go for something like a cottage for the feel of it. further more nubra is a large valley, by center if you mean a market place- there is none! you should rather consider what you would like to do in nubra...
in case you intend to visit siachen and panamik hot springs you should stay in sumur .. if you intend to explore the dunes and tur tuk village hunder would be an ideal choice. hope this helps

column5:
hi, you can go with creta to most places without any issues abut crossing sela pass could be a challenge. we had no issues with road icing on our way to tawang from bomdila, but on our way back, due to heavy snowfall the roads ware iced up and the creta had difficulty climbing up with the ropes on the rear wheel. remember you can only put chains on the from wheel. and the ropes only go in rear wheels. although due to the army presense you would not need to worry about being stranded there. they'll help you out.
good luck, have a safe journey.

column4:
dave, someone said, people hk beaches - people usually spend days hk spend time dashing place sure see so-called 'must-do's'.
if planning spend 10 days there, see nothing wrong taking day two relax beach beside hotel pool - i've certainly done myself! hong kong covers area 2700 km², there's plenty see 700km coastline find place relax, going next year, got loads time research plan that. decided spend entire 15 days there, spending couple days recovering jetlag beside hotel pool last couple days lazing beach prepare shock going home, sounds good holiday me!
i october best weather - less chance rain earlier year, temperatures mid high 20s.
column5:
hi dave, as someone has already said, most people don't go to hk for the beaches - but then most people don't usually spend more than a few days in hk and they spend all their time dashing around from one place to another to make sure that they see all the so-called 'must-do's'.
if you're planning to spend 10 days or more there, then i see nothing wrong at all with taking a day or two out to relax on a beach or beside a hotel pool - i've certainly done that myself! hong kong covers an area of over 2700 km², so there's plenty to see and do and over 700km of coastline to find a place to relax, but if you aren't going until next year, you've got loads of time to research and plan all that. if you decided to spend your entire 15 days there, then spending the first couple of days recovering from jetlag beside a hotel pool and the last couple of days lazing on a beach to prepare for the shock of going home, sounds like a good holiday to me!
i would say that october probably has the best weather - less chance of rain than earlier in the year, but still temperatures in the mid to high 20s.

column5:
jay
i think my point still stands, many people myself included are caught in the booked and move it on scenario as i explained in my previous post.
those that have booked since mid last year obviously fall into the it will be over by 2021 camp and frankly given numerous overly optimistic statements by boris and his happy band of hopelessly inexperienced sycophants and the tory tabloids it’s hard to pass the blame on to them.
i have a 4 week holiday to malaysia and india booked for february 2022. its been booked since february 2020, is for my 60th and it’s cost more than my first house - the balance was due last week.
to cancel would lose £5k and so i had to pay the balance.
this means that at the moment the travel agent has an interest free loan from me. i have no idea if we will get to go, i strongly suspect not and the refund policy is up to 90 days after the date of commencement of the holiday.
i actually haven’t knowingly booked a holiday since febrauary 2020 but i am caught in the “move it on for six months” trap with three separate flight bookings to cyprus and dubai.
i agree with chrissie - i keep moving them on to keep the travel insurance valid and to maintain original cost of flight.
it’s not all about wilful ignorance
for the op i’d move it to september or even better october because the weather is nicer !

column4:
"my folks senior (beach)"
sorry ... judgement? father nineties enjoyed going beach towns, 'lay beach' kind guy.
beach towns tend breezes help hot summer weather far enjoyable. stroll along beachfront, beats pants stroll car clogged city street. realistically unless require big city amenities (museums, art galleries, big shopping malls), beach communities everything need long stay.
most bigger beach communities substantial expat population along it, home comfort, western stores, foreigner oriented menus such. "local".
but asked hua hin particular, find hua hin modernized western tastes.
column5:
"my folks are too senior for that (beach)"
sorry i have to ask ... did they say that or is that your judgement? my father in his nineties enjoyed going to beach towns, though he wasn't a 'lay on the beach' kind of guy.
beach towns tend to have breezes which help make hot summer weather far more enjoyable. and a stroll along the beachfront, beats the pants off a stroll down a car clogged city street. realistically unless you require big city amenities (museums, art galleries, big shopping malls), beach communities have everything you need for a long stay.
most bigger beach communities here will have a substantial expat population and along with it, a bit of home comfort, western stores, foreigner oriented menus and such. however you can still go "local".
but since you asked about hua hin in particular, i find hua hin to be too modernized and too western for my tastes.

considered swim lagoon pool room anantara?
speaking experience good choice little ones. reason little tired wants afternoon nap/time sun, head room sun bathe terrace dip & lagoon pool whilst little sleeps. put travel cot window you’re close enough see hear them.
our room safety gate well chance little wandering pool unattended.
if height summer it’s unlikely you’ll able spend day pool year old.

column5:
have you considered a swim up lagoon pool room at the anantara?
speaking from experience i think these are good choice with little ones. the reason being is when the little one is tired and wants an afternoon nap/time out of the sun, you can head back to the room and sun bathe on your terrace and dip in & out of the lagoon pool whilst the little one sleeps. you can put the travel cot by the window so you’re close enough to see and hear them.
our room had a safety gate as well so no chance of a little one wandering into the pool unattended.
if not in the height of summer it’s unlikely you’ll be able to spend most of the day by the pool with a 1 year old.
if this isn’t an issue then look at waldorf astoria which is a stunning hotel or caesar’s palace which i’m sure your partner will live.
westin is a good choice as well, it has several kiddies pool within its grounds and the actual kids pool at the westin is large & shaded.
if you can get it within budget al naseem at the madinat is great also.

deira islands far general sightseeing never mind night bad weather day you’re kind stuck nothing within walking distance.
i’d look marina area personally there’s need inclusive ladies nights, promotions appreciate dubai expensive alcohol you’re wanting inclusive look following:
amwaj rotana
sheraton jumeirah
movenpick jbr
habtoor grand
dukes palm
grand hyatt dubai
all offer inclusive extent i’d pick riu dubai.
the three marina area ideal location wise dukes palm grand hyatt ( city) easily located getting whilst you’ll need taxis it’ll much easier cheaper!
there inclusive hotels including le meridian mina seyahi (where barasti located) they’ll lot price wise riu.

column5:
perhaps see if you can change at all. for a 50th birthday you’d be much better staying closer to the action.
deira islands is far out for even general sightseeing never mind a night out and if you have a bad weather day you’re kind of stuck with nothing within walking distance.
i’d look around the marina area personally and there’s no need to be all inclusive with ladies nights, promotions etc but i do appreciate dubai can be expensive for alcohol so if you’re really wanting to go all inclusive then look at the following:
amwaj rotana
sheraton jumeirah
movenpick jbr
habtoor grand
dukes the palm
grand hyatt dubai
all of the above offer all inclusive to some extent and i’d pick any of them over riu dubai.
the first three are around the marina area which is ideal location wise but even dukes on the palm and grand hyatt ( which is in the city) are more easily located for getting about and whilst you’ll need taxis from these it’ll be much easier and cheaper!
there are other all inclusive hotels including le meridian mina seyahi (where barasti is located) however they’ll be a lot more price wise than riu.
the ones i’ve listed are more likely to be comparable and you’ll appreciate their location and accessibility a lot more.
riu might seem like a bargain but you’ll end up spending more on transport and you’ll encounter very lengthy journeys getting about.

column4:
strong position - normally august pretty quiet due summer heat.
i looking hotels world trade centre business bay short stop over. places conrad, towers rotana, rose rayhaan, mar marquis - central gets: souks/dubai mall/burj khalifa metro 45 aed cab airport.
you surprised quality hotel dollars. (creekside) 24 hour blocks don’t look - others, sure, deal. late flight normally check out, leave bags concierge, gym changing rooms shower heading airport.
at.mosphere sunset drinks, fountain, dinner souk al bahar drinks neos @ address.

column5:
you are in a strong position - normally august is pretty quiet due to summer heat.
i would be looking at hotels from world trade centre to business bay for a short stop over. places like the conrad, towers rotana, rose rayhaan, mar marquis - about as central as it gets: souks/dubai mall/burj khalifa and metro and 45 aed in a cab back to the airport.
you will be surprised at the quality of the hotel for your dollars. some (creekside) do 24 hour blocks so don’t over look that - others, i am sure, will do a deal. if i have a late flight i normally check out, leave bags with the concierge, do my thing and then use the gym changing rooms to shower before heading to the airport.
at.mosphere for sunset drinks, then fountain, dinner in souk al bahar maybe then drinks in neos @ address.
taxi to dubai mall area hotel from airport is around 70 - 80 aed including airport surcharge. wouldn’t struggle with luggage onto a metro - especially in august. as lots of resident leave in august, traffic does appear to be lighter.
it will be hot so take care - usual precautions.

column5:
ive not stayed but would consider it for a long break, ive stayed in their thai hotels and the brand is good and it gets good reviews on here.
the usp is the pools as there at lots of them some with direct access from the rooms - they would be the ones i would want.
ghh is lovely but the pool which is small compared to most will fall into the shade at time times in dec so that will mean you will most def have to go each day across to lrm for pool and beach . that may get a bit relentless after a while and lrm is a busy hotel so it could be a challenge getting 6 loungers mid morning together on the beach or at pool. this would not bother me in the warmer months as the pool is fine in the sunnier days but in dubai winter it may become a issue it can be cold and windy because of the tower blocks blocking out the sun . you wont get that at lrm nor anantara. complete contract very different one will be lovely and hot the other could be chilly.
ghh is a lovely hotel but its a grown ups hotel - its not resort styled more biz orientated , its selling points are its large apartments and food , but i think for what you want and the difference in price anantara would be fine , just be prepared to plan days out as its a way down the palm , but many stay on the palm and are not bothered by that at all - atlantis is a fair old trek off as well. the palm has tons more now than it used to, so def things now on the palm to see and do. id try and get the apartment if possible to have pool access.
edited: 7:50 am, january 13, 2021

column4:
>>> waves tend action followed lull, empty period. covid pretty much non stop, flood minor fluctuations level. 'waves' sound cool media. <<<
the reason health professionals media refer "waves" look graph new cases (or deaths, hospitalization), see wave pattern. peaks, followed valleys. case us, valleys following peaks continue higher last valley high peaks, 4th wave many states control rates covid.
column5:
>>> waves tend to be an action followed by a lull, an empty period. but with covid it has been pretty much non stop, like a flood with some minor fluctuations in level. but 'waves' sound cool to media. <<<
the reason that health professionals and the media refer to "waves" is that when you look at graph of new cases (or deaths, or hospitalization), you see a wave like pattern. there are peaks, followed by valleys. in the case of the us, the valleys following the peaks continue to get higher so the last valley was as high as the first 2 peaks, and we are now in a 4th wave with many states having out of control rates of covid.

column4:
official reason given ocean park closure former water world given legco meeting 2013 consider environmental impact new water world;
“the former water world nine outdoor water facilities. appeal local residents undermined given fact swimming facilities hong kong time featured water slides. besides, former water world operated september year, attendance impacted persistently weak overall economic condition time due asian financial crisis 1998. made operation former water world difficult.”
column5:
the official reason given by ocean park for closure of the former water world given to a legco meeting in 2013 to consider the environmental impact of the new water world;
“the former water world had only nine outdoor water facilities. its appeal to the local residents was undermined given the fact that some other swimming facilities in hong kong at that time also featured water slides. besides, the former water world only operated from may to september each year, and its attendance was impacted by the persistently weak overall economic condition at that time due to the asian financial crisis in 1998. these all made the operation of the former water world difficult.”

i cope tourist lived rarely ventured outside! anybody misfortune outdoor parking height summer tell it’s pleasant... steering wheels, seat belts boiling...

column5:
i cannot sit outside for long periods ( unless by the pool) in august but manage fine by the pool and can eat lunch in the shade through the day.
i can also manage to stroll outside in the summer but again not for long periods, 30 mins or so. it’s a subjective question as some folk flat out cannot cope with the heat & humidity in the summer whereas others like me have a high tolerance to humidity.
i actually cope better now as a tourist than i did when i lived there and rarely ventured outside! anybody that has had the misfortune of outdoor parking in the height of summer will tell you it’s not at all pleasant... steering wheels, seat belts etc are absolutely boiling...
if you’re happy to eat indoors in the evening then i think summers in dubai are do-able, hotel prices are reasonable and there’s plenty of western tourists on holiday there.

column4:
dubai last august weather problem all. managed walks (30-45 mins) marina jbr problem. course, tiring, nothing unpleasant.
you forget al fresco dining, many cool bars (the penthouse, level 43) outside terraces open summer grab drink two, weather windy (light, somewhat pleasant breeze common dubai august).
of course, possible evening, day best stick pool indoor attractions (although 10-15 mins strolls day, e.g. dubai fountans, problem us). worth mentioning last year's summer supposedly coldest years, experience representative :d
that said, everyone reacts differently extreme heat difficult you. dubai summer popular destination, given much cheaper everything is, worth shot. worst case end chilling pool magnificent shopping malls time :d
column5:
i was in dubai last august and weather was actually not a problem at all. we managed to have a few walks (30-45 mins) around marina and jbr and it was not a problem. of course, a bit tiring, but nothing unpleasant.
you can forget about al fresco dining, but many cool bars (the penthouse, level 43) have their outside terraces open in summer and you can grab a drink or two, especially when the weather is a bit windy (light, somewhat pleasant breeze is a common thing in dubai in august).
of course, all of this is possible in the evening, because during the day it's best to stick to the pool or indoor attractions (although 10-15 mins strolls during the day, e.g. around dubai fountans, also weren't a problem for us). it's also worth mentioning that last year's summer was supposedly one of the coldest in years, so my experience may not be representative :d
that said, everyone reacts differently to extreme heat so it's difficult to say how will you. dubai in summer is still a very popular destination, and given how much cheaper everything is, i would say it's worth a shot. in worst case you will end up just chilling by the pool or in magnificent shopping malls most of the time :d

column4:
august gone, weeks.
we sat pool day, you’re literally pool every 1/2 hour so, isn’t problem tbh, it’s imperative hotel pool area imo. hot beach sea warm enjoy properly. chance eating outdoors evening. lasted outdoors evening (other desert safari) watching fountain show burj khalifa. straight indoors.
you couldn’t walk 20-30minutes (ish) daytime either.
this didn’t stop holiday, touristy desert safari, jet skis, ferrari world, atlantis water park, malls, burj khalifa, madinat, le perle, etc.
doing break holiday nicely, long days sun toll dubai, holiday destinations august.
would august; could different time.
would that’s time could go; yes.
column5:
we were there august just gone, for 2 weeks.
we sat around the pool during the day, but you’re literally in the pool every 1/2 hour or so, which isn’t a problem tbh, so it’s imperative that your hotel has a great pool area imo. too hot for the beach as the sea is too warm to enjoy properly. absolutely no chance of eating outdoors or an evening. the most we lasted outdoors of an evening (other than at the desert safari) was watching the fountain show at the burj khalifa. then straight back indoors.
you couldn’t walk around more than 20-30minutes (ish) during the daytime either.
this didn’t stop us having a great holiday, we did most of the touristy things such as desert safari, jet skis, ferrari world, atlantis water park, malls, burj khalifa, madinat, le perle, etc.
doing these things break the holiday up nicely, especially as long days in the sun do take their toll in dubai, more than other holiday destinations do in august.
would i go again in august; probably not if i could go a different time.
would i go if that’s the only time i could go; yes.

column4:
want honest opinion i’d ditch tour.
if timer time limited perhaps consider given you’re familiar dubai i’d recommend diy exploration otherwise you’re yr old bored best behaved little start irritated traipsing souks june!
my daughter loved smccu tour including mosque visit opinion right age go, younger boredom set in.
alternatively pricier look hiring private tour half day. dubai tours, arabian adventures them.
sean r often good recommending sort thing. least private driver pace worth paying extra opinion.
column5:
if you want my honest opinion i’d say ditch the tour.
if you were a first timer or your time was limited then perhaps consider it but given you’re familiar with dubai then i’d recommend a diy exploration otherwise you’re 4 yr old will be bored and even the best behaved little one can start to get irritated after traipsing around the souks in june!
my daughter loved the smccu tour including the mosque visit however she was about 8 and in my opinion the right age to go, any younger boredom will have set in.
alternatively although it will be pricier look at hiring a private tour for half a day. dubai tours, arabian adventures etc they all do them.
sean r often is good at recommending this sort of thing. at least with a private driver you go at your own pace and will be worth paying the extra in my opinion.

column4:
notice replies, like-minded, enjoy knocking city's nook & crannies, 'too long' possible. others, agree sort of, nights enough see 'iconic' sites, along market temple 3.
if living london, relative, big mango. visits, hated it, thought nothing giant slum. although, stay lower suk, explore much. used squeaky clean western hygiene (appearance / smells (lack sewer), easily put off.
now, many visits (100+) seen all, krung thep metro huge, love arriving. short week, love leaving .... 🤣🤣🤣
being weekend pros & cons, festive & open, crowded. enjoy knocking & exploring city's non touristy side, love it.
but .... coming big city, so, wanting beach time, want prioritize visit, big city feeling found home. coming uk, beach, thai's crappy ones along warm weather relief, hear & read.🤣
my thai beach experience 20+ years ago, phuket, got thinking retiring thailand. trip recon retirement. 2nd beach holiday pp, sealed idea.
hindsight, thailand opens 'normal' tourism, pp priority, slow starting again, turns tourist ghetto, i'd prioritize visit c19 there. save extensive exploration big mango later visit, changes there, revamping areas already, quite nicely.
about revisit pp myself, 2022, looking lovely tourist.
good "museums/galleries" .... suck here.
edited: 7:23 pm, january 16,
column5:
i notice the replies, some are like-minded, and enjoy knocking around the city's nook & crannies, and 'too long' isn't possible. others, and agree sort of, 3 or 4 nights is more than enough to see the 'iconic' sites, along with a market and or temple or 3.
if living in london, relative, you may or may not like the big mango. i know my first few visits, i hated it, and thought it nothing more than a giant slum. although, i did stay on lower suk, and didn't explore much. if used to squeaky clean western hygiene (appearance / smells (lack of sewer), then you can easily be put off.
now, after so many visits (100+) and still haven't seen it all, as krung thep metro is huge, i love arriving. and after a short week, i love leaving .... 🤣🤣🤣
being there on weekend has its pros & cons, more festive & more things open, but crowded. if you enjoy just knocking around & exploring a city's non touristy side, you'll love it.
but .... since coming from a big city, if so, and wanting beach time, you may want to prioritize that on first visit, as big city feeling can be found at home. especially coming from uk, as any beach, even thai's crappy ones along with warm weather would be a relief, from what i hear & read.🤣
my first thai beach experience was 20+ years ago, phuket, and got me on thinking about retiring in thailand. trip was actually a recon for retirement. 2nd beach holiday was pp, and sealed the idea.
hindsight, and when thailand opens to 'normal' tourism, i think pp would be my priority, as slow starting up again, before it turns back into a tourist ghetto, i think i'd prioritize my first visit after c19 there. save extensive exploration of the big mango for a later visit, as any changes there, will be for the better as they are revamping some areas already, and quite nicely.
about to revisit pp myself, before 2022, as looking lovely without tourist.
good thing not into "museums/galleries" .... they really suck here.
edited: 7:23 pm, january 16, 2021

column5: would love to hear more about diving in fujairah. we have 5 days in dubai. we are a diving family and plan to dive at crescent moon island one day, and hopefully at the dubai aquarium. debating whether during our short trip an excursion to fujairah would be worth it or not.

column4: hi, fujairah nice spot, quite easy to. hour three quarters drive dibba, lot diving happens, seems. need overnight don’t want to, picked 3:30 pm. lot people, haven’t able dive year, refresher course day palm jumeirah nemo’s. we’re pretty experienced divers, 32 dives over, big deal, told visibility poor dubai right. incredibly cloudy tons sediment water, saw (kinda) arabian (asfur) angelfish right beach duke’s went completing refresher tasks. fujairah nice dive, two dives dibba rock artificial reef, nitrox, (or geezer gas), me. saw lots morays, clownfish/anemones, turtles, trunkfish, triggers, pipefish, asfur angels, pretty nudibranchs, lots healthy coral. water pretty cool, wore 3mm wetsuit kind chilly, cold easily. worthwhile dives, imho. love diving places gulf oman red sea endemic species don’t see anywhere else...i dive i’d dive aquarium mall, sure.
column5: hi, fujairah was a really nice spot, and quite easy to get to. it was only about an hour and three quarters drive to dibba, which is where a lot of the diving happens, it seems. no need to overnight if you don’t want to, we were picked up about 7 am and were back by about 3:30 pm. like a lot or maybe most people, we haven’t been able to dive in over a year, so we did a refresher course the first day off palm jumeirah with nemo’s. we’re pretty experienced divers, 32 dives all over, so no big deal, but they told us the visibility was poor off dubai and they were right. incredibly cloudy and tons of sediment in the water, but we still saw (kinda) a few arabian (asfur) angelfish right off the beach at duke’s when we went around after completing our refresher tasks. fujairah was a really nice dive, we did two dives at dibba rock and artificial reef, they also had nitrox, (or geezer gas), for me. we saw lots of morays, clownfish/anemones, turtles, trunkfish, triggers, pipefish, more asfur angels, some pretty nudibranchs, lots of healthy coral. but the water was pretty cool, i wore a 3mm wetsuit and was kind of chilly, but i get cold easily. very worthwhile dives, imho. i love diving in places like the gulf of oman or red sea where there are endemic species you don’t see anywhere else...i would dive there before i’d dive in the aquarium in the mall, for sure.

column4: honestly don’t know, didn’t see much shallow reef area diving boat 15m it’s kind apples oranges. want inquire nemo (or operator) whether shallow water snorkeling so, don’t way fujairah it...
column5: honestly i don’t know, i didn’t see much shallow reef area but we were diving from a boat at 15m so it’s kind of apples and oranges. you may want to inquire with nemo (or another operator) as to whether there is shallow water snorkeling and if so, maybe you don’t have to go all the way to fujairah to do it...

column4: spending days dubai two 15 year olds. scuba divers incorporate diving trips. heard good crescent moon island, internet research given much info. scuba shade newer dive shop day trips seems organized, two dives/ day. arabian diver overnight trip, hard time getting details it. sure want overnight trip- sound kind exciting. stay tents- ridiculously hot tents may? appeal arabian divers included deep sea fishing along diving, family enjoy activities. welcome recommendations divers experience visiting crescent moon island! tia!
column5: we will be spending 5 days in dubai and have two 15 year olds. we are all scuba divers and like to incorporate some diving on our trips. i have heard good things about crescent moon island, but my internet research has not given me much info. scuba shade is a newer dive shop and does day trips and seems very organized, with two dives/ day. arabian diver does an overnight trip, but i have been having a hard time getting details about it. not sure if we want an overnight trip- but does sound kind of exciting. you stay in tents- would we be ridiculously hot in tents in may? the appeal of arabian divers is that it included deep sea fishing along with diving, and i think my family would enjoy both activities. i welcome recommendations from any divers or anyone with experience visiting crescent moon island! tia!

column4:
marina area stay hotel nice.
it’s pool area disappointing due shade lot, don’t plan sunbathe prefer away summer heat, suit though.
it’s worth noting summer low season it’s possible book top hotel good price.
have good shop consider want hotel, wouldn’t book based price.

edited: 11:52 am, april 24,
column5:
the marina is a great area to stay and the hotel is very nice.
it’s pool area is a bit disappointing due to being in the shade a lot, if you don’t plan to sunbathe or prefer to get away from summer heat, it might suit you though.
it’s worth noting that summer is low season so it’s possible to book a top hotel for a good price.
have a good shop about and consider what it is you want out of a hotel, i wouldn’t just book it based on price.
how do you plan to get about? the summer months are very hot & humid so it’s worth factoring in it you plan to get the metro, as it’s a bit of a walk from the but the tram stop is nearby .
edited: 11:52 am, april 24, 2021

column4: honestly, emirates. visit dubai comfortable convenient. son flies a380 jfk-dxb yesterday 11 hours depending weather traffic. relax, sleep, eat worrying getting navigating airports reach dubai. watch tv plane dubai whet appetite.
column5: honestly, i would go with emirates. if this is your first visit to dubai then i think this would be the most comfortable and convenient. my son flies the a380 and did jfk-dxb yesterday and it is only just over 11 hours depending on weather and traffic. you can relax, sleep, eat without worrying about getting off and navigating other airports until you reach dubai. you can even watch some tv on the plane about dubai to whet your appetite.

column4: went backpacking solo europe early twenties. took train kazakhstan russia, russia plane spain spain trains france, portugal way kazakhstan made stop italy. spent months traveling alone, drugging belongings. met tons kind people/strangers helped along journey. didn’t speak languages english people amazing helping buying tickets, ordering meal, etc. learnt lot life myself. invaluable investment myself. live america.
column5: i went backpacking solo in europe when i was my early twenties. i took a train from kazakhstan to russia, from russia a plane to spain and from spain trains to france, portugal and on my way back to kazakhstan made a stop in italy. i spent 2 months traveling alone, drugging my belongings. met tons of kind people/strangers who helped me along the journey. i didn’t speak the languages other than english and people were amazing helping me with buying tickets, ordering meal, etc. learnt a lot about life and myself. it was a great invaluable investment in myself. i now live in america.

column4: hola audrey, soy adrián, los veo desde hace tiempo muy lindo contenido. lo veo tu padre daniel en sus contadas  de vida dijo del paso de su familia ( ustedes ) por las sierras de córdoba, cerca de villa berna (creo). de hecho allí mostraron cuando fueron  merendar la domanda (café). les cuento que el 16 de este mes nevo mucho para zona, lo que es habitual esa cantidad, ayer 26/06/21 nevo otro poco. por supuesto que se compara con la cantidad de nieve que ustedes acostumbran en el norte, pero fue una muy linda experiencia para disfrutar en familia, mi esposa natalia  mis hijos antonella, marcos carolina. agrego, que vivimos actualmente en villa rumipal, 11 km al sur de santa rosa de calamuchita, siempre que podemos recorremos todos los lugares tan bonitos que tenemos. te envío algunas fotos de villa berna nevado, con mi familia.
column5: hola audrey, soy adrián, los veo desde hace tiempo y muy lindo contenido. lo veo a tu padre daniel y en sus contadas  de vida dijo del paso de su familia ( ustedes ) por las sierras de córdoba, cerca de villa berna (creo). de hecho allí mostraron cuando fueron a  merendar a la domanda (café). les cuento que el 16 de este mes nevo mucho para zona, lo que no es habitual esa cantidad, y ayer 26/06/21 nevo otro poco. por supuesto que no se compara con la cantidad de nieve que ustedes acostumbran en el norte, pero fue una muy linda experiencia para disfrutar en familia, mi esposa natalia y  mis hijos antonella, marcos y carolina. agrego, que vivimos actualmente en villa rumipal, a 11 km al sur de santa rosa de calamuchita, y siempre que podemos recorremos todos los lugares tan bonitos que tenemos. te envío algunas fotos de villa berna nevado, con mi familia.

column4:
wife loves swim difficult getting cold (only time ever swum open sea phuket 35 degree weather :) normally ever heated jacuzzis, untill stayed waldorf amsterdam indoor pool kept 30-32 making perfect wife. unfortunately month queen stayed waldorf berlin didnt pool warm meant wife stayed jacuzzi usual. question... january/feb mild dubai understand many places heat pools guess heat soupy temperature wife looking wrong? alternatively places heated indoor pools? prefer staying hilton property diamond gold ihg, open place pool could live wife's requirements :)

column5:
so my wife loves to swim but she is really difficult about getting cold (only time she has ever swum in open sea was in phuket in 35 degree weather :) so normally we only ever use heated jacuzzis, untill we stayed at the waldorf in amsterdam where the indoor pool is kept at 30-32 making it perfect for my wife. unfortunately the month after queen we stayed at the waldorf in berlin they didnt have the pool as warm which meant my wife stayed with the jacuzzi as usual. so my question... with january/feb being mild for dubai i understand many places heat their pools but i would guess they might not heat them to the soupy temperature me and my wife is looking for or am i wrong? alternatively are there any places with heated indoor pools? i would prefer staying at a hilton property as i am diamond but i also have gold with ihg, and am open to any other place if they have a pool that could live up to my wife's requirements :)
looking forward to hearing from you all hope you are staying safe!
column8: 30-32 degree pools indoor or outdoor January/February?

column5:
if you’ve been to dubai before then you’ll be aware of the standard of driving.... if you feel comfortable then go for it, i drove in dubai for years but i no longer do as the ever changing roads just give me a headache.
my husband drives now when we are there but he does find it stressful at times.
also be mindful if you go anywhere with outdoor parking, getting into a boiling hot car in the summer in dubai that’s been standing a few hours is no fun. touching the seatbelts and steering wheel even less so!!!
i understand your concern re safety as i’m quite paranoid when it comes to covid & germs in general but i think dubai rta has quite stringent measures in place re hygiene. i’m unsure if there’s still a maximum number of passengers allowed, if so then you might need two taxis but if you’re sitting in the back with a face mask on and sanitising your hands after touching seat belts, doors etc i think you’d feel okay but it’s obviously a personal choice.
in all honesty if & when i get to travel anywhere this year i plan to do little in terms of sightseeing and avoid crowds, transport as much as i can but there’s the obvious hurdle of the flight & airport...
edited: 7:02 am, april 25, 2021

column4:
"is worth paying 148 floor burj khalifa. move needle experience?"
maybe people. i've dubai numerous times desire there, matter floor. seems least pre-covid people hang block views getting earlier help. i'm like, pay view people going view? course perfect day, see much nothing due weather conditions.
i'm sure "dubai museum/fort" list places go, say, good perspective past current dubai. dirham went times. basically street al ustad. provided complimentary tour arrived time. tours going on, follow small group around. tour guides work dubai government tourists office. worth visit ripleys type setting.
column5:
"is it worth paying to go to the 148 floor in the burj khalifa. does it move the needle on the experience?"
maybe for some people. i've been to dubai numerous times and still have no desire to go up there, no matter what floor. it seems at least pre-covid people would just hang up there and block the views and getting there earlier didn't help. i'm like, why pay for a view and people are going to be all in my view? and of course you have to go on the perfect day, or you'll see much of nothing due to the weather conditions.
i'm not sure if you have the "dubai museum/fort" on your list of places to go, but i can say, it will give you a good perspective of past and current dubai. it was only one dirham when i went both times. it's basically down the street from al ustad. i was provided a complimentary tour when i arrived the one time. if they have any tours going on, you can just follow the small group around. the tour guides work for the dubai government tourists office. that might be more worth than the visit than a ripleys type setting.

column4: coming perfect time side thailand narrow much. travelled extensively mainland cannot help that. samui much smaller phuket main sites easily covered day neat temples views. beaches lovely could two centre koh phangan / koh tao (diving / snorkelling) holiday. given interest kayaking phang nga bay stunning lots options island hop trips water available phuket krabi. leave local expert due easier access islands imho views pick beach krabi.
column5: you are coming at the perfect time for either side of thailand so that doesn't narrow things down much. i haven't travelled extensively on the mainland so cannot help with that. samui is much smaller than phuket and the main sites are easily covered in a day with some neat temples and views. the beaches are lovely and you could two centre with koh phangan and / or koh tao (diving / snorkelling) which would be a great holiday. given your interest in kayaking phang nga bay is stunning with lots of options to island hop and trips on the water available from phuket or krabi. i will leave it to a local expert but i think due to the easier access to islands and imho better views i would pick a beach in krabi.

column5:
>>any recommendations on good skiing (mid/advanced skiers)?
for those levels, consider kagura/naeba instead, about 20 and 50 min respectively by express bus uphill from echigo-yuzawa station, which is served by joetsu shinkansen from tokyo in about 80 min direct.
have skied/stayed there 4 to 5 times. plenty of good runs for those ski levels, apart from great powder from jan.
gala - not enough runs. besides, plenty of beginners at the base where accidents occur. you might finish in half day - similarly in karuizawa.
search on snowjapan.com for more details.

column4:
normally bus tours reason mentioned, exception kushiro. rural area, infrequent bus service, travelling independently public transportation result seeing fewer places took bus tour. winter weather harsh could miserable wait hour bus stop. english signage limited bus stops. least tour bus, people case difficulties cold directions.
note ticket office akan bus inside superhotel building adjacent kushiro train station. took find ticket office assumed separate bus station building.
column5:
i normally don't like bus tours for the same reason you mentioned, but i would make an exception in kushiro. it's a rural area, with infrequent bus service, and travelling independently on public transportation would result in seeing fewer places than if you took a bus tour. winter weather is harsh and you could be miserable if you had to wait an hour at a bus stop. english signage may be limited at bus stops. at least with a tour bus, there will be other people with you in case you have any difficulties with the cold or with directions.
note that the ticket office for akan bus is inside the superhotel building adjacent to the kushiro train station. it took me a while to find the ticket office because i assumed it would be in a separate bus station building.

column5:
#8, it is very true. look at hertz car rental. the major mistake it made (according to news reports) was that it did not borrow a large sum of money at the beginning of the pandemic to weather the storm, and was not able to make scheduled loan repayments during the pandemic when the traffic virtually stopped. so it had to file for bankruptcy. it is coming out of bankruptcy now with the same name, but all old equity shareholders were wiped out.
large companies have larger financial obligations and larger losses. united airlines was losing $6 million a day.

column4:
>> spring blossoms amazing, quite gamble timelines (booking honeymoon weeks advance adventurous
indeed, normal years usually reserve kyoto hotels least months advance, sakura blossoms. option stay osaka commute kyoto daily hour. however, later book higher hotel rates (when cheaper rooms snatched up) possibly less convenient locations.
rain non-issue sakura koyo season. general, rainy days cannot ruled season. however, seasons due passing frontal rain resulting drizzles location days that's it. occasional heavy downpours rainy season late june mid july passing/landing typhoons.
column5:
>> spring blossoms would be amazing, its quite a gamble with timelines (booking our honeymoon 2 weeks in advance may be more adventurous
indeed, in normal years i usually reserve kyoto hotels at least 5 months in advance, especially for sakura blossoms. another option is to stay in osaka and commute to kyoto daily in about 1 hour. however, the later you book the higher the hotel rates (when cheaper rooms have been snatched up) and possibly in less convenient locations.
rain is a non-issue in either the sakura or koyo season. in general, rainy days cannot be ruled out in any season. however, in those 2 seasons it's due to passing frontal rain resulting in drizzles in a location for at most 2 to 3 days and that's it. it won't be like occasional heavy downpours during the rainy season in late june to mid july or during passing/landing typhoons.

column4:
difficult build entire itinerary repeating places. quick thoughts weeks assuming fly in/out tokyo:
1-3 tokyo settle, rid jet lag, perhaps day trip kamakura/enoshima kawaguchiko
4-9 fly regional airport eastern hokkaido train way sapporo snow festival. see thread hokkaido ideas
10-15 fly osaka. osaka kyoto base days. day trip option 1) okayama + kurashiki; 2) koyasan (can overnight trip); 3) himeji + kobe; 4) kinosaki onsen (best overnight trip), stop amanohashidate way back; 5) nara (if visited previously). 15, train takayama late afternoon (maximize daylight hours) arrive evening.
16 takayama + shin-hotaka ropeway
17 shirakawago morning, kanazawa afternoon stay overnight there
18 kanazawa full day, train tokyo later evening
19-21 tokyo, toss nikko day trip chill tokyo
edited: 10:35 pm, 25,
column5:
it's difficult to build an entire itinerary without repeating some places. quick thoughts for 3 weeks assuming you have to fly in/out of tokyo:
1-3 tokyo to settle, get rid of jet lag, perhaps take a day trip to kamakura/enoshima or kawaguchiko
4-9 fly to a regional airport to eastern hokkaido and train your way down to sapporo for snow festival. see your other thread for hokkaido ideas
10-15 fly to osaka. use either osaka or kyoto as your base for a few days. day trip option 1) okayama + kurashiki; 2) koyasan (can be an overnight trip); 3) himeji + kobe; 4) kinosaki onsen (best as an overnight trip), can stop at amanohashidate on way back; 5) nara (if you haven't visited previously). on 15, take train to takayama in the late afternoon (maximize daylight hours) to arrive in the evening.
16 takayama + shin-hotaka ropeway
17 shirakawago morning, kanazawa afternoon and stay overnight there
18 kanazawa full day, train to tokyo later in the evening
19-21 tokyo, toss in a nikko day trip if you like or just chill at tokyo
edited: 10:35 pm, may 25, 2021

column5:
hi,
my husband and i are planning to join a group tour to japan, hopefully in 2022. their first group trip is in mid- may and their last trip is in mid-october. which would you recommend based on weather? we don't care for heat and humidity, so we were originally leaning towards october. but then i read that it rains more in october and the days are shorter, so we are now leaning towards may- mainly because the days are longer. but i'm worried it will be too hot and humid for us. any suggestions or feedback? right now it feels like a toss up.
thank you for your help!

column4: visited japan october ten years row, mainly going tokyo, osaka kyoto mainly good weather temperatures 70sf. unlike uk rain japan usually comes heavy spells wet day misleading impression stats.

column8: Honshu winter itinerary & Japanese Alps questions

column4:
mind butting here, op, frequent visitor part alps area (actually coming home 8days ago there) let say: roughly speaking, 3days overcast/snowy winter months. chances able soak alpine feel shin hotaka offer. yes, weather cooperates, reward awaits, mesmerizing views silvery tall peaks unfolded eyes. hate this, said bus trip much first-timer doesn't. note is, city matsumoto 1hour train ride away nagano, city (matsumoto) authentic japanese castle (called black crow castle) welcomes visitors, exquisitely crafted old interiors together exhibits samurai swords armors sure draw attention. yes, photo opportunity too: couple young guys clad samurai armors put pic inner entrance. views mainkeep nice, boot. clear day see far mt yari (not mention stately mt jonen/otensho/tsubakuro/cho, names beauties/tall peaks northern japanese alps). agree, matsuden tram matsumoto head shinshimashima rail. yes, here, switch nohi bus takes hirayu (1hr, take), onsen town nestled part alps half-way point matsumoto-takayama corridor. along way huge river gorge scenic dams dotted around. hirayu-takayama 1hr ride, (though fleeting seconds) chance *ohh-ing ahh-ing* looking awesome tall jagged ridgeline snow-blanketed hotaka mountains. yes, bus hirayu shin hotaka (30min so), backtrack takayama. view-wise only, matsumoto-takayama wins handsdown, compared takayama-s'go-kanazawa. yes, depends weather.
happy planning!
column5:
hope you don't mind me butting in here, op, but as a frequent visitor to this part of the alps area (actually coming home 8days ago from there) let me say: roughly speaking, 2 out of 3days are overcast/snowy for the winter months. so chances are you may not be able to soak in the great alpine feel that shin hotaka has to offer. yes, when the weather cooperates, a great reward awaits, where mesmerizing views of the silvery tall peaks get unfolded before your eyes. hate to say this, but the said bus trip doesn't mean much for a first-timer when it doesn't. yet one thing to note is, city of matsumoto is about 1hour train ride away from nagano, in which city (matsumoto) an authentic japanese castle (called black crow castle) welcomes visitors, where exquisitely crafted old interiors together with exhibits like samurai swords and armors sure draw their attention. yes, a photo opportunity too: a couple of young guys clad in samurai armors like to put you in a pic with either of them at the inner entrance. views from the mainkeep are nice, to boot. on a clear day you can see as far as mt yari (not to mention stately mt jonen/otensho/tsubakuro/cho, names of the beauties/tall peaks of the northern japanese alps). should you agree, i suggest you take matsuden tram from matsumoto so you head to shinshimashima by rail. yes, from here, you switch to a nohi bus and it takes you to hirayu (1hr, give or take), an onsen town nestled in this part of the alps and a half-way point on the matsumoto-takayama corridor. along your way is a huge river gorge with scenic dams dotted around. hirayu-takayama is also a 1hr ride, where (though fleeting seconds) you have a chance to be *ohh-ing and ahh-ing* looking at the awesome tall jagged ridgeline of the snow-blanketed hotaka mountains. yes, you can bus it from hirayu to shin hotaka (30min or so), then backtrack and off you go to takayama. view-wise only, matsumoto-takayama wins handsdown, compared to takayama-s'go-kanazawa. yes, all depends on weather.
happy planning!
column8: Honshu winter itinerary & Japanese Alps questions

column4:
matilda, glad gave positive twist itinerary. case sure, matsumoto pretty straight forward jr kofu: 1hour-plus train (ltd express) ride away, take. matsumoto-nagano. see images matsumoto castle flickr click takes fancy pops large: 
looks enticing, no? views top kind. castle japan afford visitors good mountain views, imo. said last post, see faraway/back peak mt yari (japanese matterhorn).
btw, right assume (splurging little bit) overnight stay onsen ryokan? type accommodation galore hirayu! enjoy skiing wish (almost stone's-throw away). bus station, beautiful snow-blanketed mt kasa mt norikuras look inviting weather permitting. allowed, i'd suggesting venture (wintertime) kamikochi highland capture gorgeous scene 3winters row recent past... that'd thread talk with, sorry.
roads icier hirayu takayama (particularly approaching raised big curve huge cliff couple minutes departing hirayu takayama, 9000feet peaks loom/tower ahead right-hand side) shinshimashima hirayu. never seen/heard road accidents winter (when everyone's sticking safe drive), leg road getting closed snow. said last post, need ride (in case: possible aversion buses) tram matsumoto reach shinshimashima. interesting ride first-timers, reckon, catch japanese local scenes flesh (views plus people, brings smile face see apple-red-cheek kids commuting). tram station shinshimashima small, large parkng lot adjacent though. feel came boonies/back o' beyond. yes, there's cafe right outside station (signpost saying *kamikochi curry* specialty), i've never seen open, oh veggie/fruit shop across road it. and, view-wise, something write home about, sadly. yes, inside small complex wooden bench- vending machines-equipped waiting room, oh nice western-style restroom. 2summers ago, stinky mountain hut's (sorry true), provided *toto washlets* talking niceties requires thread. ;) (yes, sure ones hotels come. remember first-timer getting panicky bathroom wanting help ta years back.) got dumbfounded went see spick'n span men's room time! looked pretty much brand new ones used ease 9days ago today. station staff must taking mighty good care them, gather.
with said above, shinkanse ride nagano kanazawa godsend hokuriku-goers tokyo/nagano. far combination tram bus rides creature-comfort, matilda. yes, decide direction.
again happy planning!
column5:
matilda, am glad if i gave a positive twist to your itinerary. in case you're not sure, matsumoto is pretty straight forward to get to if you take jr from kofu: 1hour-plus train (ltd express) ride away, give or take. so is matsumoto-nagano. see images of matsumoto castle on flickr and give a click to one that takes your fancy so it pops out large: 
looks enticing, no? views from the top is one of a kind. no other castle in japan can afford visitors with as good mountain views, imo. as i said in my last post, you can see as faraway/back as the peak of mt yari (japanese matterhorn).
btw, am i right to assume you are ok (splurging a little bit) for an overnight stay in an onsen ryokan? that type of accommodation galore in hirayu! you can enjoy skiing there too if you wish (almost a stone's-throw away). from the bus station, beautiful snow-blanketed mt kasa and mt norikuras look inviting weather permitting. if allowed, i'd go on suggesting you venture out to (wintertime) kamikochi highland so you capture a gorgeous scene like i did 3winters in a row in the recent past... but that'd take another thread to talk over with, sorry.
roads are icier between hirayu and takayama (particularly so when you're approaching a raised big curve over a huge cliff a couple minutes after departing from hirayu for takayama, where 9000feet peaks loom/tower ahead on your right-hand side) than between shinshimashima and hirayu. but i have never seen/heard about any road accidents around here during winter (when everyone's sticking with safe drive), nor any leg of the road getting closed because of snow. as i said in my last post, you need to ride (in your case: possible aversion to buses) a tram from matsumoto so that you can reach shinshimashima. an interesting ride for first-timers, i reckon, if they like to catch japanese local scenes in the flesh (views plus people, brings a smile on my face when i see apple-red-cheek kids commuting). a tram station like shinshimashima is very small, with a large parkng lot adjacent to it though. so you may feel as if you came to boonies/back o' beyond. yes, there's a cafe right outside the station (signpost saying *kamikochi curry* is their specialty), but i've never seen it open, oh and a veggie/fruit shop across the road from it. and, view-wise, it's not something to write home about, sadly. yes, inside the small complex is a wooden bench- and vending machines-equipped waiting room, oh and a very nice western-style restroom. up until 2summers ago, theirs was as stinky as mountain hut's (sorry but true), but then provided with *toto washlets* talking about the niceties of them requires another thread. ;) (yes, you sure will use ones at your hotels when you come. i remember a first-timer getting panicky in his bathroom and wanting help here on ta years back.) i got dumbfounded when i went in to see the spick'n span men's room at that time! they still looked like pretty much of brand new ones even when i used to ease myself 9days ago from today. the station staff must have been taking mighty good care of them, i gather.
with all of that said above, the shinkanse ride from nagano to kanazawa is a godsend to hokuriku-goers if from tokyo/nagano. it's far better than a combination of tram and bus rides when you think of your creature-comfort, matilda. yes, it's up to you to decide on either direction.
again happy planning!

column5:
kamikochi - for great views from taisho-ike, visiting on clear days is far more important than arriving at 5am. wife and i had visited once in may on a rainy day when the distant mountains are partially shrouded in clouds/mists.
besides, overnight bus is not for everyone - don't expect a good sleep and thus likely being tired the whole day after.
as long as you visit in the morning hours on a clear and calm day, it'd be spectacular.
feature photo of kamikochi from taisho-ike at 8am, during my last stay in oct 2017.

same taken at around 10am in oct 2010.

ps. wife and i had visited kamikochi 5 times.

column5:
>>our budget per night is approx 22,000 yen
if you mean hotel room rate only that's on the low side. search for local business/budget hotels in japan such as toyoko inn. budget hotels roughly charge from jpy10k per adult per room.
beware that august is the hottest month in japan. expect hot and humid weather in tokyo/kyoto/osaka.
snow monkey may or may not soak in onsen in summer. however, the park rangers provide incentives to those monkeys to do so, as i've watched on local tv travel programs.

column4:
assuming staying tokyo, consider karuizawa yuzawa onsen town ski resorts accessed day trips tokyo via frequent shinkansen direct hour+, non-skiers sightseeing kamakura/enoshima day trips.
for advanced skiers, consider hakuba days. skiing almost annually 2014, ski trip hakuba last feb cancelled due pandemic.
due global warming, snow prime conditions late dec 2015 roughly.
check snowjapan.com archived snow reports.
niseko - recommended except advanced skiers. lodgings dining way expensive others, apart flying domestic sapporo/cts case. hv skied times.
edited: 1:42 am, february 21,
column5:
assuming you'd be staying in tokyo, consider either karuizawa or yuzawa onsen town where ski resorts can be accessed as day trips from tokyo via frequent shinkansen direct in about 1 hour+, while non-skiers may go for sightseeing in kamakura/enoshima as day trips.
for advanced skiers, consider hakuba for a few days. i have been skiing there almost annually since 2014, though my ski trip to hakuba in last feb was cancelled due to the pandemic.
due to global warming, snow have not been in prime conditions in late dec since 2015 roughly.
check out snowjapan.com for archived snow reports.
niseko - not recommended except for advanced skiers. lodgings and dining are way more expensive than others, apart from flying domestic to sapporo/cts in your case. hv skied there 4 times.
edited: 1:42 am, february 21, 2021

column5:
how many days will you have? if you opt for hokkaido (such as niseko), and you want to ski for a few days, you will need to allow at least a week to 10 days up there.
if you are going to fly into tokyo, then go with dli's and shot's advice above. timing is especially important. in recent years, snow accumulation at the slopes had been arriving late. to ensure good snow condition, the best time to go ski is likely going to be after christmas.

column4:
drive unless ample driving experience snowy/icy roads. noboribetsu, toyako served public transports. driven 30 times japan, never driven ski trips.
asahikawa 2nd largest city hokkaido. jr express trains serve b/w sapporo asahikawa roughly per hour 6am+.
>>for day trip sapporo asahikawa, you’ll need check train schedules yourself. train 11am.
column5:
don't drive unless you have ample driving experience on snowy/icy roads. noboribetsu, toyako are served by public transports. have driven over 30 times in japan, but have never driven on ski trips.
asahikawa is the 2nd largest city in hokkaido. jr express trains serve b/w sapporo and asahikawa roughly once per hour from 6am+.
>>for your day trip from sapporo to asahikawa, you’ll need to check the train schedules yourself. the first train is at 11am.

column5:
christmas/new year on phu quoc gets you nice weather and nice enough beaches. central vietnam isn't at its best at that time of year.
high season though, so you'll need to book at least a little ahead of time, but i'd not advise that for a good while since i'm increasingly sceptical about just when travel will be possible. i'd hang off until it's at least possible to get visas or visa waivers/exemptions again and independent travel travel is allowed.

column4:
slightest idea weather particular week future year. taken four cruises british isles loved all, ship 800 passengers 400 crew, want bigger ship. cruise june weather bad day couple got orkney refused reboard, made way home. woman slipped wet deck broke leg, watching raf airlift highlight day.
the rest 10 day cruise lovely weather.
column5:
no one can give you the slightest idea of the weather for a particular week in a future year. i have taken four cruises around the british isles and loved them all, but in a ship with 800 passengers and 400 crew, i wouldn't want to be on a bigger ship. one cruise in june the weather was so bad on the first day that one couple got off at orkney and refused to reboard, they made their own way home. one woman slipped over on the wet deck and broke a leg, watching the raf airlift her off was the highlight of the day.
the rest of the 10 day cruise was in lovely weather.

column5:
my daughter wanted to visit scotland. so we left on a sat am and went to e'burgh for the night. left sun afternoon. arrived and departed from waverly.
so the feeling, in only my opinion, is very piccadilly circus/las vegas/times square if you stay on/near princes street. if you like that vibe, you're in luck. shopping, day-drinking (i am 100% not judging as i have enjoyed day-drinking myself), loud acoustical-guitar music, etc.
for boring people like me, i would suggest staying either way further back in the old town section or the new town section. and keep in mind that the balmoral and the waldorf are pc/lv/ts in terms of their locations even though they are expensive.
it was pouring rain most of our visit, but the little bit of rural scotland we saw from the train reminded me of maine. not shocking since the the mountains that end at the coast of maine pick up in scotland. pretty much the same geological thumbprint very roughly speaking (my background is in geology). really lovely.
the castle was booked up our weekend, so we went to the holyrood palace. very calm, not touristy, very pleasant. there was a watercolor exhibit at the queen's gallery next door that we also enjoyed. additionally, we liked the national scottish gallery. it had a nice gift shop and cafe, as well.
we decided that we've been to edinburgh twice: the first time and the last time. we would use e'burgh as a launching spot for a more rural, wilderness visit. but that's just us. apparently, i have rubbed off on my daughter and despite her college antics and interests, she seems to prefer quiet and calm and historical as opposed to shopping and a festival scene; don't assume all people under 25 will love edinburgh.
it was very easy to get to edinburgh from london. the train ride has great vistas if you sit on the coastal side. we booked 1st class for the return trip and it was fun. free sandwiches, chips, wine, sodas, etc. lots of sheep out the window. i saw a small group of deer laying in.a field. very picturesque.

column4:
princes street yesterday sunny, unlike day melissa came, doubt people wasn’t busy. struggling understand comparison time square piccadilly circus. don’t see it. aren’t illuminated billboards where.admittedly big departments stores fallen victim covid permanently, looking sad.
the side street balmoral hotel, sir walter scott monument. gardens floral clock, art gallery clear view bank scotland ho mound, 1100 hundred year old castle 600 year old houses beside - heck historic?
i unfair judge city brief day trip london.
if she’s ventured water leith walkway, she’s thought countryside. missed beautiful royal botanic gardens national museum scotland (with excellent exhibitions galloway hoarde).any old town screams history - avoiding it.
each suppose.
column5:
i was on princes street yesterday and it was sunny, unlike the day melissa came, so no doubt more people about but it really wasn’t that busy. i really am struggling to understand the comparison to time square and piccadilly circus. i just don’t see it. there aren’t any illuminated billboards any where.admittedly with 3 of our big departments stores having fallen victim to covid permanently, it is looking a bit sad.
the other side of the street with the balmoral hotel, sir walter scott monument. the gardens and floral clock, the art gallery and the clear view of the bank of scotland ho on the mound, the 1100 hundred year old castle and 600 year old houses beside it - how the heck is this not historic?
i also think it unfair to judge a city on a brief day trip from london.
if she’s ventured on the water of leith walkway, she’s have thought herself in the countryside. she missed the beautiful royal botanic gardens and the national museum of scotland (with some excellent exhibitions on now like the galloway hoarde).any where in the old town screams of our history - there is no avoiding it.
each to their own i suppose.

column4:
i’ve used luffield can’t help but..
you’ll find spend lot time watching race big screens (or ipad) well what’s front decent view screen important - silverstone pancake flat seeing across circuit near impossible). high won’t achieve much viewing puts action, win it’s raining you’ll drier it’s blazing sun there’s shade - doubt matters i’d want dozen rows front cover weather extremes.
a f1 race relatively long event there’s natural ‘half time’ drivers parade end toll bladders folk race (or lot of) beers (and quite them). sit end row you’ll jumping let visit facilities monotonous regularity, sit middle struggle call nature. choice!
ot, want watch motor race rather ‘be there’ brands hatch offers viewing experience.
column5:
i’ve not used luffield so can’t help there but..
you’ll find you spend a lot of time watching the race on the big screens (or your ipad) as well as what’s in front of you so a decent view of a screen is important - silverstone is pancake flat so seeing across the circuit is near impossible). high up won’t achieve much more viewing and puts you i bit further from the action, the win is that if it’s raining you’ll be drier and if it’s blazing sun there’s some shade - i doubt it matters but i’d want to be a dozen rows back from the front to cover weather extremes.
a f1 race is a relatively long event and there’s no natural ‘half time’ so from drivers parade to the end will take its toll on the bladders of the folk who go to the race with a few (or a lot of) beers (and there will be quite a few of them). if you sit at the end of a row you’ll be jumping up to let them visit the facilities with monotonous regularity, if you sit in the middle it will be a struggle if you get the call of nature. your choice!
ot, but if you want to watch a motor race rather than just ‘be there’ brands hatch offers a better viewing experience.
