column4:
visit london often trip brighton. need full day welcome change.
the royal pavilion well worth visit worth checking currently display. weather depending, pleasant walks along beach, along pier direction marina. lanes offers number small shops, interesting quirky, north laine must.
the journey pleasant, tend thameslink st pancras rather southern victoria. little hour trains generally quiet, weekend. found lay trains many carriages needed guaranteed find quiet relatively empty space.
it's relatively short walk hill station main part town. buses desirable way hill depending weather exhausting day been..
whatever decide do, enjoy!
edited: 5:19 am, yesterday
column5:
when we visit london we often take a trip to brighton. you really need a full day but it might be a welcome change.
the royal pavilion is well worth a visit and it is worth checking what is currently on display. weather depending, there are some pleasant walks along the beach, along the pier and in the direction of the marina. the lanes offers a number of small shops, for the more interesting and quirky, then the north laine is a must.
the journey is pleasant, we tend to take the thameslink from st pancras rather than southern from victoria. it's a little over an hour and the trains are generally quiet, even over a weekend. we have found that they lay on trains with many more carriages than needed so you're guaranteed to find a quiet and relatively empty space.
it's a relatively short walk down the hill from the station to the main part of town. there are buses which may be desirable on the way back up the hill depending on the weather and how exhausting the day has been..
whatever you decide to do, enjoy!
edited: 5:19 am, yesterday

column5:
4 day trips from fort william - plenty of choice!
i'd look at glencoe and glen etive for one (the latter glen used in skyfall filming as it happens) - look at going up the chairlift on a decent weather day; a short walk from there takes you to a magnificent viewpoint over all, including the top of ben nevis if clear.
some photos from it: 
if a chairlift doesn't appeal you can also go up the gondola at nevis range and there is a walk you can do from there too.it's a good view but to me doesn't match in character what you get from glencoe.
drive down glen etive as far as you wish; it's a beautiful glen though in summer, quite busy with informal campers.
i would always recommend as part of that day, a drive round the kinlochleven loop - views are stunning and it's missed out by so many people hurtling up the a82.the lochleven seafood cafe is very good.the little glencoe cafe in the village isn't in the most scenic location but it does nice food/cakes. that said there's probably no better location for food with a view than the kingshouse hotel up near the ski centre. haven't eaten there yet though.
if gentle strolls are the thing, the glencoe lochan fits the bill; uphill, there is a waterfall walk (when rivers have got higher again!) at kinlochleven.
getting out to arisaig and the camusdarach beaches makes for a good day out and you could carry on and see something of skye by nipping over on the ferry to armadale (book well in advance.)even seeing some of south skye/sleat (perhaps lunch at the hotel eilean iarmain hotel/bar) would be well worth it.views are fantastic.
you could also go over on the corran ferry to see something of ardnamurchan, a beautiful peninsula, perhaps going just as far as salen. the kilcamb lodge hotel is a gem and does good food but there are other options out there. if you cut through to acharacle, a walk to castle tioram is lovely and easy too.
you can also do that loop, with more driving, as part of a longer day that takes in camusdarach.
arisaig is also where the shearwater boat goes over to eigg as a day trip - beautiful island, well worth seeing.bikes for hire and a little bus used to take people to the gorgeous singing sands - but check first.
check out the route description for the steall falls walk to ensure it's ok for you - it is a bit rocky in places underfoot above a steep gorge though most people i'm sure find it ok in dry weather. it takes you to a nice spot.
further north is urquhart castle which gets a pounding on the forum but i like it - if you can get there early to beat the rush hour so to speak. it's in a great spot.loch ness isn't our most beautiful loch but it's nicest end is at fort augustus which is a nice wee place in itself with good views.various lunch options there or look at popping in to the glengarry castle hotel.pricey for lunch but does good tea and cakes in a gorgeous setting.
starters for 10

column5: as said above, you won't be able to take any luggage for the hold if you're on day trip tickets, also, if the weather is bad they, (steamship company) sometimes cancel day trip tickets, so you wouldn't get there at all. accommodation is limited (as it's a small place) and first dibs usually goes to whoever has booked it for this year. that said it really is worth a trip over, but maybe for a few more days than just one night. have you tried longstone lodge or any b&b's, although they may have a minimum stay in the summer.

column5:
hello folks.
covid allowing etc (fingers and toes very tightly crossed!) i'm planning a trip to harris on may with my partner baby and three year old. we are wondering about which route to take - ferry from oban stopping for two nights in barra then across the uists, or ferry from mallaig to the uists, or driving up through skye to the uig harris crossing spending a night or two in skye. we'll already have done a lot of driving and i think we'll all love the ferries, though i do fear the prospect of sea sick kids if weather is bad. we've been to skye before (loved it!) but not the outer hebrides.
any thoughts on which would be the most enjoyable route to take?

column5:
avoid summer if you would like to see mount fuji like the pictures you see.
it is the climbing season without snow caps.
the biggest point of hakone is owakudani valley like yellowstone.

about touristic, both are. just hakone has longer history as resorts.
two railway companies, odakyu and seibu are involved with hakone, while kawaguchiko area is for fujikyu.
if you would like to enjoy a better view of mount fuji, lake kawaguchiko is the place to visit.
if you would like to see dynamic owakudani valley, go for hakone.

column4:
shot-sensei,
wow. dangling dslr camera skiing last i'd ever contemplate. salute !!
looks fun - snow looks great.
have never skiied norikura kogen, slalom run looks tempting - apart onsen 1400m.
shiga kogen - shots northern jp alps range distance. skied 2013 terakoya, ichinose pistes fav.
hakuba happo-one - stayed hakuba tokyu hotel jan 2018 wife joined (not skiing though). year snow showering 50cm daily mountains hardly visible days stayed. next time i'd look kashima-yari, jiigatake (on clear days) taking topmost ski lift.
thanks sharing :)
column5:
shot-sensei,
wow. dangling a dslr camera while skiing is the last thing i'd ever contemplate. salute !!
looks like you had great fun - snow looks great.
have never skiied in norikura kogen, though the slalom run there looks tempting - apart from its onsen up on 1400m.
shiga kogen - great shots of the northern jp alps range in the distance. skied once only in 2013 and terakoya, ichinose pistes were some of our fav.
hakuba happo-one - also stayed in hakuba tokyu hotel once in jan 2018 when my wife joined (not skiing though). in that year snow was like showering 50cm daily and the mountains were hardly visible for the few days we stayed. next time i'd also look for kashima-yari, jiigatake (on clear days) when taking the topmost ski lift.
thanks for sharing :)

column5:

the monster looks to me like what we see out our back windows: giant hemlock trees heavily laden with new fallen snow. fortunately for our trees the snow doesn't stay on the branches too long or it would result in them being permanently deformed, or worse - they might break from the weight of the wet snow.
thanks again for sharing your photo and your ski trip.

column5:
dli, they way i looked around, no one was carrying a dslr camera, except one who was by the lower end of the protection net that ran parallel with the g slalom course; yet, he wasn’t wearing his ski boards. this was hitting home to me: a smaller and lighter mirror-less (yet on a high-end side) dslr should be your best friend in a situation like that. how can you manage, (with both hands occupied, and that one for a *pricy* item,) the narrow and steep bumpy path (that’s left for competition rooters) along the said net, except doing this poor trick: slow propeller-turns? ; )
btw, for onsen accommodation, takamagahara comes to my mind (ichinose’s next-door neighbor yet actually connected with each other). you may like to see this: 
onsen waters, if they tried to dig them out in the ground, would perhaps be found in oku shiga, so says their japanese homepage, but they don’t because of the protection of their natural environment.


and another hotel in oku shiga, which is a ***** one:

column4: folks. fortunate enough travel japan november. opportunity travel early july 2022 family. intent visit areas tokyo, kyoto, kanazawa, takayama, kiso valley. read rainy season hot rainy around. it’s clear bad is. example hawaii rain every day it’s small amount night. weren’t reading reports never know. - general question - continue plan visit early july scrap fall spring trip time. thanks much opinions!
column5: hi folks. i have been fortunate enough to travel in japan in may and november. i have an opportunity to travel there again in early july 2022 with family. my intent would be to visit the areas of tokyo, kyoto, kanazawa, takayama, and the kiso valley. from what i have read this is rainy season so hot and rainy all around. but it’s not clear to me how bad that is. for example in hawaii it can rain every day but it’s a small amount at night. if you weren’t reading the reports you would never know. so - my general question - should i continue to plan to visit during early july or scrap it for a fall or spring trip another time. thanks very much for your opinions!

column4: normally, early july, see rain everyday days days. course, happens weather system, could see rain time. otherwise, could pure sunny days. temperatures high good dose humidity likelihood. visitor, tend walk lot that's summers miserable heat.
column5: normally, by early july, you shouldn't see rain everyday for days and days. of course, if there happens to be a weather system, you could see rain all the time. otherwise, there could also be pure sunny days. temperatures will be high with a good dose of humidity in all likelihood. as a visitor, you tend to have to walk around a lot so that's why summers can be miserable if you don't like the heat.

column4:
driving fuji five lakes region fine. done twice spring fall, slightly traffic went autumn foliage. planned well, mid april good time kawaguchiko enjoy cherry blossom well beautiful pink moss. kawaguchiko holding annual sakura festival time frame, weather permitting course.
agree it’s drop matsuyama takamatsu time. many interesting places mainland honshu worth going couple days. cherry blossom main objective consider spending time osaka kyoto. average year time visit season many beautiful sakura sites osaka kyoto. took spring visit kansai region 2019. let interested elaborate more.
another place often neglected nagoya transport hub train travel. highly worthwhile side trip spectacular illumination event flower park nabana-no-sato easy evening excursion staying night nagoya.
column5:
driving in the fuji five lakes region is fine. we had done it twice once in spring and once during fall, just slightly more traffic when we went for autumn foliage. you have planned it well, mid april is a very good time for kawaguchiko as you can enjoy cherry blossom as well as beautiful pink moss. kawaguchiko is holding its annual sakura festival during that time frame, weather permitting of course.
agree it’s better to drop matsuyama and takamatsu this time. there are many interesting places in mainland honshu that are worth going for a couple of days. if cherry blossom is a main objective consider spending more time in osaka and kyoto. in average year your time of visit is in season and there are many beautiful sakura sites in and around osaka and kyoto. we took in some during our spring visit to the kansai region in 2019. do let me know if you are interested and i can elaborate a bit more.
another place often neglected is nagoya which to most is just a transport hub for train travel. a highly worthwhile side trip is the spectacular illumination event in the flower park of nabana-no-sato which is an easy evening excursion if you are staying a night in nagoya.

column5:
my boyfriend and i booked flights on a whim... and then started researching and feel like we are totally overwhelmed (we don’t know much about japan but can’t wait to go!)
where do i begin? i got some guidebooks, but there is so much info on them that covers the entire country... i feel like i should nail down the regions were visiting before i start researching because otherwise there’s just too much information.
we are flying into osaka in early november, and out of sapporo in mid/late november (15 days total). we are willing to rent a car or take a train or take take flights between some of the locations… we want to see some cultural sights (temples, etc), eat great food, go hiking, visit an onsen or two, ride bikes around town, etc (not a huge fan of museums but might be willing to do one or two if they are can’t-miss). mostly just love to see (and eat) amazing things.
we love to mix it up too. city/country, luxe hotel/bnb/family-stay/camping, planned guided tours/spur-of-the-moment.
hoping to hit up the south/west when it might still be somewhat warm and see some fall colors, then head north/east (who knows if it will be snowing by then, which could be cool).
we usually like to spend at least three days in a location, so we could probably hit up four regions?
i don’t even know 100% that the trip will happen because of covid - of course it will all depend on what state the world (and japan) is it at the time. i am hopeful though.
would love any ideas of regions to visit, how long to stay there, how to get from one place to another, and any other tips!
thank you so much for your insight.
column8: 15 days in Japan in November. Osaka to Sapporo.

column4:
1st-timers consider golden route - tokyo/kyoto/hiroshima. 15 days, add days jp alps drop fuji 5-lake nature, onsen koyo (fall foliage). highly efficient public transports.
if air ticket cancelled, depart tokyo drop sapporo. hokkaido best visited thru' oct free snow urban areas.
in general, local hotels open booking months advance.
given pandemic, there's harm research hold booking coming aug/sept. japan slow rolling vaccines public. monitor constant updates.

refer japan-guide.com research, including suggested itin.
column5:
for 1st-timers consider the golden route - tokyo/kyoto/hiroshima. with about 15 days, add a few days in the jp alps and drop by fuji 5-lake for nature, onsen and koyo (fall foliage). use highly efficient public transports.
if your air ticket can be cancelled, better depart from tokyo and drop sapporo. hokkaido is best visited in may thru' oct when it's free of snow in urban areas.
in general, local hotels are open for booking about 3 to 6 months in advance.
given the pandemic, there's no harm doing research now but hold back booking until coming aug/sept. japan is slow in rolling out vaccines to the public. monitor this with constant updates.

refer to japan-guide.com for research, including suggested itin.
column8: 15 days in Japan in November. Osaka to Sapporo.

column4:
i'm sapporo fan, winter, agree flight plan. 15 days add much plan, i'd avoid tokyo area, leaving trip.
arriving osaka spend least week there, day trips nara, kyoto (at least days here) hikone himeji (to visit original castle), fly sapporo visit otaru, toya lake (with night onsen hotel/ryokan), hakodate. november experience koyo kansai snow hokkaido, that's wonderful think.
column5:
i'm a sapporo fan, above all during winter, so i agree with your flight plan. but in 15 days i wouldn't add too much to my plan, so i'd avoid tokyo area, leaving it for another trip.
arriving in osaka you should spend at least one week there, with day trips to nara, kyoto (at least 3 days here) and hikone or himeji (to visit an original castle), then fly to sapporo and visit otaru, toya lake (with a night in an onsen hotel/ryokan), hakodate. in november you can both experience koyo in kansai and snow in hokkaido, that's wonderful i think.
column8: 15 days in Japan in November. Osaka to Sapporo.

column4:
visit japan, it'd odd skip tokyo - akin skipping london opt edinburgh uk instead upon 1st visit.
there nice onsens jp alps okuhida. prime time visit fuji 5-lake mid-nov koyo peak. onsen stay perfect.
if desperate snow, head murodo @2400m along alpine route (w/o heading way hokkaido) snow nov, transport service suspended due severe weather conditions.

my koyo visit fuji 5-lake nov 2016.

ps. visited hokkaido 15 times, including times skiing only.
edited: 10:55 pm, 24,
column5:
if this is your first visit in japan, it'd be odd to skip tokyo - a bit akin to skipping london but opt for edinburgh in uk instead upon 1st visit.
there are some nice onsens in the jp alps such as okuhida. it's also prime time to visit fuji 5-lake in mid-nov when koyo is at peak. an onsen stay there would be perfect.
if you're so desperate for snow, head to murodo @2400m along the alpine route (w/o heading all the way to hokkaido) for first snow in nov, though transport service there might be suspended due to severe weather conditions.

my koyo visit in fuji 5-lake in nov 2016.

ps. have visited hokkaido about 15 times, including 5 times for skiing only.
edited: 10:55 pm, may 24, 2021

column4:
comments relate miyako, iwate prefecture. (there miyako island end japan okinawa.)
i chance see rock formations jodogahama beach stay miyako. best view sightseeing boat. town suffered greatly 2011 earthquake resulting tsunami.
from 2016 brochure jodogahama beach sightseeing boat:
"due 3.11 earthquake occurred march 11, 2011, lost two three ships. fortunately, however, enjoy cruising last you! appreciate warm support. enjoy beauty strength nature surrounding jodogahama beach, never lost disaster."
column5:
my comments below relate to miyako, iwate prefecture. (there is also a miyako island at the other end of japan in okinawa.)
i hope you had a chance to see the rock formations at jodogahama beach during your stay in miyako. the best view is from the sightseeing boat. the town suffered greatly from the 2011 earthquake and the resulting tsunami.
from a 2016 brochure for the jodogahama beach sightseeing boat:
"due to the 3.11 earthquake occurred in march 11, 2011, we lost two of three ships. fortunately, however, we can enjoy cruising on the last one with you! we really appreciate your warm support. please enjoy the beauty and the strength of the nature surrounding jodogahama beach, which was never lost even in the disaster."

column5:
this conversation reminded me...
rikuzentakata is one of the towns that was hard hit by the tsunami. a project is underway to plant 17,000 cherry trees at the high-water mark so future generations will remember, and so they will know how high they must go when the next tsunami comes. so far, they're 10% of the way to their target, with no progress during the year of covid.
there's a map of their progress at the bottom of this page:

column8: Sapporo Snow Festival? Worth checking out?

column4:
little cold, snow ice sculptures, festival worth couple days. several winter festivals sapporo area time.

some little challenging sapporo. otaru easiest short walk train station festival sites. asahikawa runs frequent shuttle buses train station festival site.
column5:
it can get a little cold, but if you like snow and ice sculptures, it is a great festival and worth a couple of days. there are also several other winter festivals in the sapporo area around the same time.

some are a little more challenging to get to from sapporo. otaru is the easiest as it is a short walk from the train station to the festival sites. asahikawa runs frequent shuttle buses from the train station to the festival site.
column8: Sapporo Snow Festival? Worth checking out?

column4:
sapporo + snow festival + otaru = roughly days. interested whisky, head yoichi's
nikka distillery. day trip overnight onsen trip, look noboribetsu. depending conditions, able visit parts hell valley. north, addition cranes, abashiri prison offers interesting visit. asahiyama zoo excellent.
it very, cold likelihood. lived michigan years visited snow festival, felt getting hit multiple alberta clippers. walk 15 minutes find place duck inside break.
column5:
sapporo + snow festival + otaru = roughly 3 days. if you are interested in whisky, you can also head to yoichi's
nikka distillery. for a day trip or an overnight onsen trip, look into noboribetsu. depending on conditions, you might be able to visit parts of hell valley. further north, in addition to cranes, abashiri has a prison that offers an interesting visit. asahiyama zoo is excellent.
it will be very, very cold in all likelihood. i lived in michigan for years but when i visited the snow festival, it felt like we were getting hit by multiple alberta clippers. we would walk around for 15 minutes and then have to find a place to duck inside to take a break.
column8: Sapporo Snow Festival? Worth checking out?

column5:
for my daughter’s graduation trip, we will be spending 2 weeks in japan. the trip will be in may or june of 2023, provided everything gets back to some semblance of normal by then. given the things she wishes to do and things we want to do as a family, here is our itinerary so far. we understand that we may not be able to do everything, but will try to do our most wanted things.
day 1 arrive in tokyo- late afternoon, shibuya crossing and plan to stay at shibuya excel hotel tokyu while in tokyo.
day 2 in tokyo- harley davidson, ghibli museum, tokyo metro government building, robot restaurant
day3 in tokyo- kamishinmeitenso shrine, shiba daijingū shrine, koami-jinja shrine, takagi shrine, sensoji temple, kawaii monster café, nintendo tokyo
day 4 in tokyo- gundam base and statue, teamlab borderless, akihabara
day 5 will take a day trip to nasu hot springs to see sesshoseki, then back to tokyo for the night
day 6 in hakone- stay the night at a traditional ryokan. ryokan hakone ginyu is first on our list because of the private onsen.
day 7 in hakone- gora park, ōwakudani, lake ashi, torii gate and hakone shrine, moto hakone sightseeing cruise hoping to get a good view of mt fuji somewhere. will try to stay at the prince hakone ashinoko
day 8 on to nagoya- atsuta jingu shrine, harley davidson
day 9 from nagoya- hojyuin temple (bảo thọ viện) then on to -kyoto- hozoji temple, international manga museum, samurai kembu show at gion hatanaka. will try to stay at tokyu stay kyoto shinkyogoku-dori, because i believe it to be a good base location.
day 10 in kyoto- fushimi-inari-taisha, shōren-in monzeki temple & teahouse, chion-in temple, kōdaiji temple, kiyomizu-dera temple, ponto-cho alley for dinner
day 11 in kyoto- tea ceremony koto, myoshinji temple, harley davidson, nishiki market
day 12 to tokyo for meiji jingu shrine, yoyogi park, pokémon center mega tokyo
day 13 airport for departure
we will be using shinkansen as much as possible but will need a lot of local trains, buses and subways in each city. we are thinking of adding an extra day in tokyo to fit in everything we wish to do.
a) will the jr rail pass, tokyo metro 72 hour pass be beneficial and save us money? i also see that kyoto offers a similar bus and subway pass.
b) as we wish to do goshuin, how do we know the times and days, shrines and temples are open? any shrine or temple recommendations will be appreciated.
c) on day 7- any better recommendation for hotel with a good view of mt fuji, assuming the weather is cooperating. we wish to stay in the lake ashinoko area?
d) we like collecting harley davidson poker chips, does anyone know if the harley davidson shops in japan sell them? if not we will be settling for shirts.

column4:
>>a) jr rail pass, tokyo metro 72 hour pass beneficial save money? see kyoto offers similar bus subway pass.
if leave japan osaka kansai airport, need jr pass all. passes pay well.
except traveling round trip tokyo - nikko/nasushiobara, save little jr tokyo wide pass  save include ride narita airport - tokyo ltd. exp. narita express tokyo - kawaguchiko ltd. exp. fuji excursion within 3-day window.
>>b) wish goshuin, times days, shrines temples open? shrine temple recommendations appreciated.
shrines temples usually closing day. opening time available official sites.
for day 5, worth spending whole day nasu visiting sesshoseki. temples shrines + nature stuffs, nikko bundle attractions.
btw, understand goshuin "the prove sincere worship", collection rare stamps. :)
>>c) day 7- recommendation hotel good view mt fuji, assuming weather cooperating. wish stay lake ashinoko area?
if want view mt fuji room, look kawaguchiko, hakone. visiting kawaguchiko stay night there, explore hakone next day instead.
also, quite number ryokans hakone kawaguchiko offer private hot springs (in room private bath house) limit choice two. jalan  filter ryokans.
column5:
>>a) will the jr rail pass, tokyo metro 72 hour pass be beneficial and save us money? i also see that kyoto offers a similar bus and subway pass.
if you can leave japan from osaka kansai airport, then you do not need a jr pass at all. most of the passes does not pay off as well.
except if you are traveling round trip tokyo - nikko/nasushiobara, then you can save a little bit with jr tokyo wide pass  you can save more if you can include the ride narita airport - tokyo on ltd. exp. narita express or tokyo - kawaguchiko on ltd. exp. fuji excursion within the 3-day window.
>>b) as we wish to do goshuin, how do we know the times and days, shrines and temples are open? any shrine or temple recommendations will be appreciated.
shrines and temples are usually do not have closing day. opening time are available on their official sites.
for day 5, i don't think it is worth spending a whole day to nasu just visiting sesshoseki. if you like temples and shrines + nature stuffs, i think nikko can give you a better bundle of attractions.
btw, hope you understand that goshuin is "the prove of your sincere worship", not the collection of rare stamps. :)
>>c) on day 7- any better recommendation for hotel with a good view of mt fuji, assuming the weather is cooperating. we wish to stay in the lake ashinoko area?
if you want a better view of mt fuji from room, where you should look for is kawaguchiko, not hakone. so i would suggest you visiting kawaguchiko and stay 1 night there, and explore hakone on the next day instead.
also, there are quite a number of ryokans in hakone and kawaguchiko do offer private hot springs (in room one or private bath house) so you don't have to limit your choice to just one or two. you can use jalan  to filter those ryokans.

column5:
i am not sure if other people in tokyo have seen this beginning in their own areas, but yesterday there was a "team" of workers out for most of the day plastering the walkways around my local station with dozens of "tokyo 2020" banners. this is in addition to the flags/banners that have been on streetlights/poles for the last year. will it drive enthusiasm or resentment?
given the state of emergency, it might have been better to be plastering the place with "coivd2019" banners with a health message instead. there are a lot of facilities and stores closed (not just because of golden week).
btw:
apparently the eu approved the export of more than 50 million vaccine doses to japan this year, yet few have actually been administered and the claims of supply bottlenecks is looking shaky.
and:
the city of chiba have refused a request to set up a testing facility for the surfing competition because it does not have the resources. with daily testing and limits of movement/transport, it seems the infrastructure the olympics is hoping to use is pushing back.

column5:
welcome guerino,
sorry to be getting to the thread so late in the discussion. i too recommend staying at least a night at kawaguchiko, if for no other reason than you have a better chance for clear skies if you have 2 rather than 1 day.
chureito pagoda is fine if the weather be clear, otherwise don't bother. also rather than taking the stairs as dli_hk says, you can walk up the road for vehicles which we found to be much easier than the stairs.
whatever you do, be sure to check one of the live cams before heading out - and even then things can get cloudy fast:


and we recommend the momiji tunnel more than the momiji corridor for spectacular views (and photo ops) of fuji in a “tunnel view” through koyo (or sakura)
see this article -

if you want further info on getting to the momiji tunnel, just ask i’d be happy to help.

column4:
oreo-x, looks itinerary; i'm sure enjoy places currently planning visit. going detail specific suggestions, let interests (temples, culture, food, nature/hiking, people watching, etc.) well budget? help narrow bit. instance, kyoto's top sights clustered area. ton awesome areas walkable, bunch places require buses, trains taxis.... time efficiently, going taxi route advisable (full) day kyoto itinerary.
for hiroshima, i'd recommend stay miyajima (aka itsukushima) stay somewhere landside that's far ferry terminal. want spend fully day there; magical. gets evenings well early morning, utterly devoid hordes daytrippers. way, main torii gate completely covered due renovation, amazing place visit.
on way kanazawa takayama, strongly swing shirakawa-go (gokayama); gorgeous winter months snow envelops gassho-style thatched roof houses there.
the i'd spend fully day nara. kyoto amazing, many ways enjoyed nara more. i'm talking deer park (to me, that's waste time unless kids enjoy interacting animals.) historic sights completely different look, feel historical significance compared kyoto's main attractions - highly encourage check out!
column5:
hi oreo-x, that looks like a great itinerary; i'm sure you'll enjoy the places that you're currently planning to visit. before going into detail on specific suggestions, can you let us know your interests (temples, culture, food, nature/hiking, people watching, etc.) as well as your budget? that will help narrow things down a bit. for instance, kyoto's top sights are not clustered in one area. there are a ton of awesome areas that are walkable, but a bunch of places require buses, trains or taxis.... and to really use your time most efficiently, going the taxi route really is advisable for a 3 (full) day kyoto itinerary.
for hiroshima, i'd recommend you either stay in miyajima (aka itsukushima) or stay somewhere landside that's not far from the ferry terminal. you really want to spend a fully day there; it's magical. and it gets better in the evenings as well as early morning, when it's utterly devoid of the hordes of daytrippers. by the way, even though the main torii gate is completely covered up due to renovation, it's still an amazing place to visit.
on the way from kanazawa to takayama, i strongly suggest you swing by shirakawa-go (gokayama); it's especially gorgeous in the winter months when snow envelops the gassho-style thatched roof houses there.
the only other thing i'd suggest would be to spend a fully day in nara. while kyoto is amazing, in many ways we enjoyed nara even more. and i'm not talking about the deer park (to me, that's a waste of time unless your kids enjoy interacting with animals.) the historic sights are completely different in look, feel and historical significance compared to kyoto's main attractions - i highly encourage you check it out!
column8: First trip to Japan - advice on 2.5 weeks itinerary

column4:
overall itin looks fine well planned.
better drop shirakawa-go hours travelling enroute takayama nohi bus. village covered snow feb, offering serene tone.
nara - day trip osaka kyoto suffice - served frequent commuter trains less hour.
both nikko hakone top day trip destinations tokyo. latter natural scenery museums spread mountains. apart those, consider kamakura/enoshima closer sea.
koyasan likely covered snow 1000m. overnight stay temples, beware arrive earlier vegetarian dinner usually served early. served 6pm. note rooms bathroom/toilet shared. issue, book toilet did. costs more, good value money.
>>we want stay least night ryokan onsen eat kaiseki.
along itin, consider hakone returning tokyo. hakone 200+ ryokans spread mountains. usually recommend lake ashi mt fuji viewed clear days.
column5:
overall your itin looks fine and well planned.
better drop by shirakawa-go for a few hours while travelling enroute to takayama by nohi bus. the village should be covered in snow in feb, offering a more serene tone.
nara - a day trip from either osaka or kyoto would suffice - served by frequent commuter trains in less than 1 hour.
both nikko and hakone are top day trip destinations from tokyo. the latter is more for natural scenery and some museums spread out in the mountains. apart from those, consider also kamakura/enoshima closer to the sea.
koyasan would likely be covered in snow at 1000m. for an overnight stay in temples, beware to arrive earlier as vegetarian dinner is usually served early. ours was served before 6pm. also note that most rooms do not have own bathroom/toilet and have to be shared. if this is an issue, book one with own toilet as we did. though it costs more, it's good value for money.
>>we want to stay at least one night in a ryokan with an onsen and eat a kaiseki.
along your itin, consider hakone before returning to tokyo. hakone has more than 200+ ryokans spread out in the mountains. i usually recommend those around lake ashi where mt fuji can be viewed on clear days.

column4:
definitely overnight hakone want hot springs (which purpose going hakone). hard cut time...maybe less day explore city kyoto?
also, mention overnight koyasan. plan stay temple, it’s wonderful experience hard kids. temple different hotels/ryokan. rooms rice paper walls (could hear others’ quiet conversations), low heat (wore thermals yukata), private baths (the shower open room multiple shower heads along wall, separated sex shower room women separate men). also, (optional) activities (fire ceremony, meditation) required silence sitting still. kids handle this, definitely temple stay!
and fire ceremony monks offer guests participate - it! monks you’re part ceremony, observer. signals bad character decline activity (paying respects dead ancestors). whatever reason, pressured everyone participate.
column5:
i would definitely do an overnight in hakone if you want to do hot springs (which for us was the purpose of going to hakone). hard to say where to cut time...maybe one less day to explore the city of kyoto?
also, you mention an overnight in koyasan. if you plan to stay at a temple, it’s a wonderful experience though may be hard on kids. our temple was very different from hotels/ryokan. the rooms had rice paper walls (could hear others’ quiet conversations), low heat (wore thermals under our yukata), and no private baths (the shower was an open room with multiple shower heads along the wall, separated by sex though so one shower room for women and a separate one for men). also, the (optional) activities (fire ceremony, meditation) required silence and sitting still. if your kids can handle this, then i would definitely suggest a temple stay!
and if you do the fire ceremony and the monks offer for the guests to participate - do it! maybe the monks think you’re part of the ceremony, not just an observer. or maybe it signals bad character to decline the activity (paying respects to your dead ancestors). whatever the reason, they pressured everyone to participate.
column8: First trip to Japan - advice on 2.5 weeks itinerary

column4:
suggestion:
2/15 -2/18 tokyo full days, day head kamakura-enoshima
2/19 nikko day trip
2/20 izu peninsula, kawazu/izu kogen day trip early blossoms
2/21 early train kanazawa overnight there, see snow monkeys en route interested
2/22 kanazawa
2/23 bus shirakawago morning, continue takayama afternoon
2/24 takayama afternoon, nagoya overnight want visit nabana sato. otherwise, head kyoto
2/25-3/3 kyoto, including day trips 1) nara/osaka; 2) koyasan (unless kids enjoy temple stay morning service); 3) hiroshima/miyajima (go early); 4) himeji (1/2 day required)
3/4 train odawara hakone. head hnd airport later evening via shinagawa
3/5 1am depart
key points proposed itinerary:
--landing 6am, hotel likely allow drop bags off. hnd airport paid showers interested. need plan time pass morning lunch. asakusa (with skytree) tsukiji market good candidates
--from 2/19 3/4, 14-day jr pass cover jr travels. means shinkansen limited express trains cover many rides izu peninsula, nikko, kanazawa, kyoto-osaka-hiroshima, hakone heading towards airport;
--nabana sato bad place visit, "must" sort place either. park hour outside central nagoya;
--if basing kyoto, many day trips planned, best pick base within 5-minute walking radius kyoto station;
--if concerns dragging bags moving around, luggage forwarding strategically. bags hotels door-to-door. delivery next day (except airport requires days) need overnight bags between;
--green car good vital. ordinary car seats much comfortable airplane's economy seat.
column5:
another suggestion:
2/15 -2/18 tokyo full days, take one day to head to kamakura-enoshima
2/19 nikko day trip
2/20 izu peninsula, kawazu/izu kogen day trip for early blossoms
2/21 early train to kanazawa and overnight there, see snow monkeys en route if interested
2/22 kanazawa
2/23 bus to shirakawago morning, continue to takayama in the afternoon
2/24 takayama until the afternoon, nagoya overnight if you want to visit nabana no sato. otherwise, head to kyoto
2/25-3/3 kyoto, including day trips to 1) nara/osaka; 2) koyasan (unless you think your kids would enjoy a temple stay with morning service); 3) hiroshima/miyajima (go early); 4) himeji (1/2 day required)
3/4 train to odawara for hakone. head to hnd airport later in the evening via shinagawa
3/5 1am depart
key points to this proposed itinerary:
--landing at 6am, your hotel will most likely only allow you to drop your bags off. hnd airport has paid showers if you are interested. you then need to plan your time to pass the morning until after lunch. asakusa (with or without skytree) and tsukiji market are good candidates
--from 2/19 to 3/4, you can use a 14-day jr pass to cover all jr travels. that means you can use shinkansen or limited express trains to cover many of the rides to izu peninsula, nikko, kanazawa, kyoto-osaka-hiroshima, hakone and even heading towards the airport;
--nabana no sato is not a bad place to visit, but it's not really a "must" sort of place either. the park itself is about an hour outside central nagoya;
--if basing yourself at kyoto, with so many day trips planned, it's best to pick a base within a 5-minute walking radius of kyoto station;
--if you have concerns dragging bags while moving around, use luggage forwarding strategically. your bags will go between hotels door-to-door. delivery is next day (except to the airport which requires 2 days) so you will need to use overnight bags in between;
--green car is good but it's not vital. ordinary car seats are much more comfortable than an airplane's economy seat.

i am currently planning my future (hopefully 2022) trip to vietnam, and i was extremely impressed by the beauty of the rural areas.

i laid out two itineraries, one in april and one in september, as they seem like great months overall for the whole country, weather wise.

31st march, arrival in ho chi minh city, spend two nights there.
2nd april, flight to hue for the hue festival, stay two nights.
4th april, train/whatever from hue to ninh binh, stay three nights.
8th april, mai chau by motorbike from ninh bing, one night.
9th april, pu luong by motorbike, day trip or one night.
then back to ninh binh and back to hanoi.

i'm also absolutely willing to expand my stay in specific places if you think it's worth it.

column5:
whilst it can be unpredictable, if you’ve never been to asia before, don’t risk a bad holiday by going when it being spoilt is a possibility. if you are going to hoi an as part of a bigger trip and can divert if needed once in vietnam then that’s not too bad an option but if your enjoyment depends on that week being in hoi an then it’s best not to chance it. the rest of vietnam can be enjoyed in poor weather, but the main hoi an town and the beaches are the main reason to be there for most visitors and neither would be much fun in a continual downpour or a typhoon..

column4: remember hoi place many remember. devastated cyclones flooded town last fall. usual rainy season comes ever year; 100 year flood. beach eroded beyond recognition many places dozens hotels restaurants closed permanently. covid, getting double-wammy residual business dried up. live hoi (based vietnamese friends saying) return plan moving dalat south strike zone cyclones. see article:
column5: you have to remember that hoi an is not the same place that many will remember. they were devastated by the cyclones which flooded the town last fall. this wasn't the usual rainy season that comes ever year; this was a 100 year flood. the beach has eroded beyond recognition in many places and dozens of hotels and restaurants have closed permanently. now with covid, they are getting a double-wammy and what residual business was there has dried up. i live in hoi an and (based on what my vietnamese friends are saying) when i return i plan on moving to dalat or further south out of the strike zone for the cyclones. see this article:

column5:
i have nothing more to add.
but since i've been revisiting (virtually) the đắk lắk area the last couple of weeks, i'll just say that there have been a lot of changes. many more homestays (besides the new/newer hotels) that look quite nice and comfortable as opposed to the dingy guesthouses of old.
if anybody plans to visit, march would be a good time if you like dry weather.
it's the season for the coffee flower blooms and also the season for the rubber plants to shed their leaves:

the bi-annual coffee festival is held in buôn ma thuột in march on odd years, but as it was suspended this year, there's a good possibility for it next year.
on the other hand, if you like waterfalls, opt for november - which is also toward the end of the rainy season; time for the tree marigold to blossom.

after buôn ma thuột/đắk lắk, if you time it well, you could join the 3 to 4-day festival up in chư pah (gia lai) - just north of pleiku.

john
edited: 11:41 am, february 19, 2021

you see green.

if river, see peasants working.
there incentive travel week april, catch local regional festival.
the hoa lư staged 6th 10th.
the thái vi temple tâm cốc area 14th-17th.
there festivals festival month north (the third month lunar year, 2022, coincides dates april western calendar .

i recommend tam cốc two main reasons:
1. pay split government entity control boat dock rowers predetermined percentage.
i can't remember sure, 50/50.

column5:
if you want it cool, visit no later than early april.
you should see some green.
march is good if you like the occasional fog that brings out the mistyque of the place.
the view from the mua cave also depends. people start planting some time in march so you may see fields of water entertwined with fields of greens.
if you're on the river, you may see the peasants working.
there might be another incentive to travel in week 2 or 3 of april, when you may catch a local or regional festival.
the one in hoa lư should be staged between the 6th and 10th.
the one at the thái vi temple in the tâm cốc area should be between the 14th-17th.
there are other festivals as it's the festival month in the north (the third month of the lunar year, which in 2022, coincides with the same dates in april of the western calendar .

i recommend tam cốc for two main reasons:
1. what you pay is split between the government entity that control the boat dock and the rowers in a predetermined percentage.
i can't remember for sure, but i think it's 50/50.
trang an, on the other hand, is run by a huge private entity that operates several mega entertainment complexes throughout the country. we don't know whether some of the profits line certain individual's pockets (under the table) as there have been various reports of them avoiding taxes in the news.
2. tam cốc is all natural, whereas tràng an has been manipulated by humans quite a bit.
besides the skull island, several temples were erected as props (no monk, no traditional worship).
dynamites and lots of rocks/stones from the nearby mountains were used and are continuing to be used.
cheers,
john

column5:
hello,
we can say that may is the start of the rainy season not only in northern vietnam but a large swath of mainland southeast asia. but, it's just the start and really doesn't peak until july - august. on the other hand, you don't have the heavy wintertime fog or spring haze, so the skies are often very clear, a good time for landscape photography. i would like to be in north vietnam by the beginning of may myself, but it doesn't look promising for this year.
you can study up on the weather here:

may is too early for rice planting in hoang su phi and xim man. difficult to say exactly when it will start, but i would say mid to late-june.
here is a shot from thông nguyên, taken on july 4, 2019. you can see how immature the seedlings are, i guess i missed planting by a week.

if you are really interested in rice planting, last year they started in sa pa and bat xat districts around the 10th of may. mu cang chi started around may 20th.
none of these destinations require a great deal of planning to visit. you could easily go up to ha noi and get the latest rice-planting intel, check the weather, and then head further north.
how will you be traveling in the north? motorcycle, hire-car, bus?
take care :)

column4: live hanoi visit hoang su phi twice year. rainy season start exactly time month wait end april weather phenomena become apparent .however, beginning may, small amount rain farmer start planting rice, depending fields enough water rice plating not. job last end month. according experience, move visit backend trip. half area covered rice planting process.
column5: i live in hanoi and i visit hoang su phi twice a year. the rainy season will start in may but to know exactly what time of the month we have to wait until the end of april when weather phenomena become more apparent .however, from the beginning of may, it always has a small amount of rain and the farmer will start planting rice, depending on what fields get enough water for rice plating or not. this job will last until the end of the month. according to my experience, you should move your visit to the backend of your trip. when half of the area has already been covered by rice and the other is in the planting process.

travelfish has a pretty good list of highlights: 
but, for me, the north of vietnam is well worth all the time you can give it: 
> should we fly or go overnight train?
either is good, but it depends on where you're going and what fits your schedule. trains are fine, but don't go everywhere.
the one thing to remember with vietnam is that it's bigger than it looks on the map and that travel is slower and more tiring than you'd expect. maybe that's two things. and it's worth checking out the expected weather:  there's three things..
it all depends on what your interests are and what you'd like to see/do. you've probably got at least a year to plan before you'd be able to travel, so there's plenty of time to research and plan.

column5:
vietnam is one of the easiest places to get around on your own, it is a well trod backpackers hang out. there are bus routes from anywhere to everywhere. we spent a month there and used a guide for the central highlands , as public transport was scarce and 8 years ago. we also used the services of mrs ha for airport transfers and guided tours around hoi an and hue plus her guide in hanoi.
mrs ha vietland discovery tours. i do know that her website was compromised a few years ago so ensure that you do not contact her on a bogus site.
however, you do need to be careful if you are traveling on the lower budget scale, we met many youngsters who had been ripped off by dodgy tour operators.
do check out the weather for september as vietnam has several climate areas including monsoons. we ravelled mid february to mid march where it was sandals and shorts south to north with hanoi being the only place that we need trousers and fleeces.

column5:
2025 is just the target completion date for phase 1 at the long thanh airport (designed capacity of 25m passengers annually in phase 1).
wnether the project will complete on time or not is a different matter.
as for the tsn airport, the slow period had allowed them to completely rework a runway. they are also working on other projects like anti-flooding, roadway expansions to ease traffic congestion, etc.
the work on building terminal t3 won't begin until oct this year with a 37-month schedule (end on 2024).
still a way to go on both.
john

i'd suggest south to north for several reasons.
1. the overall weather; not too too hot in the south and central yet (usually it gets hotter in april), and more temperamental in the north in april.
also, if you get lucky, like this year, when enough rain comes early, the terrace fields may have water in certain spots, and people may even start to seed like here in hoang su phi a couple of weeks ago:

2. in april, you should see white plum blossoms, rapeseed (mustard green) yellow flowers, red bombax anceps , white pearl blossoms, and some pinkish white buckwheat flowers:





and maybe even some late cherry blossoms.

3. tea harvest is some time in april.
4. the mèo vạc love marker near the end of april (for 2022); the main date will be the 27th, but do plan to arrive on the 26th if you can for the early activities.
(don't forget to book your accommodations early).

column5:
> any advice would be greatly appreciated.
far from clear that vietnam will be open by 2022. 1st half is extremely unlikely in my opinion, unless the vaccine fairy finds millions of spare doses. second half of 2022? too far away to guess.
vietnam needs 150 million doses to caver 75 million people. they're currently at less than 30,000 people fully vaccinated and about one million vaccinated once. they have plans and orders for about 110 million doses, but they're not all for delivery this year. they have home grown vaccines in trials, which might help if they are safe, effective, approved, and available in massive quantities. that's a lot of ifs.
january/february are pretty nice on phu quoc if all you want to do is chill. plenty of accommodation and eateries. but the weather's ok for seeing a lot more of the country: 
do watch out for tết which is 1st february. expect massive logistical problems if trying to travel a few days either side.
you can't currently get a visa for vietnam at all, so, plan and investigate all you like, but i wouldn't be booking anything until it's sure that travel to vietnam is possible (which i doubt very much it will be by feb 2022 :-( )
edited: 2:41 pm, may 30, 2021

column4:
early dec early snow season japan ski resorts general. good consistent powder timeline head niseko, hokkaido.
if timeline flexible, aim mid-jan end-feb/early march. intermediate advanced ski levels, recommend ski resorts hakuba, shiga kogen powder snow abundant. besides, lodgings/dining less expensive niseko, additional domestic air connection sapporo/cts required.
search snowjapan.com snow reports.
edited: 9:01 pm, march 01,
column5:
early dec is early snow season in japan ski resorts in general. for good and consistent powder in that timeline better head to niseko, hokkaido.
if your timeline is flexible, better aim for mid-jan to end-feb/early march. at intermediate to advanced ski levels, i recommend ski resorts like hakuba, shiga kogen where powder snow is also abundant. besides, lodgings/dining would be less expensive than in niseko, where an additional domestic air connection to sapporo/cts is required.
search on snowjapan.com for snow reports.
edited: 9:01 pm, march 01, 2021

column5:
if you have a jr pass (especially if you travel around japan, not just tokyo) i suggest just use jr local trans within tokyo and take a few subway rides if the place is not reachable via jr lines.
if the jr station is a little bit farther, just walk for 5-10 mins more although summer heat might be uncomfortable.
if you are not planning to get a jr pass, it is 600-1500 jpy, depending on how much you need to take subways. the cheapest ride is around 180-200 jpy, even just one station apart.
sometimes, they can offer a cheaper one day subway pass on weekends but that depends. i only experienced it in osaka though.

column5:
1. all reports say that the olympics will be held without foreign spectators in july-august. japan's rate of covid vaccination is one of the slowest in the industrial world. my guess is that japan will not be open for tourists until every resident who wants a vaccination is able to get one and the vaccine has enough time to be fully effective. that assumes that there isn't a new variant that is resistant to the current vaccines. there's also the possibility of requiring self-quarantine for several days, depending on the situation of the ground. that being said, i don't think japan will be open to tourists in september.

2. a trip jan-feb? do you like cold weather? while i snow ski, i'm not a big fan of cold weather and i thought it was uncomfortably cold in tokyo and kyoto to be outside sightseeing for half a day or more at a time.

column5:
we all have our "informed opinions." it just depends on which of us you choose to believe.
a news article just said israel (if that's where you are from) is now close to achieving herd immunity. it is possible that israelis might be allowed to enter japan earlier than some other places? however, at this point, i don't see much movement until after the olympics. the event has to take place and an assessment of its impact has to be done before anything loosens. an eye towards the first months of 2022 is more hopeful (but not necessarily realistic--we just don't know).
as to when to visit, except for hokkaido, the months i avoid are july through first half of september due to heat and humidity. ideally, october onwards is nice. cold is relative to your personal tolerance. i like visiting in january and february as well even though i don't always ski.

column5:
i visited japan in late february (tokyo - 4 days) / early march (kyoto - 6 days) a few years ago. it was a great trip!
in tokyo in late february, i was able to enjoy the plum blossoms in the grounds of yushima tenman-gū (yushima tenjin shrine) near ueno station. in kyoto, i spent a rainy day exploring the covered shopping arcades of teramachi and shinkyogoku (with an umbrella the hostel had lent me)! there's always something to do whatever the weather.
i'd say dress in layers (one day in tokyo it was 7°c in the morning and 17°c in the afternoon) and take time to rest and have a hot (or cold) drink.
and if you can, take the shinkansen between tokyo and kyoto and choose seat e (d is fine too) in any of the carriages to get a view of mount fuji from the train; in winter, the sky is more likely to be clear so the chances of seeing mount fuji are greater!
note: look into takuhaibin, the luggage delivery service.

i used them between tokyo and kyoto, making for a hassle-free travel experience on the train (it takes 2 days, if i remember well, for the luggage to arrive so plan accordingly).
thank you for your question. it allowed me to revisit my trip (i miss japan)! i hope you get to enjoy japan too.
edit: sorry, i hadn't seen dli_hk'spost on takuhaibin.
edited: 1:08 pm, may 04, 2021

column4: made 48 visits japan, march/april october february august. going singapore tokyo august, anything tokyo hotter humid. time found crowds tiresome kyoto height cherry blossom japanese considerate people world and, shinjuku station, crowded places world, ever bumped me. chilly weather april usually sunny low humidity 20c afternoon. days vary dramatically shirt sleeve day followed close freezing. winter temperatures similar l used uk l never experienced dreary days here, days clear sunny. wonderful observe delight locals experience cherry blossom and, apart kyoto, caused little trouble elsewhere. rain japan english drizzle tropical downpour avoid rainy season.
column5: i have made 48 visits to japan, most of them in march/april and october with a few in february and august. going from singapore to tokyo in august, if anything tokyo was hotter and just as humid. the only time i have found crowds tiresome was in kyoto at the height of the cherry blossom but the japanese are the most considerate people in the world and, even in shinjuku station, which is one of the most crowded places in the world, no one has ever bumped into me. i have had some chilly weather in april but usually it is sunny with low humidity and around 20c in the afternoon. days can vary dramatically with a shirt sleeve day followed by one close to freezing. winter temperatures are similar to those l am used to in the uk but l have never experienced the dreary days we get here, with most days clear and sunny. it is wonderful to observe the delight that the locals experience from the cherry blossom and, apart from in kyoto, it has caused me little trouble elsewhere. when it does rain in japan it is not our english drizzle but more like a tropical downpour so i would avoid the rainy season.

column4: living kyoto last june (2020) rained weeks straight. river flooded riverbanks closed. i’m sure happens every year, living kyoto weeks weeks end june wished somewhere japan wasn’t dealing rain/flooding. i’d hate someone’s experience kyoto japan that. i’d come japan it’s phenomenal country, i’d flexible travel within japan depending weather. it’s humid june. august brutal!
column5: i was living in kyoto last june (2020) and it rained for 2 weeks straight. the river flooded and the riverbanks were closed. i’m not sure if this happens every year, but i was living in kyoto for 5 weeks and there were 2 weeks at the end of june where i wished i was somewhere else in japan that wasn’t dealing with rain/flooding. i’d hate for someone’s experience of kyoto or japan to be during that. i’d still come to japan as it’s a phenomenal country, but i’d be flexible and travel within japan depending on the weather. it’s not humid in june. august is brutal!

column4: i’ve traveled japan annually cherry blossom season. visit time, it. weather perfect it’s beautiful time japan. also, culturally, it’s locals favorite time year energy/vibe time. heck, japanese women picking cherry blossom petals hair drinking strong zeros park!
column5: i’ve traveled to japan annually for the cherry blossom season. if you can visit it during that time, do it. the weather is perfect and it’s the most beautiful time to be in japan. also, culturally, it’s the locals favorite time of year and there is a better energy/vibe during that time. heck, i had japanese women picking cherry blossom petals out of my hair while drinking strong zeros in the park!

column4:
rain singapore - convectional perennial, typical tropical region.
rain hk - sw monsoon rain end april till may/june. sometimes, presence stationary fronts lead downpours days dissipates moves north sw monsoon gains upper hand.
rainy season japan except hokkaido - roughly mid june mid july. drizzles heavy downpours depending scale duration frontal rain band.
for nice "shoulder" seasons, consider (after golden week) weather generally warm hot humid. timeslot sightseeing oct early nov prefer avoid koyo (fall foliage) season places. weather drier day temps low 20s high teens, occasional typhoons pass land resulting rainy days affected locations.
ps. visited singapore year round - 70 times business stretching 15+ years, 10+ tokyo jan thru' oct business 80+ personal travels japan (except okinawa).
edited: 9:36 pm, march 20,
column5:
rain in singapore - convectional and perennial, typical in tropical region.
rain in hk - sw monsoon rain from end april till may/june. sometimes, presence of stationary fronts might lead to downpours for days until it either dissipates or moves north if the sw monsoon gains the upper hand.
rainy season in japan except hokkaido - roughly from mid june to mid july. it can be in drizzles or heavy downpours depending on the scale and duration of that frontal rain band.
for nice "shoulder" seasons, consider may (after the golden week) when weather is generally warm but not too hot nor humid. another timeslot for sightseeing is oct to early nov if you prefer to avoid the koyo (fall foliage) season in those places. weather is drier and day temps are in low 20s or high teens, though occasional typhoons may pass by or land resulting in a few rainy days in affected locations.
ps. have visited singapore all year round - probably over 70 times for business stretching for 15+ years, 10+ in tokyo from jan thru' oct for business and another 80+ for personal travels all over japan (except okinawa).
edited: 9:36 pm, march 20, 2021

i've been told by some people that i shouldn't bother with yakushima if i'm going in may since it's so rainy but my entire group is used to hiking and camping in horrible weather (we were all scouts in the canadian north) so we don't mind. my main worry though is how common are trails closed due to being too dangerous because of rain? if not officially closed how common is it for them to become overly dangerous due to rainy conditions? we will most likely be sticking to the more common touristy hiking trails and are hoping on booking a tour for them so we won't be going in blind.
we really want to go to yakushima but if it's likely for us to not be able to go onto hiking trails then it may be best to save yakushima for another trip.

column5:
for those spots, 3 days would be less rush.
consider below on high level.
d1 - tokyo to kamikochi would take up at least 5 hours. stay there overnight for hiking, scenery. note that alpico bus operates from mid-april to mid-nov. if possible, visit before end oct for peak fall foliage.
d2 - kamikochi to shin-hotaka via hirayu by nohi bus. stay overnight in 1 of 5 onsen villages in okuhida onsen such as hirayu onsen.

d3 - okuhida > snow monkey park via matsumoto and nagano > tokyo via hokuriku shinkansen
noticed from your other posts that you might be travelling from kansai to tokyo. if so, consider this to avoid backtracking.
kyoto > kanazawa (2n) > takayama (1n) > kamikochi or shin-hotaka

column4:
per yearly average, sakura usually reaches full bloom tokyo end mar/early april.
when cherry blossoms bloom?

however, timing fickle recent years due global warming. instance, full bloom dates tokyo days earlier average year.

for planning, suggestion plan last week march timeline flexible. note guess - based 10+ sakura visits japan. jma usually releases sakura forecast late feb, course closer accurate, barring unforeseen weather conditions closer and/or blooming season.
in general, weather sakura blossom cold. expect day temps range low high teens (in degree celcius). march 2021, days day temps shot low 20s.

rainy days cannot avoided japan, surrounded oceans directions. nevertheless, rain timeline due passing frontal rain, resulting mostly drizzles roughly days max per location. umbrellas borrowed hotel concierge bought convenience stores corners.
edited: 2:32 am, april 06,
column5:
as per yearly average, sakura usually reaches full bloom in tokyo around end mar/early april.
when do the cherry blossoms bloom?

however, timing has been more fickle in recent years due to global warming. for instance, full bloom dates in tokyo have been about 7 days earlier than average this year.

for planning, my suggestion is to plan for the last week of march if your timeline is flexible. note that this is just my guess - based on my 10+ sakura visits in japan. jma usually releases its sakura forecast from around late feb, and of course the closer the more accurate, and barring any unforeseen weather conditions closer and/or during the blooming season.
in general, weather during sakura blossom would not be that cold. expect day temps to range from low to high teens (in degree celcius). in march 2021, there were a few days when day temps shot up to low 20s.

rainy days cannot be avoided in japan, which is surrounded by oceans in all directions. nevertheless, rain in that timeline is more due to passing frontal rain, resulting in mostly drizzles for roughly 2 to 3 days max per location. umbrellas can be borrowed from hotel concierge or can be bought in convenience stores around the corners.
edited: 2:32 am, april 06, 2021

column4:
becky, see, people love kuta, others much. per post 2, read areas bali see suits you, try stay area/areas close want see do.
as example, want experience culture, sightseeing, adventure rafting bike rides etc, kuta long way things, ubud suit better, least time. wanted snorkelling diving, ne coast pemuteran suit better. want sit beach day, shop lot mingle hoards tourists, kuta fine you. aware ocean conditions though, surf rough dangerous poor swimmers. beach dirty full rubbish wet season - cleaned daily.
column5:
becky, as you can see, some people love kuta, others no so much. as per post 2, please read about the areas of bali to see which suits you, and do try to stay in the area/areas which are close to the things you want to see and do.
as an example, if you want to experience the culture, do sightseeing, do some adventure things such as rafting or bike rides etc, then kuta is a very long way from where you'd do these things, so ubud would suit you better, for at least some of the time. if you wanted snorkelling or diving, then the ne coast or pemuteran would suit you better. if you want to sit on the beach most of the day, shop a lot and mingle with hoards of tourists, then kuta might be just fine for you. do be aware of the ocean conditions though, as the surf can be rough and dangerous for poor swimmers. the beach can also be very dirty and full of rubbish during the wet season - although it does get cleaned daily.

column5:
can’t say if you are missing out. we are all different and have different likes/dislikes and things that make us happy. we’re not big ubud fans. might have a few days stay. may not bother. but that’s us.
you can’t fit in everything you might want to see and do in one trip.
we tend to start in amed every year but every year we have a slightly different itinerary that one of us (usually mrs pig and daughter) hasn’t been to (i have had solo diving/chillaxing trips where i have been to places mrs pig and daughter haven’t).
diving and snorkeling forms a large part of our holidays whether me and mrs pig (who doesn’t dive but loves snorkeling) or with our daughter (who is a marine biologist and loves diving and snorkeling).
so when we go on holiday i make sure mrs pig isn’t bored/becomes a dive widow whilst i am diving.
that’s why amed is so good. ican do 2 dives in the morning and finish for the day at lunch.
give mrs pig doorstep snorkeling, chilled places to eat and some shopping and she is happy.
we are big amed fans so generally spend the most days in amed.
myself and daughter like the easy going diving. we all like the easy access “fall in the water” snorkeling and the easy going life. mrs pig likes the fact she can just fall in the water snorkel while i’m diving. enough places to eat and drink to have variety.
i haven’t yet found a dive centre in gilis that matches how we dive in amed so accept the “difference”. not as flexible or “friendly”.
but for mrs p fall in the water snorkeling and lot more shopping than amed
after 5 nights or more in amed we are then very much 3 or 4 night people in other places like gilis/nl etc and now only have a night or 2 “down south” before flying home.
pemuteran also good. nice place to stay. few good places to eat and drink on the main road. we stay at 
however we wouldn’t have pemuteran and say gilis/lombok on the same trip.
we tend to always start in amed so amed - pemuteran - ubud - “down south” works well.
ubud - pemuteran - amed - “down south” also works.
if you have lots of time obviously after amed could do gilis then “down south”
we also make use of transfers to do a bit of sightseeing. e.g. between ubud and pemuteran can stop at lake beratan ulun danu beratan and/or northern waterfalls.
between ubud and amed can easily stop at tirta gangga water palace.
we often stop there if going from amed to “down south” as you literally drive past the front door.
it is all probably too much choice.
but i think you have a nice blend of everything to give you a taste and feel ….. and like the rest of us make you want to come back again to do something else.

column5:
i’m planning my first trip to bali, and am looking to see what other contact lens wearers’ experiences are in regards to safety.
i’ve heard the ocean water is quite polluted, but my sight is really bad, and i can’t afford lasik, so if i want to surf or enter the water and not get lost, i pretty much have to wear contacts. (i don’t want prescription goggles)
my plan is to wear daily contacts and throw them out immediately after swimming, and on days i don’t swim, throw them out at the end of the day.
i’ve heard about nasty eye infections leading to even blindness from normal bodies of water and even pools all around the world, so given what i’ve heard about the excessive water pollution there, as well as the tap water quality, i’m a little bit concerned!
would love to hear other’s experiences and what’s worked for them!
column8: Tips for Contact Lens Use in Bali?

column4:
wear contacts spend 58 days bali, 2-3 times year (pre covid course). scuba dive, bother swimming hotel pools. wear monthly contacts, night rather dry eyes, find comfortable.
i've ever mild eye problem, many years ago tulamben diving. unsure infection sting something water. someone drive apotek (chemist) amlapura given drops cost $4 fixed problem within 24 hours. wore glasses dive couple days ensure issue completely resolved.
now, carry bottle drops me, home, case infection, never happened. contain antibiotic steroid.
column5:
i wear contacts and spend 58 days in bali, 2-3 times a year (pre covid of course). i also scuba dive, but do not bother swimming in hotel pools. i wear monthly contacts, but always take them out each night as i have rather dry eyes, so find it more comfortable.
i've only ever had one mild eye problem, many years ago while i was in tulamben diving. i am unsure if it was an infection or a sting from something in the water. i just had someone drive me to the apotek (chemist) in amlapura and was given some drops that cost about $4 and fixed the problem within 24 hours. i wore glasses and did not dive for a couple of days to ensure the issue was completely resolved.
now, i always carry a bottle of the same drops with me, and even have them at home, just in case of another infection, but it has never happened. they contain an antibiotic and steroid.
column8: Tips for Contact Lens Use in Bali?

column4: ubud days kamandalu maya easy access town. padma offer shuttle service town quite distance away. stayed maya contemporary styled. alternatively, check komeneka properties. mention time year intend visit imo cold swimming june/july, padma heated pool.

column4:
grace, aware february/march wet season bali. west coast beaches covered rubbish debris. extremely hot humid. downpours, sunny, cloudy sunsets hit miss. don’t book activities ground bali ascertain weather conditions.
currently bali open it’s stated green zones - nusa dua, sanur ubud. day quarantine designated green zone hotels, pcr test arrival end quarantine stay. costs expense. understand covid rules transit country.
we book everything (airline/accommodation). ota choose “free cancellation” option booking accommodation. understand policy airline’s refunds flight cancelled.
you follow jackie pomeroy’s covid-19 update fb. mentioned bali indonesia it’s indonesian government makes final decisions bali governor. due international travellers bali year many hotels, restaurants, cafes, shops, supermarkets, shopping centres closed likely never return it’s difficult recommend anything. many hotels sale.
edited: 8:25 pm, 21,
column5:
hi grace, just be aware that february/march is the wet season in bali. the west coast beaches will be covered in rubbish and debris. it will be extremely hot and humid. there will be downpours, then maybe sunny, maybe cloudy and sunsets hit and miss. don’t book any activities until your on the ground in bali to ascertain the weather conditions.
currently if and when bali should open it’s stated that there will be green zones - nusa dua, sanur and ubud. there is a 5 day quarantine in designated green zone hotels, a pcr test on arrival and at the end of your quarantine stay. these costs are at your own expense. understand the covid rules for your transit country.
we always book everything ourselves (airline/accommodation). we use an ota and choose the “free cancellation” option when booking accommodation. understand the policy of your airline’s refunds if the flight should be cancelled.
you may like to follow jackie pomeroy’s covid-19 update on fb. as mentioned bali is in indonesia and it’s the indonesian government that makes the final decisions not the bali governor. due to no international travellers to bali in over a year many hotels, restaurants, cafes, shops, supermarkets, shopping centres have closed and it's very likely some will never return so it’s very difficult to recommend anything. many hotels are up for sale.
edited: 8:25 pm, may 21, 2021

column5:
hi grace,
if you have booked everything separately there are different rules and rights you have regarding cancelation/refunds/rebookings.
as an example last year we had numerous flights booked with singapore airlines to bali in 2021. some were booked through a third party (expedia) some direct. i also had some london-bali flights booked with turkish airlines (for my daughter and her bf) over expedia.
in all cases the airlines canceled the flights (as indonesia was closed to international tourism and importantly dps was closed) and i got full refunds for all flights. this is the law in the uk and eu. if your flight is canceled you are entitled to a full refund.
not just long haul. my daughter was due to fly with lufthansa to muc (home) for christmas. after uk announced the kent variant germany closed off the border with uk and canceled all flights within 8hrs of the announcement. my daughter missed the deadline by 10hours (all bags packed with xmas presents, extra luggage checked in). not seen her since.
did get all the money back for flights, business upgrade, extra baggage.
if you decide to cancel based on governmental advice or just how you feel then the area is very grey. many airlines were offering rebooking or vouchers but not refunds.
this was highlighted last year in the uk when british airways refused refunds despite ukgov advice not to travel. their attitude was “our flights are still going - not our problem you chose not to fly”.
fell foul of that. us in munich and daughter in london had a number of flights booked with ba last year we had to cancel. got the ba runaround. no idea what amount of vouchers/credits we have remaining.
all that aside as mentioned february/march is rainy season and beaches around seminyak can be covered in rubbish.
balis rainy season isn’t actually that rainy. nothing like what you see in the rainy season in vietnam, thailand and cambodia. in fact the peak amount of rain in balis rainy season is similar to the peak rain in ko samui's dry season.
if you want more reliable weather consider may to september. even october to early november is fairly dry.
covid/tourism aside one plus point if you haven’t booked a package and your hotels are not paid for you can change your itinerary. as you do more research on bali you may decide to change your itinerary or your properties.
you haven’t listed the hotels/properties you booked. it is important that you check the exact location of any property you have booked. do not believe any hotel or tourist brochure on location.
this is especially true for ubud properties. ubud doesn’t mean ubud.
there is ubud town, ubud district (up to 8km from town in some directions) and “nowhere near ubud but we’ll call ourselves ubud anyway even though it is 20km and 1hrs drive to town on a good day”.
do not take for granted services like “free shuttle” to town as a benefit or means there is a decent service.
seminyak is not as bad but certainly spreads out a long way. kuta merges into legian into seminyak just by crossing the road from one bar/shop to another all located along the long, mainly surfing kuta beach.
you can actually be in “seminyak” and be closer to beachwalk mall in kuta than seminyak square.
the problem with “seminyak” properties is that they spread a long way in land past the bypass and also up towards canggu and into the “countryside” of kerobokan.
if you wantany info on properties simply ask.

column5:
haven't been yet (chomping at the bit to go to sumatra), but from everything i have read, there isn't much in pulau weh that you won't also find at mentawai. and you'll certainly find better snorkeling/diving around bali.
my own priority is wildlife, so i've researched that, and while yes, bukit lawang is an option to see semi-wild orangutan, the longer path and wilder beasts can be found at ketambe which takes a day to get to instead of a few hours like bukit lawang. bukit lawang isn't big and definitely not as touristy as bali, it is touristy as compared to ketambe. the other even wilder option is to go visit mr. jali's lone place at kedah, which is a few hours further up from kedah along the same road. i've been trying to arrange that and haven't been able to reach jali's operation yet. but it does appear to be operating, as i can see from his instagram (which i found but he doesn't respond to messages in english and i don't speak the local language (yet)).
all of the above is based on extensive research, but not having actually set foot there yet. perhaps some locals will see this thread and give better answers.
edited: 2:59 pm, march 10, 2021
