thank you all very much for the replies! all so helpful! here's a bit more information:
i'm thinking 10 or 12 days in may of 2022 for the trip, hoping that covid will not be an issue at that point (my parents are both vaccinated) and based on my research may is the beginning of the dry season but not high season yet.
they have never been to asia which why i thought of bali as a great introduction to the continent, given that it should be great for both cultural sightseeing and beach life. also, they live in italy and not all destinations have good flight arrangements (i was thinking of thailand and the philippines too but flights are just not convenient).
i'm thinking of a staffed villa for a couple of reasons: first, they love having space and being away from people. they normally prefer quiet and secluded places. second, i think it's an experience to have an amazing villa by the beach (i've done this in thailand before and had an amazing time) where the staff thinks of everything. and while they will definitely go out for a few meals, given that this is a gift i want it to be all inclusive and completely worry-free.
they both like sightseeing and laying on the beach. my dad loves diving but my mom doesn't, so he will probably dive a couple of times only.
i like the idea of splitting their time between two different parts of the island (i didn't realize how long it takes to cross the island).
please let me know if you have more suggestions and recommendations!

column5:
we go to bali for diving/snorkeling/chillaxing.
i dive, daughter dives and wife likes to snorkel.
in normal times we spend time on gili t. usually straight after amed (also popular for diving,snorkeling, chillaxing).
generally most debris gets washed up during the rainy season (dec-feb). in the dry season not so frequent however around july can get high winds coming down the java sea leading to rough seas and resulting in debris being washed up.
the thing about gili t is there a patches of beach in the small underdeveloped beachfront areas (yes there are some) which do get covered in debris. as mentioned previously a lot of beach clear up goes on but if you walk around the island there are parts that are left more “natural”.
the beach areas all around the island are largely kept clean. not unusual however for broken bits of coral to get washed up on the beach. tou notice this straight away when you jump of the fastboat in bare feet in the shallows.
easy to find turtles. anywhere between the pier near www.manta-dive.com (where we stay) and danima resort just fall in and snorkel with turtles. can see them whilst stood on the beach.
north end of the island is a good snorkel spot.
fastboats
lots of fastboat services to the gilis. most companies include free mainland pickups/dropoff services, often direct hotel, from ubud and all major southern resorts.
book your tickets once in bali for best prices.
should note that overall travel time (ubud pickup, road transfer to padangbai, wait around, boat journey) ubud to gili t is ~ 3.5hrs.
this isn’t too bad on the way out because you will reach gili t around 10:30/10:45
problem is return. because the fastboats are roundtrip services after gili t they go round the other gilis, compulsory stop on lombok, before returning to bali.
this means that the return boat service from gili t to the mainland can be 2:45 then you have road transfers which can take a couple of hours depending on where you are going.
return services only start when the first boat arrives around 11am-12 noon. overall you can assume at least 4 hours return journey time at best.
alternative - amed
if you want fall in the water snorkeling then look at amed.
only 2hrs or so drive from ubud. we sometimes do ubud - amed - gilis.
amed is a large area. the beaches aren’t white sand “caribbean idyll”. more a sand/stone mix.
it is a large area. we stay in jemeluk bay. the largest area with most places to eat/drink/stay.
as a flavour we stay at www.kembalibeachbungalows.nl
just walk out, fall in the water and snorkel. often see turtles. lots of fish. seen morays, stonefish (dangerous) and the odd baracuda. nemos etc. even seen juvenile blacktip sharks in front of the 
area is very paid back.
above main jemeluk beach is 
good place for a bite to eat and views. probably has the best views from a yoga deck in whole bali.

chris,
firstly denpasar administrative capital. tourist destination. dps airport tuban start huge tuban/kuta/legian/seminyak urban tourist strip.
mengwi place near taman ayung temple (one favourite places visit) area. narrow somewhat long dragged area. covers 1km beach canggu tanah lot stretches 20km inland.

ubud popular good base sightseeing activities. people choose visit kuta etc. 30km usually takes 1h30 day. traffic horrendous “down south”.
as far visiting doesn’t look promising honest, somewhat ironically, china mooted possibly countries indonesia sort “travel corridor”.

column5:
hi chris,
firstly denpasar is just the administrative capital. not a tourist destination. dps airport is actually in tuban which is the start of the huge tuban/kuta/legian/seminyak urban tourist strip.
mengwi is a place near taman ayung temple (one of our favourite places to visit) but is also an area. it is a narrow but somewhat long dragged out area. covers about 1km of beach between canggu and tanah lot but stretches over 20km inland.
best places to stay should be based on your own personal interests. certain sights and activities are best done from certain places. this is much to do with the size of bali 5280sqkm - over 4 times the size of greater manchester. put this together with the poor roads and traffic, where you won’t average much more than 30kmh, it can take ages to get anywhere.
purely as an example we go to bali mainly for the diving, snorkeling and chillaxing. so stay in those areas (amed on the east coast, pemuteran, gili islands and nusa lembongan). we are in amed every year. it is only 90kms from dps but takes 3hr transfer.
ubud is popular and also a good base for sightseeing and some activities. some people choose to visit from kuta etc. it is only 30km or so but usually takes 1h30 during the day. traffic is horrendous “down south”.
as far as visiting it doesn’t look promising and to be honest, somewhat ironically, china has been mooted as possibly one of the first countries with whom indonesia will have some sort of “travel corridor”.
other things not known/to be considered are what the entry criteria will be. again this may be different depending on where you come from.
could include any/some/combination of -ve test, covid vaccine, compulsory quarantine on arrival.
you also have to take into account the rules of the countries you transit.
as an example we generally fly to bali with singapore airlines. last year at the height of the pandemic singapore even banned european travelers from transiting at changi airport.
and of course the uks own travel advice/regulations including right to travel and quarantine on return. may or may not still have a travel ban and any travel insurance may be invalid.
we are “hoping” for november but we don’t need to plan and will do it all a bit “lastminute.com” when eventually we fulfil all the entry and “exit” critera.
edited: 3:25 pm, april 02, 2021

column5:
i’m fortunate to have two trips each year to bali. we have spent a number of years enjoying a bali christmas, starting our stay early december. then another trip in june when i must say the weather is very pleasant. we’re ok with the december weather as we’ve been going to bali since 1982 so if we’re not out and about all day it doesn’t worry us and we very much enjoy the festive season in bali as they do cater for tourists with christmas trees, decorations (and traditional lunch if that’s required). december 2019 was an absolute killer with the heat and there was a lot of lying around the pool and lunch at our accommodation. first timers to bali may find the heat and humidity daunting.
(so i agree with sue’s sentiments; just saw your post).
edited: 5:18 am, may 10, 2021

column4:
need guide easy japan flexibility own. japan safest countries could ever people super helpful reserved time. loved japan bee times again, next year possible.
avoid july/august unbearably hot humid could spend half time hiding shops advantage air conditioning.
the last time went october beautiful weather.
i flexible travels. weeks book whole trip sure free cancellation want stay little longer somewhere detour can. lots see.
column5:
you don't need a guide as it is easy to get around in japan and you will have more flexibility on your own. also japan is one of the safest countries you could ever go to and the people are super helpful although very reserved at the same time. i absolutely loved japan and have bee 3 times now and i hope to go again, maybe next year if at all possible.
avoid july/august as it can be unbearably hot and humid and you could spend half your time hiding in shops just to take advantage of the air conditioning.
the last time i went was in october and it was beautiful weather.
i would say do your own thing and be flexible with travels. if you have 4 to 6 weeks then you don't have to book the whole trip in one go or if you do just make sure that you have free cancellation then if you want to stay a little longer somewhere or make a detour then you can. there is lots to see.

column5:
#12,
in general, highway bus drivers in japan are much more cautious (than elsewhere in the world). steering speeds might be around 60-80km/h even on expressways and less swerving. have taken those b/w say nagoya <> takayama (in 3 hours though well over 10 years ago), tokyo <> fuji 5-lake (2 hrs+) and elsewhere in japan such as to ski resorts many times.

note that the khp (as recommended earlier) saves if you complete a round trip from osaka. for one-way travel to onomichi/hiroshima only, just buy single shinkansen or highway bus ticket.
also, the hiroshima airport only serves a few asia destinations only.

column8: My 10 year son wants to visit Japan - need advise

column4:
thought 10-year old serving translator tour guide parents! could opportunity him! encourage much trip planning handle!
try study basic japanese etiquette; plenty youtube videos topic.
when go? check climate data japan. summer hot humid. fall spring pleasant. try avoid major japanese holiday periods, heavy travel periods japanese. i've tried august (way hot humid), september (still humid), october (comfortable), november (comfortable mind occasional chill). typhoons fall, i'd rather rainy day week high humidity. see  .
where stay? hotel rooms tend small. almost neighborhoods safe, cheap clean room safe area. stay mostly toyoko inn hotel chain, tiny clean room free breakfast. convenience little refrigerator room, microwave lobby, coin-operated laundry machines; toyoko inns all. hotels, rakuten travel website good start.
the japanese train system excellent english signage offers reliable service. find train schedules www.hyperdia.com. consider national japan rail pass and/or regional rail passes.
if want see katsura imperial villa garden kyoto, need reservation advance.
consider adding nagasaki itinerary; dejima museum excellent. ideas places visit kyushu, see 
you could spend couple days hiroshima see peace memorial museum, shukkeien garden, fukuromachi elementary school peace museum, miyajima.
column5:
i really like the thought of a 10-year old serving as translator and tour guide for his parents! this could be a great opportunity for him! please encourage him to do as much of the trip planning as he can handle!
try to study basic japanese etiquette; there are plenty of youtube videos on this topic.
when to go? check the climate data for japan. the summer is hot and humid. fall and spring are pleasant. try to avoid major japanese holiday periods, which are heavy travel periods for the japanese. i've tried august (way too hot and humid), september (still too humid), october (comfortable), and november (comfortable if you don't mind an occasional chill). there are typhoons in the fall, but i'd rather have a rainy day than a week of high humidity. see  .
where to stay? hotel rooms tend to be small. almost all neighborhoods are safe, so you can go cheap and still have a clean room in a safe area. i stay mostly at the toyoko inn hotel chain, where you get a tiny but clean room and free breakfast. it's a convenience to have a little refrigerator in the room, a microwave in the lobby, and coin-operated laundry machines; toyoko inns have them all. for other hotels, the rakuten travel website is a good start.
the japanese train system has excellent english signage and offers reliable service. you can find train schedules at www.hyperdia.com. consider the national japan rail pass and/or one of the regional rail passes.
if you want to see the katsura imperial villa garden in kyoto, you will need to make a reservation in advance.
consider adding nagasaki to your itinerary; the dejima museum is excellent. for more ideas of places to visit on kyushu, see 
you could also spend a couple of days in hiroshima to see the peace memorial museum, shukkeien garden, fukuromachi elementary school peace museum, and miyajima.

column4: open later 2022! answer query cabins water khao sok, cheow larn lake. entrance 50km away park entrance jungle house is. pick cheap overnighter transport places near main park entrance area, read went accommodation pretty basic. wanted stay panvaree greenery booked separately expedia went. possible book trip via jungle house similar selecting accommodation, i'm sure. getting khao sok cheow larn tour little faffy doable. taxi course, ended getting mini van main road bhan ta khun taxi there. left, got shuttle surat thani airport pier. loved panvaree greenery. overnight cost included couple boat trips reservoir see beautiful scenery spot wildlife, kayaks explore own, food amazing.
column5: i really hope that things will be open again by later in 2022! in answer to your query re cabins on the water at khao sok, that will be cheow larn lake. the entrance is about 50km away from the park entrance where the jungle house is. you can pick up a cheap overnighter with transport from any of the places near the main park entrance area, but from what i read before i went the accommodation is pretty basic. i wanted to stay at panvaree the greenery so booked that separately through expedia before i went. it might be possible to book a trip via the jungle house or similar selecting your own accommodation, i'm not sure. getting from khao sok to cheow larn without a tour was a little faffy but doable. you can get a taxi there of course, or i ended up getting a mini van from the main road to bhan ta khun and a taxi from there. when i left, i got a shuttle to surat thani airport from the pier. i loved panvaree the greenery. the overnight cost included a couple of boat trips around the reservoir to see the beautiful scenery and spot wildlife, they had kayaks to explore on your own, and the food was amazing.

column4:
khunbill mentioned khao lak covers long stretch along highway, much remember long ago.
for bang niang area considered main part town, lots eateries, tsunami museum, night market such. nang thong next beach south number two easy walking eateries, shopping, etc.
baan khaolak resort (assuming location today) southern end nang thong beach, understandable long walk then. today find dining options within short stroll, khao lak grown considerably years.
column5:
as khunbill mentioned khao lak covers a long stretch along the highway, probably much more than you remember from long ago.
for most bang niang area is considered to be the main part of town, with lots of eateries, the tsunami museum, the night market and such. nang thong the next beach south is probably number two for easy walking to eateries, shopping, etc.
baan khaolak resort (assuming it is in the same location today) is at the southern end of nang thong beach, so understandable that it was a long walk back then. but today you will find more dining options and such within a short stroll, as khao lak has grown considerably over the years.

column4:
>>> waves tend action followed lull, empty period. covid pretty much non stop, flood minor fluctuations level. 'waves' sound cool media. <<<
the reason health professionals media refer "waves" look graph new cases (or deaths, hospitalization), see wave pattern. peaks, followed valleys. case us, valleys following peaks continue higher last valley high peaks, 4th wave many states control rates covid.
column5:
>>> waves tend to be an action followed by a lull, an empty period. but with covid it has been pretty much non stop, like a flood with some minor fluctuations in level. but 'waves' sound cool to media. <<<
the reason that health professionals and the media refer to "waves" is that when you look at graph of new cases (or deaths, or hospitalization), you see a wave like pattern. there are peaks, followed by valleys. in the case of the us, the valleys following the peaks continue to get higher so the last valley was as high as the first 2 peaks, and we are now in a 4th wave with many states having out of control rates of covid.

column5:
"really don't plan your holiday with old reports or statistics about the weather."
so how do people plan? simply ignore the weather because things might be different or continue to use past data as a reference? the fact that it was raining on 6 may 2021 doesn't automatically mean that 6 may will now be raining every year. simply an anomaly.

we hotels indication preferred price range.

column5:
as you seemed a bit interested in khao sok treehouses- have a look at our jungle house. all treehouses explained with costs. if you also look at their ‘tours’ page, this will give you an idea of what’s available from all khao sok places to stay. we like the canoeing (especially as someone does all the paddling for you). did elephant riding from there (and elephant hills) some years ago. no riding anymore, but the children will be entranced by the elephant care activity. our jungle house now has a new property, our jungle camp, which also looks good. also check out elephant hills. ($$$$).
we can all suggest hotels if you give some indication of your preferred price range.
virtually everything will be cheaper in chiang mai than at the southern beach resorts, not to mention cooler and less humid too. loads of cooking schools in cm suitable for families.

#14 ... +1
nov price jump research, travels. thankfully school breaks sept mid oct, got best pricing, decent 'cusp' high / low season .pricing ... dry / wet season weather, years. long school break end; mar / apr / mid may. march high, depending where, along songkran course, jacked up. choosing wisely find regular pricing.

column5:
#14 ... +1
nov 1 has always been the price jump for our research, and travels. thankfully school breaks were sept to mid oct, so got the best of pricing, with decent 'cusp' of high / low season .pricing ... dry / wet season weather, over the years. same with long school break on the other end; mar / apr / mid may. march sometimes high, depending where, along with songkran of course, always jacked up. choosing wisely and can find regular pricing.
only once being rained off of lanta, early may, with non-stop 24/7 heavy rain for days on end. hopped over to phuket, and a perfect week afterwards. not bad for a 20 yr stretch of out & abouts.

column4:
travelling lot luggage less mobile suffer jet lag (or going trip lifetime, money object) private transfer likely ‘best’ frankly there’s much it. heathrow technically connected fastest route, road bad gatwick options. times 10 heathrow bet, aren’t pushed time fare dramatically cheaper gatwick tempting.
otoh young, fit, backpacking (on cruise?), budget etc, train gatwick choice.
column5:
if you are travelling with a lot of luggage or are less mobile or suffer from jet lag (or just going on the trip of a lifetime, money no object) a private transfer is likely ‘best’ and frankly there’s not too much in it. heathrow is technically better connected to the fastest route, but if the road is bad gatwick has more options. 9 times out of 10 heathrow will be the better bet, but if you aren’t pushed for time and the fare is dramatically cheaper gatwick is tempting.
otoh if you are young, fit, backpacking (on a cruise?), on a budget etc, then the train from gatwick is probably your choice.

i'd seek-out hand-dived farmed shellfish dredging lot damage marine ecosystem large areas west scotland dredging bans try let seabed recover years over-dredging.
although problem may, aware bans landing warnings placed consumption inshore scottish shellfish result blue-green algae, toxic tiny amounts likely occur high-summer months hottest summers.
edited: 5:34 am, march 04,
column5:
i'd suggest you seek-out hand-dived or farmed shellfish as dredging does a lot of damage to the marine ecosystem and there are already large areas off the west of scotland under dredging bans to try and let the seabed recover after years of over-dredging.
although it shouldn't be any problem in may, you should also be aware that there have been bans on landing and warnings placed on the consumption of inshore scottish shellfish as a result of blue-green algae, which can be toxic in even tiny amounts and is most likely to occur in the high-summer months of the hottest summers.
edited: 5:34 am, march 04, 2021

column4:
worth, experience short trip isles scilly last august.
i booked skybus got lands end airport 10:00 thick fog flights. cleared early afternoon forecast following day high winds meant travel scillonian doubtful. cut losses, phoned heliport managed late afternoon flight. thick fog st perfectly clear day penzance st marys
from memory skybus £85 way single helicopter flight £130 (i came via skybus). helicopter i’d lost days day trip.
so definitely helicopter. remember august reasonably expect decent weather
column5:
for what its worth, my own experience with a short trip to the isles of scilly last august.
i booked on the skybus and when i got to lands end airport about 10:00 there was thick fog and no flights. it hadn't cleared by early afternoon and the forecast for the following day was for high winds which meant travel on the scillonian was also doubtful. so i cut my losses, phoned the heliport and managed to get on a late afternoon flight. thick fog at st just but a perfectly clear day in penzance and at st marys
from memory the skybus was about £85 each way and the single helicopter flight was about £130 (i came back via skybus). without the helicopter i’d have lost 1 or 2 days of my 4 day trip.
so when i go again it will definitely be the helicopter. remember that this was in august when you might reasonably expect decent weather

column4:
short answer question no, slightest hint fog whole falls over. must plane top tips 1. never plan travel home saturday, worst could vagrant following monday 2. check weather airport day departure limited capacity ferry crossing offered straight alternative.
3 fully insured prospect regularly cancelled flights, disruption expense
friends found camped church hall overnight refugees sally army providing tea, helicopter ferry, best bet. helps
column5:
the short answer to that question is no, the slightest hint of fog and the whole thing falls over. if you must go by plane my top tips are 1. never plan to travel home on a saturday, at worst you could be vagrant until following monday 2. check the weather and airport first thing on the day of departure because there is limited capacity on the ferry crossing that is offered as a straight alternative.
3 get fully insured against the prospect of regularly cancelled flights, disruption and expense
friends of ours found themselves camped down in the church hall overnight like refugees but without the sally army providing tea, or better still go by helicopter or ferry, its your best bet. hope this helps

column5: we go by boat but if i had to choose between the other two it would be helicopter all the way. there are many occasions when lands end is fogged out but penzance and the islands are clear.

column4:
tram cable car run bottom orme summit complex top - start different places less destination. tram split two sections, base halfway station halfway station summit complex. mines quite close halfway station. pier entrance close base orme tramway, mines, cable cars pier geographically close other. there's vintage coach tour marine drive departs pier entrance. tour last hour includes running commentary see lot otherwise noticed car.
i'd leave pier last open fairly late evening whereas tram, cable car mines limited opening hours could easily places day.
i guess bonuses llandudno attractions grouped together close orme (there's ski slope toboggan run see onto cable car) car problem getting place place.
column5:
the tram and the cable car both run from the bottom of the orme to the summit complex at the top - so both start from different places but have more or less the same destination. the tram is split into two sections, one from the base to the halfway station and one from the halfway station to the summit complex. the mines are quite close to the halfway station. the pier entrance is close to the base of the orme so the tramway, the mines, the cable cars and the pier are all geographically very close to each other. there's a vintage coach tour around marine drive which departs from the pier entrance. the tour last about an hour and includes a running commentary so you'll get to see a lot of things you might not otherwise have noticed from a car.
i'd leave the pier until last just because it's open until fairly late in the evening whereas the tram, cable car and mines have more limited opening hours but you could very easily do all of these places in a day.
i guess one of the bonuses of llandudno is that most of the attractions are grouped together either on or very close the great orme (there's also a ski slope and toboggan run which you'll see if you get onto the cable car) so even without a car you should have no problem getting from place to place.

just to add that ferry from mallaig to skye does not go off anywhere near is often as it did three or four years back when the normal ferry went in for repairs and it was replaced by a ferry that was not suitable at certain tides so it was often cancelled even when the weather was fine . prior to this this wasn't the case and it was only cancelled due to bad weather and for the last couple of years it hasn't been the case either and it is back to be cancellations for weather reasons. it is of course still worth checking but easy enough to change your plans at the start of the day when you reach fort william :-).

column5: it's worth carrying the local phone numbers for calmac offices in each port. they can keep you up to date if you're worried about weather or other contingencies. and they're very helpful regarding sailing times. in other words, if you've got a ticket thay'll try to get you on board. plainly this is easiest on routes that operate frequently ...

column4:
april october fine unpredictable weather front cause disruption genuinely worry it. rudyardk said cal mac company (apart couple years messed mallaig ferry :-)) ticket best ferry. arrive time held due traffic road works ferry possible. cal mac ferries last 43 years idea many times sailed (it hundreds though) apart couple years never ferry cancel shelter bay several hours boat dock stornoway due weather :-)

edited: 6:53 pm, january 29,
column5:
no between april and october you should be fine and it would just take an unpredictable weather front to cause disruption but i genuinely really wouldn't worry about it. as rudyardk said cal mac are a great company (apart from the couple of years when they messed about with the mallaig ferry haha :-)) and if you have a ticket they will do there best to get you on that ferry. always arrive on time but if you are held up due to traffic or road works the they will still get you on the ferry if possible. i have been on cal mac ferries for the last 43 years and i have no idea how many times i have sailed with them (it will be in the hundreds though) and apart from those couple of years i have never had a ferry cancel on me although once we did have to shelter in a bay for several hours as the boat couldn't dock in stornoway due to the weather :-)
i really wouldn't change any plans over a situation that was occurring two or three years ago or panic over the weather having an affect on crossings between april and october although yes it can happen but you would be unlucky.
edited: 6:53 pm, january 29, 2021

column4:
you’ve got seat you’ll little elevation i’d try decent high (well high can) position asap view big screens well. silverstone flat infield infrastructure means you’ll usually view corner two sure late arrivals don’t restrict little see taking high ground early,
if sky customer sure you’ve got skygo tablet phone enough power available (a big power brick example). bbc something iplayer sure works. wifi 4g silverstone short supply due demand don’t expect miracles.
obviously it’s going long day, going friend keep spot need leave important, keep eye weather there’s protection sun rain unless stand (and rows exposed).
column5:
if you’ve not got a seat you’ll have little elevation so i’d try to get a decent high (well as high as you can) position asap and have a view of one of the big screens as well. silverstone is flat and the infield infrastructure means you’ll usually only have a view over a corner or two so make sure any late arrivals don’t restrict what little you can see by taking the high ground early,
if you are a sky customer make sure you’ve got skygo on a tablet or phone and have enough power available (a big power brick for example). if the bbc have something on iplayer then make sure that works. wifi and 4g at silverstone can be in short supply due to the demand so don’t expect miracles.
obviously it’s going to be a long day, so going with a friend to keep your spot when you need to leave it is important, and keep an eye on the weather because there’s no protection from sun or rain unless you are in a stand (and even the first rows of those are exposed).

column5: the fast ferries aren't listed because they are so often cancelled. they are horrendous in a swell and cant cope with the weather, and if they only have a few bookings they will move you to the next proper boat.

column4:
also, weather pretty good xmas trips. much precipitation. little warm devon, cold weather person.
note, festive season walking trip, cotswolds, encounter rough weather. snowed heavily southern england week earlier, got cold, everything froze much plowing (except main roads) sidewalk shoveling . slow going secondary roads, packed icy sidewalks places oxford (where spent night) challenging someone used seeing shoveled, fortunately hiking boots driving. london new year's cold (about 30 - 32 f, cold us) snowing lightly. generally cold snow unusual area.
column5:
also, weather was pretty good on my xmas trips. not much precipitation. it was a little warm for me in devon, but i am more of a cold weather person.
note, on one festive season walking trip, to cotswolds, i did encounter rough weather. it had snowed heavily in southern england a week earlier, then got very very cold, so everything froze before they did much plowing (except on main roads) and sidewalk shoveling . so it was slow going on secondary roads, and packed and icy sidewalks in places like oxford (where i spent a night) were challenging to someone used to seeing them shoveled, but fortunately i had my hiking boots and wasn't driving. i have also been in london just after new year's when it was cold (about 30 - 32 f, which is cold for them if not for us) and snowing lightly. but generally i think cold and snow like that are unusual in that area.
column8: Christmas Holiday and Hiking in Southern England

column4:
plenty people (myself included) enjoy lighter-scale/shorter walks christmas new year period, certainly alone. "blowing away cobwebs" often hear described.
however need accept activities mainly outdoor, possibly fairly grim weather short-ish days much else, anything open, esp christmas/new years days, able find warm pub days. well prepared cold/wet weather clothing, good boots/walking shoes packed lunch, flask hot drink case.
column5:
plenty of people (myself included) do like to get out and enjoy lighter-scale/shorter walks over the christmas and new year period, so you certainly won't be alone. "blowing away the cobwebs" is often how you hear it described.
however you do need to accept that most of your activities will be mainly outdoor, possibly in fairly grim weather with short-ish days and there may not be much else, if anything open, esp on christmas/new years days, although you should be able to find a warm pub etc for after on any other days. so be well prepared with cold/wet weather clothing, good boots/walking shoes and take a packed lunch, flask of hot drink etc just in case.
column8: Christmas Holiday and Hiking in Southern England

column5:
sorry to sound like scrooge, but christmas is a time of sky-high accommodation prices, train chaos, closed visitor attractions, and in all probability, lousy weather and appalling mud.
a walking trip would be much more enjoyable in spring. and don't just stick to southern england. the peak district, the lake district, yorkshire dales and snowdonia all offer excellent walking.

column5:
hi john and welcome to the forum
at the risk of repeating what others have said, this is not a plan which many brits would actively recommend and it has a some known and predictable constraints (such as length of day, limited - or some days zero - public transport, food shops closed or with limited hours, restaurants shut or concentrating on festive parties, closure of visitor attractions) combined with the unpredictability of the weather (which may go from delightful to dreary within one day).
that said, here’s what i’d recommend to my own american friends.
use the first and ninth days as buffers and treat this as a one week holiday. take the train to somewhere where you can pick up a hire car and drive to a single, comfortable self-catering house or cottage, for the week. en route, do one ‘big shop’ at a supermarket to cover most of the week’s food. (bear in mind that before christmas and new year some roads and trains get very busy as people congregate from distant parts for seasonal family celebrations and that food shops are likewise busy with people stocking up.)
use your home as a base for daily sorties to local coasts, rivers, woods, moors…. keep things flexible, planning each day the day before and using what are by then the excellent short-term weather forecasts issued, for instance, by the met office.
personally my chosen venue would be the lovely estuary town of dartmouth in south devon, my home county. car pick-up probably in exeter. my family have done exactly what i’ve described above a couple of times (without the transatlantic flight and long train journey!) and had a great time. here you have a complete variety of possible coastal, river, woodland and moorland day walks almost on your doorstop, close enough to your base to allow for complete flexibility and in a town which is pleasant just to stroll around for an hour or so if the weather turns.
second choice would be the delightful coastal town of sidmouth in east devon. or lyme regis or swanage in dorset.
but to echo some other comments above, i’d go in may or september unless december was the only option.

column4:
prior pandemic visited uk october november regularly many years found neither potential inclement weather shortening days issue. however, trip find reduced daylight hours less ideal. location profile idea travel, live southern half states difference notable.
if idea england scotland tour - i'd book - suspect able reproduce parts considerably less tour operator charging. travelling rail much pleasant sitting coach whizzing past sight, choosing one's accommodation definitely plus.
'affordable amsterdam, bruges, paris & london' far much week, canny eurostar rail tickets within france, belgium netherlands.
is iceland wish list? i've visited september enjoyed relative peace quiet, found outdoor activities available added value trip.
column5:
prior to the pandemic i visited the uk in october and november regularly for many years and had found neither the potential for inclement weather or the shortening days an issue. however, if this is a first trip i think you might find the reduced daylight hours less than ideal. you've no location in your profile and we have no idea from where you'll travel, but if you live in the southern half of the states the difference will be notable.
if you like the idea of the england and scotland tour - i'd not book it - i suspect you'd be able to reproduce parts of it for considerably less than the tour operator is charging. travelling by rail would be much more pleasant than sitting on a coach whizzing past a sight, and choosing one's accommodation is definitely a plus.
'affordable amsterdam, bruges, paris & london' far too much for one week, even if one were to be canny with eurostar and rail tickets within france, belgium and the netherlands.
is iceland off your wish list? i've visited in september and enjoyed the relative peace and quiet, and found there were still outdoor activities available that added value to the trip.
column8: Travel to Europe in Late October/Early November

column5:
hi,
these “green zones” have only been mooted and exactly how they will work is unknown.
our trips to bali always include amed then often include places like gilis, nusa lembongan or pemuteran. sometimes ubud and somewhere “down south” before flying home.
we mainly go for diving, snorkeling and chillaxing.
we had a trip for november 2020 which was ubud - amed - gili t - nusa lembongan - sanur (before flying to perth/rottnes island). obviously cancelled.
our next trip, whenever, hopefully will be as above but without oz.
we will not go to bali (when allowed) if we are restricted to places we have little or no interest in staying.
however bali is not open to international tourists and nobody knows when it will be open, who will be first or entry criteria (whether -ve test and/or covid vaccine and/or quarantine) or where you will be allowed to stay.
you also have to take into account all your flight transit countries. even if bali opens it is possible your transit countries may not allow you in even for transit (as happened with singapore last year who banned many countries even from transit).
the irony is that china may be one of the first countries to have some sort of “travel corridor” agreement with indonesia.

column5:
hi,
how many days in total and what are your overall plans.
given your “implied” itinerary then consider
ubud - “an island” - “southern resort”
this is a popular itinerary and in that order.
this is a better order as you finish closer to the airport.
also if going to the gilis this is far better order because of the way the fastboat services run.
gilis are small flat islands. not much to do except diving, snorkeling and chillaxing. gili t has a rep for partying but can stay away from that area.
you can cycle around the whole island in 40mins
we often go to gili t (from amed) but go for the diving/snorkeling and chillaxing.
other islands easier to get to are nusa lembongan and nusa penida.
lembongan has more tourist infrastructure and is more for chillaxing.
penida isn’t overdeveloped tourismwise so choice of accommodation is limited in comparison.
penida is the place for walking/sightseeing.
fastboats
fastboats to the islands go out of padangbai, sanur, serangan and amed (gilis only).
you do not need to arrange your own transport to/from any port.
all fastboat services include some sort of free pickup and dropoff services. this is often direct accommodation.
these pickup/dropoff services often include ubud and all “southern resorts”.
some services out of padangbai offer pickups in candidasa.
amed services to gilis is amed only.
there are also some interisland services. there is a gili - nusa lembongan/penida service.
as an example before we got corona’d in may 2020 myself and daughter were due to do a daddy/daughter diving/chillaxing trip.
we were going to do amed - gili t - nusa lembongan - sanur or kuta.
in november 2020 we had a big family trip (me, mrs pig, daughter/son and bf/wife) and do ubud - amed - gilis - lembongan - sanur/kuta (after which myself and mrs pig were due to go to perth/rottnes island)
kuta/legian/seminyak
as mentioned it is not worth moving from kuta to seminyak. not really 2 distinct places. kuta/legian/seminyak is just a large urban tourist sprawl located along the long kuta beach. kuta merges into legian into seminyak just by crossing the road from one bar/shop to another. legian in the middle only covers ~ 1mile of beachfront. you can actually be in seminyak and be closer to the beachwalk mall in kuta than seminyak square.
sanur is another option as “southern resort”.
it is a large tourist area withthe usual wide range of tourist accommodation, restaurants, bars etc however doesn’t have nightclubs or pretentious beachclubs
itinerary
bali is a big island and once you add in islands there is a lot of variety.
thing is travel time in bali is slow going. you generally won’t average much more than 20mph even away from the congested south and ubud town where it can often be at walking pace.
as an example kuta/dps to ubud is only 25miles but usually takes 1h30.
we transfer directly to amed on landing. it is barely 60miles but usually takes 3hrs without stopping. we go to amed for the diving/snorkeling/chillaxing but for instance we can get to tirta gangga water palace orpura lempuyang temple in 30mins.
it would take 2h30 straight drive from kuta or 1h30 from ubud.
similarly if you would like to visit the waterfalls in the north they are a good 3hrs+ straight drive from kuta. closer if you go from ubud. even closer if you go from lovina.
if you wanted to do things like whitewater rafting, cycle tours then these are best done from ubud.
have a think about what you would like to see/do.
that will ultimately determine your itinerary, where best to stay and which order to do it.

column5:
hi,
if doing your diving certification is part of your trip then bali is a good option.
i dive, daughter dives and wife likes to snorkel. we are (non covid) in bali every year and diving/snorkeling forms a major part of our holidays. we generally stay at the major diving areas like amed, gili islands, nusa lembongan.
our plans for may 2020 and november 2020 was
amed - gili islands - nusa lembongan - sanur/kuta (november was also due to fly to oz after bali).
amed
amed is an area on the east coast. it is popular for diving/snorkeling and chillaxing. it is not a built up tourist resort area. very laid back.
diving is cheap.
we stay at www.kembalibeachbungalows.nl
for a big family trip (me, mrs pig, son and wife, daughter and boyfriend) we were going to book the www.balibeachhouse.com next door until we got corona’d. the property is available on airbnb.
easy snorkeling straight in front of these properties. fall in the water. no organised trips.
the reef is barely 10m from shore snorkeling 1m above the reef.
as well as normal colourful small fishies often see turtles. also seen moray eels, stonefish (dangerous) even baracuda.
a few years ago some juvenile black tip reef sharks (completely harmless) took up residence in the shallow reef in front of the  50m down the beach.
i dive a site called pyramids (in front of kembali) and have seen some white tip sharks. shy and harmless. seen a lot more on gili t.
diving - amed
we have dived for many years with www.adventurediversbali.com
located more or less across the road from kembali.
run by a brit/belgian couple.
there is also www.balidivecove.com
this is run by a brit girl called jordan and her balinese husband. now our dive centre of choice. we have known her for many years, she used to work for adventure divers but we first met her and dived with her in malta many years ago.
she is a fully qualified padi diving instructor.
often after qualifying as an open water diver and/or as part of your qualification dives you will be taken to tulamben (20mins down the road) to dive on the usat liberty. one of well known world dive sites
dive courses - open water diver
open water is the first level of qualified certification. diving down to 18m.
to make life easier you can do all the theory online at home and print off a completion certificate. you then bring that with you to bali. this reduces the number of days you need to complete the course down to 2.5 days.
padi charges for this.
ssi doesn’t charge but you need to then use an ssi registered dive centre e.g. adventure divers.
padi & ssi are basically the same accepted throughout the world.
diving with mantas - nusa penida
mantas can be seen off manta bay and manta point off nusa penida.
manta bay is often awash with snorkel boat trips although also dive trips but for a new diver can be a bit overwhelming with so many people and importantly so many boats on the surface.
manta point better but the problem with nusa penida is that because of strong currents some dive sites are for advance open water divers only with a lot of experience.
nusa lembongan
this island close to southern bali and penida is a popular place to stay. can do diving courses. also get diving and snorkel trips to nusa penida.
on lembongan  is a brit run dive centre offering courses and diving.
holiday booking
how do you intend to book your holiday. if you intend to do a typical “uk” package holiday then you can forget going to amed or other places good for diving/snorkeling.
you will be very restricted on choice of places to stay. often limited to the southern beach resorts and ubud.
if you want to book independently (like we and most people here do) then very easy to fit in a lot.
fastboats
there are lots of fastboat services between bali and the islands and sometimes between the islands.
e.g. as i mentioned amed - gilis - nusa lembongan - sanur/kuta is a thing we do.
fastboat services usually include free bali mainland pickup/dropoff services, often direct hotel/property from the major tourist places like ubud and the southern resorts of sanur, kuta, legian, seminyak, nusa dua/benoa.
although amed isn’t a major tourist centre there are fastboat services from amed to gilis. shortest crossing.
if you want to keep your holiday a bit simpler then ubud - nusa lembongan - “southern resort” is a popular combo.
can do cultural stuff/sightseeing around ubud then go off to lembongan with a company like www.rockyfastcruise.com who will pick you up in ubud, drop you off at your nl accommodation then pick you up again on return.
then do a course with www.world-diving.comwhilst on nusa lembongan.
the downside from my pov is that you don’t have the fall in the water snorkeling like in amed and if one person is doing a course for 3 days the others have to occupy themselves.

column5:
like all sensible bali ta users i wholeheartedly agree with nps above. my hubby and i have travelled to indonesia since we got certified in 2008. it is absolutely superb and incredibly reasonably priced. as well as his recommendations for bali, i would recommend liberty dive resort by the liberty wreck as a fantastic dive experience with wonderful guides and beautiful accomodation. diving with manta rays is almost guaranteed in nusa penida which can be accessed on day trips from eastern bali, so padang bai or candidasa. another really nice place to base yourselves for diving is padang bai. we have stayed in absolute scuba several times. i would also recommend that you book the property yourselves, either direct with them or via booking.com or agoda. a uk travel agency may well not send you to the best places for diving.

column5:
i’ve also stayed at the liberty dive resort with my diving daughter. would also recommend it if you were all there to do nothing but dive.
thing is as you are a family tulamben isn’t the place for non-divers whilst somebody is spending the days learning or diving.
tulamben is very much dive central. ideal if you are doing nothing else but dive. there is no beach just a volcanic large stone shore. there is often surge on shore which makes it difficult to get in and out even as an adult just snorkeling let alone in dive gear as a new diver. would not recommended it for young kids.
if you stay in jemeluk, amed you will have more of a choice to eat/drink etc. a beach. easy snorkeling even for the kids. more to occupy oneself whilst one person is learning to dive.
my wife (who is the non diver) much prefers amed. both myself and daughter as qualified divers also prefer amed as we prefer to have a mix of everything.
we don’t dive dive dive dawn to dusk.
we generally only do 2 dives in the morning always having the afternoon off.

column5:
ok it’s a huge help having a collection included. bali weather is like no other l have experienced, not even india has the same type of humidity. i find most type of pants just too hot for me. i take cotton sundresses for everyday use when lm not really going anywhere and because l do yoga l take extremely lightweight tights, usually nike or reebok have that super light all weather use pants. i can use the same pants for walking, hiking or even everyday use. you can also get some super colours and designs to wear with cotton t-shirts. also you can wash them at night and they dry overnight. i always take a small bottle of liquid soap for washing cloths. there is so much to buy in bali you will be spoilt for choice, let’s hope it’s still that way after covid.
if l was going to bali for one week l would also go carry on, some airlines allow more carry on weight than others but most will allow that small carry on case and a small back pack, it has worked for me on numerous occasions to london and it is hassle free. just buy another small case for return should you need it.
all toiletries are plentiful and available as required, l usually ask my driver to stop at a supermarket on the way to my hotel in ubud, they really don’t mind stopping somewhere. i also buy an entire crate of bottled water as l hate running out and use it for washing face and teeth.

column5:
have a look at the ayodya. best beach in the whole of nusa dua/benoa imo. has the added advantage of a few local places to eat and drink at not nusa dua rip off prices along the jalan pantai mengiat. bali collection shopping mall walkable if that’s your thing.
the only problem, as with many other swimmable areas in nusa dua/benoa (also sanur are and parts of jimbaran) is that the shore slopes down to the sea then quickly then flattens out which means ideal swimming is at high tide but not good at low tides as the sea goes out a long way and reef or rocks is exposed in places.
other hotels on the beach include the inaya putri and grand hyatt.

column4:
going amed directly arrival 5pm see getting amed late, 2.5-3 hours airport. assuming want stop dinner way, arrival late. two nights day amed going gili t.
my suggestion stay extra night amed, giving two full days there, going gili t. come back, transfer tulamben.
as luggage, amed hotel able hold you, not, driver amed transfer amed tulamben tulamben ubud. drivers used notapigsty vouch well, keep luggage safe. link below.
in opinion, tulamben worth couple days. i'm diver, (pre covid) spend 4-6 weeks there, least twice year. busy day trip divers, wreck, early much nicer. kubu seraya area snorkel well, minutes tulamben bay.
column5:
going to amed directly after arrival at 5pm will see you getting to amed very late, it is 2.5-3 hours from the airport. so assuming you want to stop for dinner on the way, your arrival will be very late. and having just two nights will only give you one day in amed before going to gili t.
my suggestion is to stay the extra night in amed, giving you two full days there, before going to gili t. when you come back, transfer to tulamben.
as for your luggage, your amed hotel should be able to hold it for you, or if not, may i suggest you use my driver for your amed transfer and then amed to tulamben and tulamben to ubud. these drivers also used by notapigsty who will vouch for them as well, and he can keep your luggage safe. link below.
in my opinion, tulamben is worth a couple of days. i'm a diver, and (pre covid) we would spend 4-6 weeks there, at least twice a year. it can get busy with day trip divers, especially around the wreck, so being there early is much nicer. you can also go up to kubu or down to the seraya area to snorkel as well, both only a few minutes from tulamben bay.

column4: bali diving four last five years, leaving uk week february. never remember days total, trips, rain day. third days couple hours maximum , usually late afternoon night. weather got drier sunnier february progressed. never stopped anything. wet half days march otherwise fine.
column5: i have been in bali for diving on four out of the last five years, always leaving the uk in the first week of february. i can never remember more than a few days in total, so in 4 trips, of rain all day. about a third of days had a couple of hours maximum , usually in the late afternoon or at night. the weather has always got drier and sunnier as february progressed. it never stopped me doing anything. you may have a few wet half days in march but otherwise you will be fine.

column4: weather become increasingly problematic world indonesia exception this. two weeks ago ntt timor leste devastated cyclone seroja hundreds lives lost due flash flooding key infrastructure many homes destroyed. event april almost unprecedented. recent years experienced wet weather sumbawa flores middle dry season - august/september. general chance less rain march guarantees.
column5: the weather has become increasingly problematic the world over and indonesia is no exception to this. just two weeks ago ntt and timor leste were devastated by cyclone seroja with hundreds of lives lost due to flash flooding with key infrastructure and many homes destroyed. an event like this in april is almost unprecedented. in recent years i have experienced very wet weather in sumbawa and flores in the middle of the dry season - august/september. in general you should have a better chance of less rain in march but there are no guarantees.

column4:

our experiences december hot, humid, downpours, sunny, overcast. sunsets hit miss. occasionally rain spoil plans day life flexible bali wait day. book anything till we’re ground bali. pair “throw away” shoes roads flooded.

column5:
unfortunately, as you’re aware, no one can predict the weather. this year the rainy season was particularly wet. one thing is definite, it will be very hot and humid. depending which area you’re wishing to stay the west coast beaches will be covered in rubbish and debris.
our experiences in december is hot, humid, downpours, then maybe sunny, maybe overcast. sunsets will be hit and miss. occasionally the rain will spoil our plans for the day but life is very flexible in bali and just wait for a better day. we do not book anything till we’re on the ground in bali. i always take a pair of “throw away” shoes as roads can be flooded.
i have not visited in the month of march. june is just perfect in our experience.
edited: 6:54 pm, april 18, 2021

column4:
said nobody predict weather bali lot microclimates. “one size fits all” answer.
it raining heavily area barely kms await raindrop seen.
as example diving east coast amed/tulamben area driest regions bali seeing little rain comparison ubud south coast areas.
when rain bali often heavy lasts 10 mins stops.
that said bali’s rainy season relatively dry comparison places thailand, cambodia vietnam.
balis peak rainfall rainy season similar ko samui peak dry season.
places thailand times much rain rainy season bali.
column5:
as has already been said nobody can predict the weather but also bali has also a lot of microclimates. there is no “one size fits all” answer.
it can be raining heavily in one area and barely a few kms await not a raindrop to be seen.
as an example where we go diving on the east coast at amed/tulamben this area is one of the driest regions of bali seeing very little rain in comparison to say ubud or south coast areas.
when it does rain in bali it is often heavy but lasts 5 or 10 mins then stops.
that said bali’s rainy season is relatively dry in comparison to places like thailand, cambodia and vietnam.
balis peak rainfall in the rainy season is similar to ko samui in the peak dry season.
places like thailand etc get 5 or 6 times as much rain in the rainy season as bali.

column4: thanks help, appreciate can’t predict weather lots historic data available online looking hand experience, visited places similar climates ‘afternoon downpour’ odd rain expected end rainy season told expect cloud cover rain days end isn’t looking for..

apart needs vehicle lost control speed going time.

driver doses (on cruise control?)
driver distracted device car
it car
swerved miss dog

column5:
so do they explain why - it goes over the central reservation?
one problem in thailand has been they don't actually fit appropriate barriers in the central res....... the whole point of dual carriageways is that traffic going in opposite directions is kept apart.
apart from that one needs to know why the vehicle lost control and what speed it was going at the time.
possible answers
driver doses off (on cruise control?)
driver distracted by device in car
it by another car
swerved to miss dog
collided with object in the road
poor road surface - e.g. pothole or flood.
oil on road
mechanical failure
etc etc

column5:
why not just go to the ferry pier area and ask around. there will be plenty of people who can help. also, might be worth putting your head in a dive shop or other tour operator and ask them. get a few prices to see what the rate is.
alternatively, just ask your hotel. they'll sort something out. may be cheaper, may be more expensive.
a word of warning - it is a fair way and the sea can get a bit rough. make sure you see the boat before committing yourself. also might be an idea to check the weather on the day.

column5: all snakes can swim so it is always possible a snake will enter the water to cross a river so the only way to be guaranteed no snakes in a river is to go somewhere where there are no snakes. all that said most snakes will avoid humans wherever possible as they know we are more dangerous to them than they are to us.

column4: #5 hardly thai bashing. little creeps beach patong ripping people left right centre. hostile aggressive behavior cause serious concern unsuspecting tourists brought attention international media occasion. found tiny mark jet ski (that 99% time there) chasing thousands $ compensation poor unsuspecting tourist find police station trying negotiate payment thousands baht deserved. faq updated risk disappeared highlighting risk involved renting jet ski thai bashing pointing pick pockets rome italian bashing.
column5: #5 hardly thai bashing. those little creeps on the beach in patong were ripping off people left right and centre. their hostile and aggressive behavior was cause for serious concern for unsuspecting tourists and was brought to the attention of international media on more than one occasion. if they found a tiny mark on a jet ski (that 99% of the time was already there) they would be chasing thousands of $ in compensation and the poor unsuspecting tourist would find themselves at the police station trying to negotiate a payment that was still thousands of baht more than they deserved. just because the faq hasn't been updated doesn't mean the risk has disappeared and highlighting the risk involved in renting a jet ski is not thai bashing any more than pointing out there are pick pockets in rome is italian bashing.

column5:
help! i am overwhelmed with options, and i need help cutting things down. a couple things as a backdrop:
'
1. we are in our mid 30s.
2. we are looking to travel in june of 2021, and we will be fully covid vaccinated.
3. looking to spend around 7/8k total on the trip - approximately 8-10 days.
4. we are not tremendously adventurous, we want to go for walks, eat, lay around and read; maybe a boat ride or two. mellow.
4. we are 4 seasons people, but i want to try something more affordable (but still amazing). it seems like thailand has luxurious affordable options that i want to explore. (the tubkaak resort is an example of what i think looks amazing and much more affordable)
5. we like the idea of trying two different hotels in close but different scenes.
6. we like private rooms with amazing views. we want a pretty beach that is swimmable.
7. not a must, but we do like the private pools.
8. we settled on thailand for the following reasons: 1) caribbean/east mexico - takes just as long to get to from west coast (us), more expensive, and the seaweed issue is out of control. 2) cabo - the water isn't the same and you can't really swim at their beaches. 3) hawaii - my wife is from hawaii, so it does not really feel like a vacation. 4) fiji/tahiti - holy smokes it's expensive.
this is our first time in southeast asia (or asia at all). we are open to any and all suggestions. thanks!

notice replies, like-minded, enjoy knocking city's nook & crannies, 'too long' possible. others, agree sort of, nights enough see 'iconic' sites, along market temple 3.

being weekend pros & cons, festive & open, crowded. enjoy knocking & exploring city's non touristy side, love it.

column5:
i notice the replies, some are like-minded, and enjoy knocking around the city's nook & crannies, and 'too long' isn't possible. others, and agree sort of, 3 or 4 nights is more than enough to see the 'iconic' sites, along with a market and or temple or 3.
if living in london, relative, you may or may not like the big mango. i know my first few visits, i hated it, and thought it nothing more than a giant slum. although, i did stay on lower suk, and didn't explore much. if used to squeaky clean western hygiene (appearance / smells (lack of sewer), then you can easily be put off.
now, after so many visits (100+) and still haven't seen it all, as krung thep metro is huge, i love arriving. and after a short week, i love leaving .... 🤣🤣🤣
being there on weekend has its pros & cons, more festive & more things open, but crowded. if you enjoy just knocking around & exploring a city's non touristy side, you'll love it.
but .... since coming from a big city, if so, and wanting beach time, you may want to prioritize that on first visit, as big city feeling can be found at home. especially coming from uk, as any beach, even thai's crappy ones along with warm weather would be a relief, from what i hear & read.🤣
my first thai beach experience was 20+ years ago, phuket, and got me on thinking about retiring in thailand. trip was actually a recon for retirement. 2nd beach holiday was pp, and sealed the idea.
hindsight, and when thailand opens to 'normal' tourism, i think pp would be my priority, as slow starting up again, before it turns back into a tourist ghetto, i think i'd prioritize my first visit after c19 there. save extensive exploration of the big mango for a later visit, as any changes there, will be for the better as they are revamping some areas already, and quite nicely.
about to revisit pp myself, before 2022, as looking lovely without tourist.
good thing not into "museums/galleries" .... they really suck here.
edited: 7:23 pm, january 16, 2021

column4:
everyone forums ideas what's best, you. mr cycling good summary. somewhere "touristy" businesses set tours show speak reasonable level english. somewhere "thai" harder understood tours thais like. recommend latter timer unless person adventurous.
i'm never quite sure people "experience thai culture", thailand experiencing thai culture, town catering tourists. want "real" thai culture buy meal 7-11 sit play cell phone hours, that's people mean. trying lots different thai food good start otherwise friendly thais meet along way small conversations (but wary ones friendly ulterior motives).
anyway suggestion, i'm personally fan hua hin beach awful, phuket/krabi area samui good starting places, depends time year different weather patterns.
column5:
everyone on the forums will have their ideas of what's best, but really it's up to you. mr cycling has a good summary. you can go somewhere a bit more "touristy" where there are businesses set up who can take you on tours and show you things to do and will speak a reasonable level of english. or you can go somewhere more "thai" but it might be a bit harder to make yourself understood and you'll do tours for things that thais like. i myself probably wouldn't recommend the latter for a first timer unless the person is really adventurous.
i'm also never quite sure what people mean when they say "experience thai culture", as if you're in thailand you're already experiencing thai culture, even if in a town catering to tourists. i mean if you want "real" thai culture then buy a meal from a 7-11 then sit and play on your cell phone for 3 hours, but i don't think that's what people mean. trying lots of different thai food is a good start and otherwise just be friendly to all the thais you meet along the way and have some small conversations (but be wary of the ones who are too friendly as they may have ulterior motives).
anyway to make a suggestion, i'm personally not a fan of hua hin as the beach is awful, but phuket/krabi area or samui are good starting places, which one depends on the time of year as they have different weather patterns.
column8: After Bangkok which beach or island would you recommend?

column4: coming perfect time side thailand narrow much. travelled extensively mainland cannot help that. samui much smaller phuket main sites easily covered day neat temples views. beaches lovely could two centre koh phangan / koh tao (diving / snorkelling) holiday. given interest kayaking phang nga bay stunning lots options island hop trips water available phuket krabi. leave local expert due easier access islands imho views pick beach krabi.
column5: you are coming at the perfect time for either side of thailand so that doesn't narrow things down much. i haven't travelled extensively on the mainland so cannot help with that. samui is much smaller than phuket and the main sites are easily covered in a day with some neat temples and views. the beaches are lovely and you could two centre with koh phangan and / or koh tao (diving / snorkelling) which would be a great holiday. given your interest in kayaking phang nga bay is stunning with lots of options to island hop and trips on the water available from phuket or krabi. i will leave it to a local expert but i think due to the easier access to islands and imho better views i would pick a beach in krabi.

column5:
hi all,
thanks very much for all your most helpful responses, it is very much appreciated.
on the cv19 situation and the travel agent, while we would never ordinarily book via a travel agent given the pandemic there is far greater security with booking through our agent as if there are quarantine requirements or government advice not to travel to thailand then our travel agent will refund or reschedule our trip.
we appreciate that there is a lot of moving about, though we really do get bored from being in one area for more than 6-7 days. if we are to remove a destination it would probably be koh tao given the poor reviews our hotel received, though we were really looking forward to the diving in koh tao, and the general vibe in the island. would anyone know if there would be good diving in other areas, we heard koh samui?
we heard that railay beach in krabi is supposed to be one of the nicest in krabi, and indeed the rayavadee hotel there looks very nice, though may be a little out of our budget, and our provisional hotel in krabi, the ritz carlton, looks good too though. if we looked to cut koh tao we would probably add a day or two here given that there seems to be a lot of activities in the area (boat tours, hiking, some nightlife etc).
koh lak was not in our original itinerary, but as we will be coming form koh sok np and flying from phuket logistically it makes sense. the similan islands looks like a great day trip too and the sarojin looks like a nice hotel to relax in before departing for dubai.
ko lanta was a place we were also considering but not sure if the beaches look as nice as our current destinations and its a bit out of the way.
once again any further thoughts on the above would be greatly appreciated.
thanks very much,
aine

column4:
travelling55, seen previous threads & sorry reply either
though beach person, i'm swimmer sunbather, walk lot & sit beach bars afterwards :). solo traveller, i'm wary leaving bag/possessions unguarded beach, & ever pop water quick dip, people around
the bigger popular beaches phuket & krabi often safety zones marked buoys, swimming elsewhere, long far out, fine, keep lookout, longtail boats & jetskis, dreadful loud noise alert presence long come close
column5:
hi travelling55, i have seen your previous 2 threads & sorry you haven't had a reply on either
though i am a beach person, i'm not a swimmer or a sunbather, i like to walk a lot & sit in beach bars afterwards :). as a solo traveller, i'm very wary of leaving my bag/possessions unguarded on a beach, & only ever pop into the water for a quick dip, where there are few people around
the bigger popular beaches around phuket & krabi often have safety zones marked out with buoys, for swimming elsewhere, as long as you don't go too far out, it should be fine, but always keep a lookout, for longtail boats & jetskis, the dreadful loud noise they make should alert you to there presence long before they come close

column5:
rainman :-) we just go to atlantis every day and take selfies.
okay, i'm kidding.
we are plugged into the local homeschool community, we have visited and spent time in all 7 emirates, and we love hotels so we move every 3 days or so. we have privilee so we visit all of the best resorts and kids clubs. we have gained all of the top hotels statuses. we haven't gotten bored yet! especially when we hear of friends back home who haven't left the house in 9 months and are suffering the bad weather.....

column4:
thanks everyone replies.
well it’s 40th birthday wanted surprise various gifts wanted send birthday card anyway.
as jewellery yes guess could try indonesian store! surprised swarovski don’t indonesian website, there’s malaysia, singapore, china, japan, korea store etc.
anyway, told twinings tins tea expensive indonesia got good deal 200g tin twinings green tea, earl grey tea breakfast tea, likes camomile bought nice tin amazon. perfume actually, i’ve got it. moisturiser there’s particular brand completely unavailable indonesia mum uses she’d mentioned try day.
it’s wanted surprise birthday several gifts show affection.
surfing wild i’m naive don’t simply send address directly tax?
>>> believe customs charges include cost shipping postage well.
mangomunky i’m confused including postage. i’ll paying postage jakarta. misunderstood something.
so essentially put £50 value package, could theory pay 50% amount?? £3 seems incredibly low! pay anything total value minimal?? marked gift?? wonder bad idea mark gift total value £70.

edited: 8:38 am, july 29,
column5:
thanks everyone for the replies.
well it’s for her 40th birthday so i wanted to surprise her with various gifts and i wanted to send a birthday card anyway.
as for jewellery yes i guess i could try an indonesian store! i was surprised swarovski don’t have an indonesian website, yet there’s a malaysia, singapore, china, japan, korea store etc.
anyway, she told me that twinings tins of tea were expensive in indonesia and i got a really good deal for a 200g tin of twinings green tea, earl grey tea and breakfast tea, then she likes camomile so i bought a really nice tin for her on amazon. about the perfume actually, i’ve already got it. as for the moisturiser there’s a particular brand that i think is completely unavailable in indonesia that my mum always uses and she’d mentioned that she would like to try it one day.
it’s just that i really wanted to surprise her for her birthday with several gifts to show my affection.
surfing wild maybe i’m naive but why don’t they simply send it to your address directly and ask for the tax?
>>> i believe customs charges include the cost of the shipping or postage as well.
mangomunky i’m a bit confused what you mean by including the postage. i’ll be paying the postage to jakarta. maybe i misunderstood something.
so essentially if i put £50 value on the package, she could in theory have to pay 50% of this amount?? £3 seems incredibly low! so for her not to pay anything the total value would have to be minimal?? or marked as a gift?? i wonder would it be a bad idea to mark as a gift if total value is £70.
thanks a lot
edited: 8:38 am, july 29, 2021

column4: problem all, fact desert cooler dubai itself. last year desert safari second half august weather quite pleasant (i'd due lower humidity).
column5: not a problem at all, in fact desert is a bit cooler than dubai itself. last year we were on desert safari in second half of august and the weather was actually quite pleasant (i'd say due to lower humidity).

column4:
short stay, area world trade centre dubai mall central gets depends budget decide do.
its worth proper dig internet see what's happening art world dubai radar.
i include:
the older parts town (around creek dubai museum) -  worth look.
the marina (great wander coffee) - looks amazing night
jumeirah madinat (for burj al arab views)
mall emirates (have look indoor ski slope) dubai mall (for fountain show night)
get silver gold metro card. taxis quite cheap short time.
column5:
for a short stay, the area between world trade centre and dubai mall is central as it gets but it depends on budget and what you decide to do.
its worth having a proper dig around the internet to see what's happening in the art world in dubai as its not on my radar.
i would include:
the older parts of town (around the creek and the dubai museum) -  worth a look.
the marina (great for a wander and a coffee) - looks amazing at night
jumeirah madinat (for burj al arab views)
mall of the emirates (have a look at the indoor ski slope) and dubai mall (for the fountain show at night)
get a silver or gold metro card. taxis are quite cheap if you are short of time.

column4: comes quarters & calendars, thailand uses western system. khunbill pointed out, different seasons here: winter (nov - feb), summer (march - may) rainy (the rest).
column5: when it comes to quarters & calendars, thailand uses the western system. but as khunbill pointed out, we have different seasons here: winter (nov - feb), summer (march - may) and rainy (the rest).

column4: snobbery experience.. holiday experience enjoy weather atmosphere food.. muslim dubai place offer hence back.. yes spots alcohol flows choose ignore areas.. benidorm seems typical blackpool strip steroids alcohol flows freely.. holiday - walk doesnt vibe, ive past years!
column5: for me its not snobbery but more about the experience.. for me a holiday is an experience where by i can enjoy the weather the atmosphere and the food.. being muslim dubai is the only place that can offer it all hence why i go back.. yes there are spots where alcohol flows however i can choose to ignore them areas.. to me benidorm seems like the typical blackpool strip on steroids where by alcohol flows freely.. that to me is not a holiday - and the walk doesnt give me that vibe, even though ive not been for the past 2 years!
column8: Sadly I think sobbery is creeping in on here
